sentence_text: Could Inflation Pressures Move up More than Expected in a Hot Economy?A second risk is that labor market tightness or tightness in other parts of the production chain might lead to higher inflation pressure than expected--the "revenge of the Phillips curve" scenario.16As I mentioned, the FOMC carefully monitors a wide array of early indicators of inflation pressure to evaluate this risk.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Wages and compensation data are one important source of information.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: These measures have picked up some recently, but in a way that is quite welcome.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Specifically, the rise in wages is broadly consistent with observed rates of price inflation and labor productivity growth and therefore does not point to an overheating labor market.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Further, higher wage growth alone need not be inflationary.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: The late 1990s episode of low unemployment saw wages rise faster than inflation plus productivity growth without an appreciable rise in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Despite what shows up in the aggregate wage and compensation data, however, I am sure that, like us, many of you are hearing widespread anecdotes about labor shortages and increasing bottlenecks in production.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: For example, as shown infigure 7, the words "shortage" and "bottleneck" are increasingly appearing in the Beige Book, the Federal Reserve's report summarizing discussions with our business contacts around the country.17The message we are hearing in our conversations is supported by a wide range of more conventional measures.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: For example, the survey of members of the National Federation of Independent Business finds firms increasingly reporting that job openings are hard to fill (figure 8).

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Further, these businesses now list "quality of labor" as their most important problem, as opposed to the more typical report of "poor sales."

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: We review a wide variety of measures of this type, and these indicators show what I think most business people see: an economy operating with limited slack.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Notice, however, that these measures are near levels that prevailed in the late 1990s or early 2000s, a period when core inflation remained under 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: While the late 1990s case proves that elevated values of these tightness measures do not automatically translate into rising inflation, a single episode provides only limited reassurance.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Thus, the FOMC takes seriously the possibility that tight markets for labor or other inputs could provide greater upward pressure on inflation than in the baseline outlook.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Our best estimates, however, suggest that so long as inflation expectations remain anchored, a modest steepening of the Phillips curve would be unlikely to cause a significant rise in inflation or demand a disruptive policy tightening.18Once again, the key is the anchored expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Is the Natural Rate of Unemployment Lower Than Expected?A third risk--in this case an upside risk--is that the natural rate of unemployment could be even lower than current estimates.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Some have argued that the Fed should be removing policy accommodation much more slowly, pushing the economy to see if the natural rate of unemployment is lower still.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Advocates of this view note that over the past several years of policy normalization, the economy has continued to strengthen and unemployment has fallen, but inflation has remained quiet.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: As I discussed in a recent speech, many analysts have accounted for the lack of rising inflation pressure by lowering their estimate of the natural rate.19For example, since the start of 2016, the unemployment rate has fallen about 1 percentage point, and estimates of the natural rate from four well-known sources have fallen over that period between 0.3 percent and 0.7 percent (figure 9).

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: If the natural rate is now materially lower than we believe, that would imply less upward pressure on inflation--the flip side of the "revenge of the Phillips curve" risk.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Our policy of gradual interest rate normalization represents the FOMC's attempt to take both of these risks seriously.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Removing accommodation too quickly could needlessly foreshorten the expansion.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Moving too slowly could risk rising inflation and inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Our path of gradually removing accommodation, while closely monitoring the economy, is designed to balance these risks.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: In wrapping up this discussion of risks to the favorable outlook, I should emphasize that I have chosen to focus on three risks that are all associated with the Phillips curve.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: There are, of course, myriad other risks.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: To name just a few, we must consider the strength of economies abroad, the effects of ongoing trade disputes, and financial stability issues.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: I hope my discussion of three particular risks gives a sense of how we approach these issues.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: ConclusionMany of us have been looking back recently on the decade that has passed since the depths of the financial crisis.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: In light of that experience, I am glad to be able to stand here and say that the economy is strong, unemployment is near 50-year lows, and inflation is roughly at our 2 percent objective.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: The baseline outlook of forecasters inside and outside the Fed is for more of the same.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: This historically rare pairing of steady, low inflation and very low unemployment is testament to the fact that we remain in extraordinary times.

title: Monetary Policy and Risk Management at a Time of Low Inflation and Low Unemployment
sentence_text: Our ongoing policy of gradual interest rate normalization reflects our efforts to balance the inevitable risks that come with extraordinary times, so as to extend the current expansion, while maintaining maximum employment and low and stable inflation.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Thank you, Senator Reed, for the kind words and the opportunity to be a part of the annual Rhode Island Business Leaders Day.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: And thank you, all, for sticking with the program for the last speaker of the day.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The Federal Open Market Committee, the body within the Federal Reserve that sets monetary policy, just concluded a meeting yesterday.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: I plan to talk briefly about how my colleagues and I see the economy evolving and our role in keeping it healthy.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Importantly, I want to hear from you.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: I very much appreciate your views, as business people, of economic conditions where you live and work.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: And, of course, I will be happy to respond to questions.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Growth is running at a healthy clip.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Unemployment is low, the number of people working is rising steadily, and wages are up.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Inflation is low and stable.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: All of these developments are very good signs.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Of course, that is not to say that everything is perfect.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The benefits of this strong economy have not reached all Americans.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Many of our country's economic challenges are beyond the scope of the Fed, but we are doing all we can to keep the economy strong and moving forward.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: That is the best way we can promote an environment in which every American has the opportunity to succeed.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Each time we meet, we face the same question: How can we set monetary policy to best support job growth and low, steady inflation?

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: For many years, this question called for very low interest rates to help an economy that had been damaged by the deep financial crisis that gripped the world 10 years ago.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As the economy has steadily gained strength, the Fed has been gradually returning interest rates closer to the levels that are normal in a healthy economy.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: We took another step on that path yesterday, with a quarter-point increase in short-term interest rates.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: These rates remain low, and my colleagues and I believe that this gradual return to normal is helping to sustain this strong economy for the longer-run benefit of all Americans.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As I mentioned, 10 years have now passed since the depths of the financial crisis‑‑a painful part of our history that cost many Americans their jobs, their homes, and, for some, their hopes and dreams.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In addition to holding interest rates low to support the recovery, we have taken many steps to make the financial system safer.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In particular, we are holding the largest banks to much higher standards in the amount of capital and liquidity they hold and in the ways they assess and manage the risks they take.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: I am confident that the system today is stronger and in a far better position to support the financial needs of households and businesses through good times and bad.

title: Brief Remarks on the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: We continue to work to sustain these fundamental improvements while also ensuring that regulation is both effective and efficient.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Thank you for the opportunity to speak here today.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Fifteen years ago, during the period now referred to as the Great Moderation, the topic of this symposium was "Adapting to a Changing Economy."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: In opening the proceedings, then-Chairman Alan Greenspan famously declared that "uncertainty is not just an important feature of the monetary policy landscape; it is the defining characteristic of that landscape.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: "1On the doorstep of the period now referred to as the Global Financial Crisis, surely few, if any, at that symposium would have imagined how shockingly different the next 15 years would be from the 15 years that preceded it.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Over the course of a long recovery, the U.S. economy has strengthened substantially.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The unemployment rate has declined steadily for almost nine years and, at 3.9 percent, is now near a 20-year low.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Most people who want jobs can find them.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Inflation has moved up and is now near the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) objective of 2 percent after running generally below that level for six years.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: With solid household and business confidence, healthy levels of job creation, rising incomes, and fiscal stimulus arriving, there is good reason to expect that this strong performance will continue.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: As the economy has strengthened, the FOMC has gradually raised the federal funds rate from its crisis-era low near zero toward more normal levels.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: We are also allowing our securities holdings--assets acquired to support the economy during the deep recession and the long recovery--to decline gradually as these securities are paid off.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: I will explain today why the Committee's consensus view is that this gradual process of normalization remains appropriate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: As always, there are risk factors abroad and at home that, in time, could demand a different policy response, but today I will step back from these.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: In keeping with the spirit of this year's symposium topic--the changing structures of the economy--I would also note briefly that the U.S. economy faces a number of longer-term structural challenges that are mostly beyond the reach of monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: For example, real wages, particularly for medium- and low-income workers, have grown quite slowly in recent decades.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Economic mobility in the United States has declined and is now lower than in most other advanced economies.2Addressing the federal budget deficit, which has long been on an unsustainable path, becomes increasingly important as a larger share of the population retires.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Finally, it is difficult to say when or whether the economy will break out of its low-productivity mode of the past decade or more, as it must if incomes are to rise meaningfully over time.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: My FOMC colleagues and I believe that we can best support progress on these longer-term issues by pursuing the Federal Reserve's mandate and supporting continued economic growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The topic of managing uncertainty in policymaking remains particularly salient.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: I will focus today on one of the many facets of uncertainty discussed at the 2003 symposium--uncertainty around the location of important macroeconomic variables such as the natural rate of unemployment.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: A good place to start is with two opposing questions that regularly arise in discussions of monetary policy both inside and outside the Fed:

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: With the unemployment rate well below estimates of its longer-term normal level, why isn't the FOMC tightening monetary policy more sharply to head off overheating and inflation?

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: With no clear sign of an inflation problem, why is the FOMC tightening policy at all, at the risk of choking off job growth and continued expansion?

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: These questions strike me as representing the two errors that the Committee is always seeking to avoid as expansions continue--moving too fast and needlessly shortening the expansion, versus moving too slowly and risking a destabilizing overheating.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: As I will discuss, the job of avoiding these errors is made challenging today because the economy has been changing in ways that are difficult to detect and measure in real time.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: I will first lay out a standard view of a handful of basic relationships that are thought to reflect key aspects of the underlying structure of the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: I will then use that framework to explain the role that structural change plays in our current policy deliberations, focusing on how that role has been shaped by two historical episodes.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Conventional Views of Macroeconomic StructureIn conventional models of the economy, major economic quantities such as inflation, unemployment, and the growth rate of gross domestic product (GDP) fluctuate around values that are considered "normal," or "natural," or "desired."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The FOMC has chosen a 2 percent inflation objective as one of these desired values.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The other values are not directly observed, nor can they be chosen by anyone.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Instead, these values result from myriad interactions throughout the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: In the FOMC's quarterly Summary of Economic Projections (SEP), participants state their individual views on the longer-run normal values for the growth rate of GDP, the unemployment rate, and the federal funds rate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: These fundamental structural features of the economy are also known by more familiar names such as the "natural rate of unemployment" and "potential output growth."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The longer-run federal funds rate minus long-run inflation is the "neutral real interest rate."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: At the Fed and elsewhere, analysts talk about these values so often that they have acquired shorthand names.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: For example, u* (pronounced "u star") is the natural rate of unemployment, r* ("r star") is the neutral real rate of interest, and Π* ("pi star") is the inflation objective.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: According to the conventional thinking, policymakers should navigate by these stars.3In that sense, they are very much akin to celestial stars.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: For example, the famous Taylor rule calls for setting the federal funds rate based on where inflation and unemployment stand in relation to the stars.4If inflation is higher than Π*, raise the real federal funds rate relative to r*.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The higher real interest rate will, through various channels, tend to moderate spending by businesses and households, which will reduce upward pressure on prices and wages as the economy cools off.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: In contrast, if the unemployment rate is above u*, lower the real federal funds rate relative to r*, which will stimulate spending and raise employment.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Navigating by the stars can sound straightforward.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Guiding policy by the stars in practice, however, has been quite challenging of late because our best assessments of the location of the stars have been changing significantly.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Shifting Stars during NormalizationIn December 2013, the FOMC began winding down the final crisis-era asset purchase program.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Asset purchases declined to zero over 2014, and in December 2015, the FOMC began the gradual normalization of interest rates that continues to this day.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: As normalization has proceeded, FOMC participants and many other private- and public-sector analysts regularly adjusted their assessments of the stars (figure 1).

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Many projections of the natural rate of unemployment fell roughly 1 full percentage point, as did assessments of the neutral interest rate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Estimates of the potential growth rate of GDP slipped about 1/2 percentage point.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: These changing assessments have big implications.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: For example, the 1 percentage point fall in the neutral interest rate implies that the federal funds rate was considerably closer to its longer-run normal and, hence, that policy was less accommodative than thought at the beginning of normalization.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The 1 percentage point fall in the natural rate of unemployment implies at present that about 1.6 million more people would have jobs when unemployment is at its longer-run level.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: These shifts in the stars generally reflect analysts' attempts to square their estimates with arriving macroeconomic data.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: For example, as the unemployment rate fell toward, and then below, estimates of its natural rate, many expected inflation to move up.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: When inflation instead moved sideways, a reasonable inference was that the natural rate was lower than previously thought.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Further, over this period, GDP growth was slower than one might have expected based on the rapid decline in unemployment and the well-known relationship between output and unemployment known as Okun's law.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Put another way, labor productivity growth consistently disappointed, which raised the question of whether that shortfall was temporary‑‑perhaps due to headwinds from the crisis--or was part of a new normal.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: These assessments of the values of the stars are imprecise and subject to further revision.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: To return to the nautical metaphor, the FOMC has been navigating between the shoals of overheating and premature tightening with only a hazy view of what seem to be shifting navigational guides.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Our approach to this challenge has been shaped by two much discussed historical episodes--the Great Inflation of the 1960s and 1970s and the "new economy" period of the late 1990s.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Shifting Stars and the Great InflationWhile the crisis and its aftermath have been extraordinary in many ways, the shifting of the stars is not one of them.Figure 2illustrates the Congressional Budget Office's (CBO) current estimate of movements in the natural rate of unemployment and potential GDP growth from 1960 to 2000.5Viewed against the ups and downs observed over these four decades, the recent shifts in longer-run values are not all that dramatic.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Of course, these CBO estimates benefit from many years of hindsight, whereas monetary policy must be based on assessments made in real time.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The Great Inflation period vividly illustrates the difficulties this difference raises.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Around 1965, the United States entered a period of high and volatile inflation that ended with inflation in double digits in the early 1980s.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Multiple factors, including monetary policy errors, contributed to the Great Inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Many researchers have concluded that a key mistake was that monetary policymakers placed too much emphasis on imprecise--and, as it turns out, overly optimistic--real-time estimates of the natural rate of unemployment.6

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Figure 3compares the CBO's current view of the natural rate of unemployment in that era with an estimate by Athanasios Orphanides and John Williams of the rate as policymakers perceived it in real time.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: From 1965 to the early 1980s, this real-time estimate of u* was well below where hindsight now places it.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The unemployment rate over this period was generally well above the real-time natural rate, and contemporary documents reveal that policymakers were wary of pushing the unemployment rate even further above u* (figure 4, top panel).7With the benefit of hindsight, we now think that, except for a few years in the mid-1970s, the labor market was tight and contributing to inflation's rise (figure 4, lower panel).

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: It is now clear that the FOMC had placed too much emphasis on its imprecise estimates of u* and too little emphasis on evidence of rising inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The Great Inflation did, however, prompt an "expectations revolution" in macroeconomic thinking, with one overwhelmingly important lesson for monetary policymakers: Anchoring longer-term inflation expectations is a vital precondition for reaching all other monetary policy goals.8

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: When longer-term inflation expectations are anchored, unanticipated developments may push inflation up or down, but people expect that inflation will return fairly promptly to the desired value.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: This is the key insight at the heart of the widespread adoption of inflation targeting by central banks in the wake of the Great Inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Anchored expectations give a central bank greater flexibility to stabilize both unemployment and inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: When a central bank acts to stimulate the economy to bring down unemployment, inflation might push above the bank's inflation target.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: With expectations anchored, people expect the central bank to pursue policies that bring inflation back down, and longer-term inflation expectations do not rise.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Thus, policy can be a bit more accommodative than if policymakers had to offset a rise in longer-term expectations.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Shifting Stars and the "New Economy" of the Late 1990sThe second half of the 1990s confronted policymakers with a situation that was in some ways the flipside of that in the Great Inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: In mid-1996, the unemployment rate was below the natural rate as perceived in real time, and many FOMC participants and others were forecasting growth above the economy's potential.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Sentiment was building on the FOMC to raise the federal funds rate to head off the risk of rising inflation.9But Chairman Greenspan had a hunch that the United States was experiencing the wonders of a "new economy" in which improved productivity growth would allow faster output growth and lower unemployment, without serious inflation risks.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Greenspan argued that the FOMC should hold off on rate increases.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Over the next two years, thanks to his considerable fortitude, Greenspan prevailed, and the FOMC raised the federal funds rate only once from mid-1996 through late 1998.10Starting in 1996, the economy boomed and the unemployment rate fell, but, contrary to conventional wisdom at the time, inflation fell.11

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Once again, shifting stars help explain the performance of inflation, which many had seen as a puzzle.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Whereas during the Great Inflation period the real-time natural rate of unemployment had been well below our current-day assessment, in the new-economy period, this relation was reversed (figure 3).

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The labor market looked to be tight and getting tighter in real time, but in retrospect, we estimate that there was slack in the labor market in 1996 and early 1997, and the labor market only tightened appreciably through 1998 (figure 4).

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Greenspan was also right that the potential growth rate had shifted up.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: With hindsight, we recognize today that higher potential growth could accommodate the very strong growth that actually materialized, let alone the moderate growth policymakers were forecasting.12

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The FOMC thus avoided the Great-Inflation-era mistake of overemphasizing imprecise estimates of the stars.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Under Chairman Greenspan's leadership, the Committee converged on a risk-management strategy that can be distilled into a simple request: Let's wait one more meeting; if there are clearer signs of inflation, we will commence tightening.13Meeting after meeting, the Committee held off on rate increases while believing that signs of rising inflation would soon appear.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: And meeting after meeting, inflation gradually declined.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: In retrospect, it may seem odd that it took great fortitude to defend "let's wait one more meeting," given that inflation was low and falling.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Conventional wisdom at the time, however, still urged policymakers to respond preemptively to inflation risk--even when that risk was gleaned mainly from hazy, real-time assessments of the stars.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: With the experience in the new-economy period, policymakers were beginning to appreciate that, with inflation expectations much better anchored than before, there was a smaller risk that an inflation uptick under Greenspan's "wait and see" approach would become a significant problem.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Risk Management in the Face of Shifting StarsGiven what the economy has shown us over the past 15 years, the need for the sort of risk‑management approach that originated in the new-economy era is clearer than ever before.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: That approach continues to evolve based on experience and the growing literature on monetary policy and structural uncertainty.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Experience has revealed two realities about the relation between inflation and unemployment, and these bear directly on the two questions I started with.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: First, the stars are sometimes far from where we perceive them to be.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: In particular, we now know that the level of the unemployment rate relative to our real-time estimate of u* will sometimes be a misleading indicator of the state of the economy or of future inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Second, the reverse also seems to be true: Inflation may no longer be the first or best indicator of a tight labor market and rising pressures on resource utilization.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Part of the reason inflation sends a weaker signal is undoubtedly the achievement of anchored inflation expectations and the related flattening of the Phillips curve.14Whatever the cause, in the run-up to the past two recessions, destabilizing excesses appeared mainly in financial markets rather than in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Thus, risk management suggests looking beyond inflation for signs of excesses.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: These two realities present challenges.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The literature on uncertainty reviewed at the 2003 symposium--and much refined since then--provides important advice for how policy should respond, although not yet, in my view, an explicit recipe or rule that a prudent central bank should follow.15The literature on robust rules, such as so-called difference rules, for example, supports the idea of putting less emphasis on the level of unemployment relative to u*.16The FOMC's practice of looking at a broad range of indicators when assessing the state of the labor market has explicitly been part of the FOMC's Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy since its inception in 2012.17We have greatly expanded the scope of our surveillance for signs of labor market tightness and of destabilizing excesses more generally.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The risks from misperceiving the stars also now play a prominent role in the FOMC's deliberations.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: A paper by Federal Reserve Board staff is a recent example of a range of research that helps FOMC participants visualize and manage these risks.18The research reports simulations of the economic outcomes that might result under various policy rules and policymaker misperceptions about the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: One general finding is that no single, simple approach to monetary policy is likely to be appropriate across a broad range of plausible scenarios.19More concretely, simulations like these inform our risk management by assessing the likelihood that misperception would lead to adverse outcomes, such as inflation falling below zero or rising above 5 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Finally, the literature on structural uncertainty suggests some broader insights.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: This literature started with the work of William Brainard and the well-known Brainard principle, which recommends that when you are uncertain about the effects of your actions, you should move conservatively.20In other words, when unsure of the potency of a medicine, start with a somewhat smaller dose.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: As Brainard made clear, this is not a universal truth, and recent research highlights two particularly important cases in which doing too little comes with higher costs than doing too much.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The first case is when attempting to avoid severely adverse events such as a financial crisis or an extended period with interest rates at the effective lower bound.21In such situations, the famous words "We will do whatever it takes" will likely be more effective than "We will take cautious steps toward doing whatever it takes."

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The second case is when inflation expectations threaten to become unanchored.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: If expectations were to begin to drift, the reality or expectation of a weak initial response could exacerbate the problem.22I am confident that the FOMC would resolutely "do whatever it takes" should inflation expectations drift materially up or down or should crisis again threaten.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: In addition, a decade of regulatory reforms and private-sector advances have greatly increased the strength and resilience of the financial system, with the aim of reducing the likelihood that the inevitable financial shocks will become crises.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The Current SituationLet me conclude by returning to the matter of navigating between the two risks I identified--moving too fast and needlessly shortening the expansion, versus moving too slowly and risking a destabilizing overheating.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Readers of the minutes of FOMC meetings and other communications will know that our discussions focus keenly on the relative salience of these risks.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The diversity of views on the FOMC is one of the great virtues of our system.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Despite differing views on these questions and others, we have a long institutional tradition of finding common ground in coalescing around a policy stance.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: I see the current path of gradually raising interest rates as the FOMC's approach to taking seriously both of these risks.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: While the unemployment rate is below the Committee's estimate of the longer-run natural rate, estimates of this rate are quite uncertain.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: The same is true of estimates of the neutral interest rate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: We therefore refer to many indicators when judging the degree of slack in the economy or the degree of accommodation in the current policy stance.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: We are also aware that, over time, inflation has become much less responsive to changes in resource utilization.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: While inflation has recently moved up near 2 percent, we have seen no clear sign of an acceleration above 2 percent, and there does not seem to be an elevated risk of overheating.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: This is good news, and we believe that this good news results in part from the ongoing normalization process, which has moved the stance of policy gradually closer to the FOMC's rough assessment of neutral as the expansion has continued.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: As the most recent FOMC statement indicates, if the strong growth in income and jobs continues, further gradual increases in the target range for the federal funds rate will likely be appropriate.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: Inflation is near our 2 percent objective, and most people who want a job are finding one.

title: Monetary Policy in a Changing Economy
sentence_text: My colleagues and I are carefully monitoring incoming data, and we are setting policy to do what monetary policy can do to support continued growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Nine years into an expansion that has sometimes proceeded slowly, the U.S. economy is performing very well.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Growth is meaningfully above most estimates of its long-term trend--though admittedly, that trend is not as strong as we would like it to be.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: The labor market is particularly robust, with unemployment at its lowest level since April 2000.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Inflation has moved up close to our 2 percent objective, although we have yet to see it remain near that objective on a sustained basis.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Today, most Americans who want jobs can find them.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: High demand for workers should support wage growth and labor force participation--the latter a measure on which the United States now lags most other advanced economies.1A tight labor market may also lead businesses to invest more in technology and training, which should support productivity growth.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: And groups such as some racial and ethnic minorities that still have higher unemployment and lower participation rates could see increasing benefits from a tight labor market.2In short, there is a lot to like about low unemployment.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Achieving our statutory goal of maximum employment in a context of price stability and financial stability is both our responsibility and our challenge.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Earlier in the expansion, as the economy recovered, the need for highly accommodative monetary policy was clear.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: But with unemployment low and expected to decline further, inflation close to our objective, and the risks to the outlook roughly balanced, the case for continued gradual increases in the federal funds rate is strong.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Current Labor Market ConditionsAt 3.8 percent, the unemployment rate is below most estimates of its long-run level, which are now clustered in the mid-4s.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Many other labor market indicators also suggest an economy near full employment.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: To name just a few, these indicators include an elevated level of job vacancies.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: For the first time since the Labor Department began collecting the data in 2000, there are now more job vacancies than there are people counted as unemployed.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: In addition, the rate at which workers are quitting their jobs is elevated, a sign that workers are able to find another job when they seek one.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: And surveys show that businesses are finding it difficult to fill vacancies, and that households perceive jobs as plentiful.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Some other indicators are less clear.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: The labor force participation rate of prime-age workers has moved up in recent years but remains below pre-crisis levels.3In addition, wage growth has been moderate, consistent with low productivity growth but also an indication that the labor market is not excessively tight.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Looking ahead, the job market is likely to strengthen further.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Real gross domestic product in the United States is now reported to have risen 2-3/4 percent over the past four quarters, well above most estimates of its long-run trend.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Expansionary fiscal policy is expected to add to aggregate demand over the next few years.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Many forecasters expect the unemployment rate to fall into the mid-3s and to remain there for an extended period.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: If that comes to pass, it will mean the lowest unemployment in the United States since the late 1960s.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: A historical comparisonBecause we have so little experience with very low unemployment, it is interesting to compare today's labor market with that earlier period.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Unemployment was below 4 percent from February 1966 through January 1970.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: During that time, inflation as measured by the price index for personal consumption expenditures increased from below 2 percent in 1965 to about 5 percent in 1970.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: In hindsight, unemployment is now widely thought to have been unsustainably low at that time and to have contributed to escalating inflation.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: But how significant is this precedent for today?

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: The U.S. economy has changed in many ways over the past 50 years.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: By some estimates, the natural rate of unemployment is substantially lower now.4For example, the Congressional Budget Office now estimates that the natural rate was about 5‑3/4 percent (and rising) in the late 1960s, compared with 4-3/4 percent at present.5

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Rising education levels do point to a decline in the natural rate since the 1960s, because more highly educated people are less likely to be unemployed.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: The share of the population with a college degree has risen from less than 15 percent in the late 1960s to nearly 40 percent now, and the share with less than a high school degree has declined from 45 percent to about 5 percent.6Another important difference from the 1960s is that inflation has been low and stable for an extended period, which has better anchored inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Today policymakers have a greater appreciation of the role expectations play in inflation dynamics and a clearer commitment to maintaining low and stable inflation.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Unfortunately, with the passage of a half-century and important changes in the structure of our economy and in central bank practices, in my view the historical comparison does not shed as much light as we might have hoped.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Questions prompted by a tight labor marketThe lack of useful historical precedent leaves us with some uncertainty about the answers to several important and challenging questions.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: First, estimates of the natural rate of unemployment by Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) participants and others have drifted lower as unemployment has declined without much apparent reaction from inflation.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: How reliable are these estimates?

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Natural rate estimates have always been uncertain, and may be even more so now as inflation has become less responsive to the unemployment rate.7The anchoring of expectations is a welcome development and has likely played a role in flattening the Phillips curve.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: But a flatter Phillips curve makes it harder to assess whether movements in inflation reflect the cyclical position of the economy or other influences.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Second, what would be the consequences for inflation if unemployment were to run well below the natural rate for an extended period?

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: The flat Phillips curve suggests that the implications for inflation might not be large, although a very tight labor market could lead to larger, nonlinear effects.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Research on this question is ambiguous, again reflecting the limited historical experience.8We should also remember that where inflation expectations are well anchored, it is likely because central banks have kept inflation under control.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: If central banks were instead to try to exploit the nonresponsiveness of inflation to low unemployment and push resource utilization significantly and persistently past sustainable levels, the public might begin to question our commitment to low inflation, and expectations could come under upward pressure.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: So far, we see no signs of this.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: If anything, some measures of longer-term inflation expectations in the United States have edged lower in recent years.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Third, can persistently strong economic conditions pose financial stability risks?

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Of course, strong economic conditions are a good thing!

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Such conditions can make the financial system better able to absorb shocks through strong balance sheets and investor confidence.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: But we have often seen confidence become overconfidence and lead to excessive borrowing and risk-taking, leaving the financial system more vulnerable.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Indeed, the fact that the two most recent U.S. recessions stemmed principally from financial imbalances, not high inflation, highlights the importance of closely monitoring financial conditions.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Today I see U.S. financial stability vulnerabilities as moderate and broadly in line with their long-run averages.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: While some asset prices are high by historical standards, I do not see broad signs of excessive borrowing or leverage.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: In addition, banks have far greater levels of capital and liquidity than before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Fourth, while persistently strong economic conditions can pose risks to inflation and perhaps financial stability, we can also ask whether there may be lasting benefits.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: As I mentioned, a tight labor market could draw more people into the labor force.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: In fact, as the labor market has tightened, more workers have been moving back to work and off disability rolls.9There could also be benefits to productivity and potential growth.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: All told, though, the persistence of any such "positive hysteresis" benefits is uncertain, since, again, the historical evidence is sparse and inconclusive.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: As is often the case, in the current environment, significant uncertainty attends the process of making monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy at a Time of Uncertainty and Tight Labor Markets
sentence_text: Today, with the economy strong and risks to the outlook balanced, the case for continued gradual increases in the federal funds rate remains strong and broadly supported among FOMC participants.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Thank you for inviting me here to celebrate this important milestone.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Today is a special day for all of us, since the founding of the Riksbank 350 years ago marked the beginning of central banking.1As we meet to discuss the challenges and opportunities the future may hold, it is worth pausing to note that the three and a half centuries since the Riksbank's founding have seen economic growth and dynamism the breadth and duration of which have been unprecedented in world history.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The Swedish innovation we celebrate today, I believe, is a vital part of the financial foundations that support the continuation of rising prosperity.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: In my comments today, I will explore the road ahead for public transparency and accountability of central banks in a time of intense scrutiny and declining trust in public institutions in many places around the world.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: As you know, the importance of transparency and accountability to monetary policymaking was recognized and became firmly entrenched in practice over the past few decades.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The Riksbank has been a leader in this transparency revolution.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Today I will focus on the less-often emphasized but critically important role transparency and accountability play in regulatory and financial stability policies.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: To preview my conclusions, public transparency and accountability around both financial stability and monetary policy have become all the more important in light of the extraordinary actions taken by central banks in response to the Global Financial Crisis.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Financial stability policymaking has evolved from managing individual crises as they arise to establishing a policy framework that emphasizes prevention.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: This framework now includes measures to increase the resiliency of the financial system; enhanced monitoring of financial institutions and of building risks to the system; and measures, such as resolution planning, that require firms to take steps today to better prepare for future episodes of stress.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: These innovations have placed special demands on transparency and accountability, and we have worked hard to explain them to the public.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The framework is still evolving, and we will need to be open to making changes and to new ways to enhance transparency and accountability.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Government, Central Banking, and IndependenceThis is a challenging moment for central banking.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Opinion polls show that trust in government and public institutions is at historic lows.2In this environment, central banks cannot take our measure of independence for granted.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: For monetary policy, the case for central bank independence rests on the demonstrated benefits of insulating monetary policy decisions from shorter-term political considerations.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: But for a quarter century, inflation has been low and inflation expectations anchored.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: We must not forget the lessons of the past, when a lack of central bank independence led to episodes of runaway inflation and subsequent economic contractions.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: As for financial stability, the crisis and the severe recession that followed revealed serious flaws at many private and public institutions, including shortcomings in supervision and regulation.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The crisis and its aftermath led central banks to take extraordinary actions, actions that challenged the ingenuity of experts in the field and were understandably difficult to explain and justify to a skeptical public.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: While these actions were authorized by law and on the whole necessary to avert the complete collapse of the financial system's ability to service households and businesses, they may have also contributed to the erosion of public trust.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Central banks are assigned narrow but important mandates.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: For monetary policy, the Fed's mandate is to keep inflation low and stable and to achieve maximum employment.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: For financial sector supervision and regulation, part of our mandate is to foster the safety and soundness of individual institutions.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: In addition, we have a responsibility, shared with other government agencies, to promote financial stability.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: I view this responsibility as being highly complementary to other aspects of our mission: Financial stability promotes sustainable economic growth, and a stable, well-functioning financial system is an effective transmission channel for monetary policy.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Indeed, there can be no macroeconomic stability without financial stability.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Within our narrow mandates, to safeguard against political interference, central banks are afforded instrument independence‑‑that is, we are given considerable freedom to choose the means to achieve legislatively-assigned goals.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: While the focus is often on monetary policy independence, research suggests that a degree of independence in regulatory and financial stability matters improves the stability of the banking system and leads to better outcomes.3For this reason, governments in many countries, including the United States, have granted some institutional and budgetary independence to their financial regulators.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Financial Stability, Transparency and AccountabilityIn a democratic system, any degree of independence brings with it the obligation to provide appropriate transparency.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: In turn, transparency provides an essential basis for accountability and democratic legitimacy by enabling effective legislative oversight and keeping the public informed.4Of course, central banks also need to stick closely to our mandates; the case for independence weakens to the extent that central banks stray into issues that the legislature has not assigned to us.5

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: There is also an important policy effectiveness argument in favor of transparency.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: In the financial stability arena, there is no better example of this than the role that the first round of stress tests played during the crisis in restoring confidence in the U.S. banking system.6So in the financial stability realm, the case for enhanced transparency is not just about being accountable; it is also about providing credible information that can help restore and sustain public confidence in the financial system.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The post-crisis regulatory system recognizes the importance of enhanced transparency, both about financial institutions themselves and about the processes and expectations of regulators and supervisors.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Before the crisis, supervision focused on the safety and soundness of individual institutions and was insufficiently attentive to risk in the financial system as a whole.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Supervisory judgments about firms were shared with the public only in rare and exceptional circumstances.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Financial stability tools were deployed after the fact, to address specific events that emerged to threaten stability.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: It is an understatement to say that this approach proved inadequate in the crisis.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The post-crisis regime has shifted to implementing preventive policies well in advance of any crisis.7Newly established ex ante policies include building the resilience of institutions by requiring more and higher-quality capital and liquidity buffers; a regime of stress tests undertaken by supervisors; and resolution planning, which requires firms to analyze their own potential for distress or failure and create a plan to be used in the event of bankruptcy.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: These post-crisis policies have benefitted from public solicitation of feedback and in many cases from consideration in open meetings of the Board of Governors.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Transparency and incorporation of public feedback in these areas have produced more effective supervision and regulation.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: For example, transparent and clearly communicated policies make it easier for regulated entities to know what is expected of them and how best to comply.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Of course, as with any large-scale, complex undertaking, the standards adopted over the past decade can undoubtedly be improved.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: At the Fed, we are committed to transparency as we assess the efficacy and efficiency of post-crisis reforms.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: In a sense, stress testing is itself a step forward in transparency.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Pre-crisis, supervisors' views of the risks facing our most systemically important firms--and the firms' ability to understand and survive these risks--were shrouded in secrecy.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Post-crisis, as part of our stress-testing regime, these supervisory views and expectations are transparent.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: We expect that these firms will have capital, liquidity, and risk-management capabilities that are adequate for the firms not only to survive, but to continue to perform their key functions even in the event of truly severe stress, akin to the global financial crisis.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: We make a great deal of information regarding the stress tests public, including the scenarios we use, portfolio-level projected losses for participating firms, and, of course, the results.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: We have also proposed for public comment a range of ways to further enhance the transparency of the supervisory stress tests.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: This detailed disclosure provides the public with a wealth of information on how these institutions would perform under severe stress.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: And this transparency both enhances public confidence and holds banking regulators accountable for their judgments.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: At the Federal Reserve we use a variety of additional means to enhance public understanding of our supervisory and financial stability efforts and judgments.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The Board's Vice Chairman for Supervision testifies before the Congress twice a year.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The Board staff's assessment of financial stability is discussed four times a year at Federal Open Market Committee meetings, and these discussions are summarized in the meeting's published minutes.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: And, since 2013, the semiannualMonetary Policy Reportto the Congress has contained a review of financial stability conditions.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: The Way ForwardThe post-crisis framework remains novel and unfamiliar.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Some of these new policies, such as stress testing and resolution planning, are inherently complex and challenging for all involved.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: As a result, transparency and accountability around financial stability tools present particular challenges.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: We will continue to strive to find better ways to enhance transparency around our approach to preserving financial stability.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Efforts to engage with the public‑‑including consumer groups, academics, and the financial sector‑‑are likely to lead to improved policies.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: Moreover, ongoing dialogue will work to enhance public trust, as well as our ability to adapt to new threats as they emerge.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: There is every reason to expect that technology and communications will continue to rapidly evolve, and to affect the financial system and financial stability in ways that we cannot fully anticipate.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: While future innovations may well improve the delivery of financial services and make the system stronger, they may also contain the seeds of potential future systemic vulnerabilities.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: We will need to keep up with the pace of innovation, which will doubtless require changes to our approach to financial stability.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: As we consider such changes, it will remain critically important to provide transparency and accountability.

title: Financial Stability and Central Bank Transparency
sentence_text: By doing so, we strengthen the foundation of democratic legitimacy that enables central banks to serve the needs of our citizens, in the long and proud tradition of the Riksbank.
