title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Thank you for inviting me to join you today as part of this distinguished panel.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Our subject is the relationship between "center country" monetary policy and global financial conditions, and the policy implications of that relationship both for the center country and for other countries affected.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: This broad topic has been the subject of a great deal of research and discussion in recent years.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Today I will focus in particular on the role of U.S. monetary policy in driving global financial conditions and capital flows.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: To preview my conclusions, I will argue that, while global factors play an important role in influencing domestic financial conditions, the role of U.S. monetary policy is often exaggerated.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: And while financial globalization does pose some challenges for monetary policy, efforts to build stronger and more transparent policy frameworks and a more resilient financial system can reduce the adverse consequences of external shocks.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: The well-known Mundell-Fleming "trilemma" states that it is not possible to have all three of the following things: free capital mobility, a fixed exchange rate, and the ability to pursue an independent monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: The trilemma does not say that a flexible exchange rate will always fully insulate domestic economic conditions from external shocks.1And, indeed, that is not the case.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: We have seen that integration of global capital markets can make for difficult tradeoffs for some economies, whether they have fixed or floating exchange rate regimes.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Since the Fed is the central bank of the world's largest economy and issuer of the world's most widely used reserve currency, it is to be expected that the Fed's policy actions will spill over to other economies.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: To illustrate this point, the scatterplot on the left side offigure 1focuses on movements in interest rates and exchange rates following Federal Reserve policy announcements.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: As you can see, changes in U.S. interest rates after Fed policy actions (shown on the horizontal axis) lead to corresponding changes in the value of the dollar (shown on the vertical axis).

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: And because of the dollar's widespread use around the world, these changes in the dollar affect financial conditions abroad.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Fed policy-related movements in U.S. bond yields also tend to spill over to bond yields abroad, such as the German yields shown in the scatterplot on the right.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Such spillovers are to be expected in a world of highly integrated financial markets.2Asfigure 2shows, bond yields (left) and equity prices (right) around the world typically move together fairly closely.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: But the influence of U.S. monetary policy on global financial conditions should not be overstated.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve is not the only central bank whose actions affect global financial markets.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: In fact, the United States is the recipient as well as the originator of monetary policy spillovers.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: For example, as seen infigure 3, changes in German yields after European Central Bank policy decisions also pass through to U.S. yields.3More broadly, it is notable that although the Fed has raised its target interest rate six times since December 2015 and has begun to shrink its balance sheet, overall U.S. domestic financial conditions have gotten looser, in part due to improving global conditions and central bank policy abroad.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Much of the discussion of the spillovers of U.S. monetary policy focuses on their effects on financial conditions in emerging market economies (EMEs).

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Some observers have attributed the movements in international capital flowing to EMEs since the Global Financial Crisis primarily to monetary stimulus by the Fed and other advanced-economy central banks.4The data do not seem to me to fit this narrative particularly well.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: As illustrated by the blue dashed line in the left panel offigure 4, capital flows to EMEs were already very strong before the Global Financial Crisis, when the federal funds rate was comparatively high.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: The subsequent surge in capital flows in 2009, as the crisis was abating, largely reflects a rebound from the capital flow interruption during the crisis itself, though highly accommodative monetary policies in advanced economies doubtless also played a role.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Moreover, capital flows to EMEs started to ease after 2011, a period when the Federal Reserve continued to add accommodation and reduce yields through increases in its balance sheet, as shown in the right panel.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: And, more recently, capital flows to EMEs have picked up again despite the fact that the Fed has been removing accommodation since 2015.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: If U.S. monetary policy is not the major determinant, what other factors have been driving EME capital flows?

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: One prominent factor has been growth differentials between EMEs and advanced economies.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Infigure 5, the left panel shows that capital inflows to EMEs picked up post-crisis, in line with the widening of this growth differential, while the slowdown in inflows after 2011 coincides with its narrowing.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Another related determinant has been commodity prices, as shown in the right panel.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: The pickup in both global growth and commodity prices over the past couple of years explains a good part of the recent recovery of capital flows to EMEs.5

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Monetary stimulus by the Fed and other advanced-economy central banks played a relatively limited role in the surge of capital flows to EMEs in recent years.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: There is good reason to think that the normalization of monetary policies in advanced economies should continue to prove manageable for EMEs.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Fed policy normalization has proceeded without disruption to financial markets, and market participants' expectations for policy (the red symbols infigure 6) seem reasonably well aligned with policymakers' expectations in the Summary of Economic Projections (the black dots), suggesting that markets should not be surprised by our actions if the economy evolves in line with expectations.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: It also bears emphasizing that the EMEs themselves have made considerable progress in reducing vulnerabilities since the crisis-prone 1980s and 1990s.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Many EMEs have substantially improved their fiscal and monetary policy frameworks while adopting more flexible exchange rates, a policy that recent research shows provides better insulation from external financial shocks.6Corporate debt at risk--the debt of firms with limited debt service capacity--has been rising in EMEs, as shown infigure 7.7But this rise has been relatively limited outside of China and has begun to reverse as stronger global growth has pushed up earnings.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: All that said, I do not dismiss the prospective risks emanating from global policy normalization.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Some investors and institutions may not be well positioned for a rise in interest rates, even one that markets broadly anticipate.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: And, of course, future economic conditions may surprise us, as they often do.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Moreover, the linkages among monetary policy, asset prices, and the mood of global financial markets are not fully understood.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Some observers have argued that U.S. monetary policy also influences capital flows through its effects on global risk sentiment, with looser policy leading to more positive sentiment in markets and tighter policy depressing sentiment.8While those channels may well operate, research at both the Fed and the IMF suggests that actions by major central banks account for only a relatively small fraction of global financial volatility and capital flow movements.9

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: Nevertheless, risk sentiment will bear close watching as normalization proceeds around the world.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: What can the Federal Reserve do to foster continued financial stability and economic growth as normalization proceeds?

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: We will communicate our policy strategy as clearly and transparently as possible to help align expectations and avoid market disruptions.

title: Monetary Policy Influences on Global Financial Conditions and International Capital Flows
sentence_text: And we will continue to help build resilience in the financial system and support global efforts to do the same.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: For more than 90 years, the Economic Club of Chicago has provided a valued forum for current and future leaders to discuss issues of vital interest to this city and our nation.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: I am honored to have the opportunity to speak to you here today.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: At the Federal Reserve, we seek to foster a strong economy for the benefit of individuals, families, and businesses throughout our country.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In pursuit of that overarching objective, the Congress has assigned us the goals of achieving maximum employment and stable prices, known as the dual mandate.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Today I will review recent economic developments, focusing on the labor market and inflation, and then touch briefly on longer-term growth prospects.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: I will finish with a discussion of monetary policy.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Recent Developments and the State of the EconomyAfter what at times has been a slow recovery from the financial crisis and the Great Recession, growth has picked up.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Unemployment has fallen from 10 percent at its peak in October 2009 to 4.1 percent, the lowest level in nearly two decades (figure 1).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Seventeen million jobs have been created in this expansion, and the monthly pace of job growth remains more than sufficient to employ new entrants to the labor force (figure 2).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The labor market has been strong, and my colleagues and I on the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) expect it to remain strong.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Inflation has continued to run below the FOMC's 2 percent objective but we expect it to move up in coming months and to stabilize around 2 percent over the medium term.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Beyond the labor market, there are other signs of economic strength.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Steady income gains, rising household wealth, and elevated consumer confidence continue to support consumer spending, which accounts for about two thirds of economic output.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Business investment improved markedly last year following two subpar years, and both business surveys and profit expectations point to further gains ahead.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Fiscal stimulus and continued accommodative financial conditions are supporting both household spending and business investment, while strong global growth has boosted U.S. exports.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As many of you know, each quarter FOMC participants--the members of the Board of Governors and the presidents of the Reserve Banks--submit their individual projections for growth, unemployment, and inflation, as well as their forecasts of the appropriate path of the federal funds rate, which the Committee uses as the primary tool of monetary policy.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: These individual projections are compiled and published in the Summary of Economic Projections, or SEP. FOMC participants submitted their most recent forecasts three weeks ago, and those forecasts show a strengthening in the medium-term economic outlook (table 1).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As you can see, participants generally raised their forecasts for growth in inflation-adjusted gross domestic product (GDP) and lowered their forecasts for unemployment.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In addition, many participants expressed increased confidence that inflation would move up toward our 2 percent target.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The FOMC sees the risks to the economic outlook as roughly balanced.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The State of the Labor MarketAs I mentioned, the headline unemployment rate has declined to levels not seen since 2000.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The median projection in the March SEP calls for unemployment to fall well below 4 percent for a sustained period, something that has not happened since the late 1960s.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: This strong labor market forecast has important implications for the fulfillment of both sides of the dual mandate, and thus for the path of monetary policy.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: So I will spend a few minutes exploring the state of the job market in some detail.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: A good place to begin is with the term "maximum employment," which the Committee takes to mean the highest utilization of labor resources that is sustainable over time.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In the long run, the level of maximum employment is not determined by monetary policy, but rather by factors affecting the structure and dynamics of the labor market.1Also, the level of maximum employment is not directly measureable, and it changes over time.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Real-time estimates of maximum employment are highly uncertain.2Recognizing this uncertainty, the FOMC does not set a fixed goal for maximum employment.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Instead, we look at a wide range of indicators to assess how close the economy is to maximum employment.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The headline unemployment rate is arguably the best single indicator of labor market conditions.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In addition, it is widely known and updated each month.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As I noted, the unemployment rate is currently at 4.1 percent, which is a bit below the FOMC's median estimate of the longer-run normal rate of unemployment.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: However, the unemployment rate does not paint a complete picture.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: For example, to be counted in the official measure as unemployed, a person must have actively looked for a job in the past four weeks.3People who have not looked for work as recently are counted not as unemployed, but as out of the labor force, even though some of them actually want a job and are available to work.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Others working part time may want a full-time job.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: And still others who say that they do not want a job right now might be pulled into the job market if the right opportunity came along.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: So, in judging tightness in the labor market, we also look at a range of other statistics, including alternative measures of unemployment, as well as measures of vacancies and job flows, surveys of households' and businesses' perceptions of the job market, and, of course, data on wages and prices.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Figure 3shows the headline unemployment rate and two broader measures of unemployment, known as U-5 and U-6.4U-5 includes the unemployed plus people who say they want a job and have looked for one in the past year (though not in the past four weeks).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: U-6 includes all those counted in U-5 plus people who are working part time but would like full-time work.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Like the headline unemployment rate, both U-5 and U-6 have declined significantly in recent years.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: They are now at levels seen before the financial crisis, though not quite as low as they were in 1999 to 2000, a period of very tight job market conditions.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The left panel of the next chart shows that employers are having about as much difficulty now attracting qualified workers as they did 20 years ago (figure 4).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Likewise, the job vacancy rate, shown on the right, is close to its all-time high, as is the average number of weeks it takes to fill a job opening.5Households also are increasingly reporting that jobs are plentiful (figure 5), which is consistent with the high level of job postings reported by firms.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In addition, the proportion of workers quitting their jobs is high, suggesting that workers are being hired away from their current employers and that others are confident enough about their prospects to leave jobs voluntarily--even before they have landed their next job.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: While the data I have discussed thus far do point to a tight labor market, other data are less definitive.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The labor force participation rate, which measures the percentage of working age individuals who are either working or actively looking for a job, has remained steady for about four years (figure 6).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: This flat performance is actually a sign of improvement, since increased retirements as our population ages have been putting downward pressure on participation and will continue to do so.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: However, the participation rate of prime-age workers (those between the ages of 25 and 54) has not recovered fully to its pre-recession level, suggesting that there might still be room to pull more people into the labor force (figure 7).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Indeed, the strong job market does appear to be drawing back some people who have been out of the labor force for a significant time.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: For example, the percentage of adults returning to the labor force after previously reporting that they were not working because of a disability has increased over the past couple of years, and anecdotal reports indicate that employers are increasingly willing to take on and train workers they would not have considered in the past.6

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Wage growth has also remained moderate, though it has picked up compared with its pace in the early part of this recovery (figure 8).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Weak productivity growth is an important reason why we have not seen larger wage gains in recent years.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: At the same time, the absence of a sharper acceleration in wages suggests that the labor market is not excessively tight.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: I will be looking for an additional pickup in wage growth as the labor market strengthens further.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Taking all of these measures of labor utilization on board, what can we say about the state of the labor market relative to our statutory goal of maximum employment?

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: While uncertainty around the long run level of these indicators is substantial, many of them suggest a labor market that is in the neighborhood of maximum employment.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: A few other measures continue to suggest some remaining slack.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Assessments of the maximum level of employment are uncertain, however, and subject to revision.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As we seek the highest sustainable utilization of labor resources, the Committee will be guided by incoming data across all of these measures.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: InflationThat brings me to inflation--the other leg of our dual mandate.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The substantial improvement in the labor market has been accompanied by low inflation.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Indeed, inflation has continued to run below our 2 percent longer-run objective (figure 9).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Consumer prices, as measured by the price index for personal consumption expenditures, increased 1.8 percent over the 12 months ending in February.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The core price index, which excludes the prices of energy and food and is typically a better indicator of future inflation, rose 1.6 percent over the same period.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In fact, both of these indexes have been below 2 percent consistently for the past half-dozen years.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: This persistent shortfall in inflation from our target has led some to question the traditional relationship between inflation and the unemployment rate, also known as the Phillips curve.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Given how low the unemployment rate is, why aren't we seeing higher inflation now?

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As those of you who carefully read the minutes of each FOMC meeting are aware--and I know there are some of you out there--we had a thorough discussion of inflation dynamics at our January meeting.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Almost all of the participants in that discussion thought that the Phillips curve remained a useful basis for understanding inflation.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: They also acknowledged, however, that the link between labor market tightness and changes in inflation has become weaker and more difficult to estimate, reflecting in part the extended period of low and stable inflation in the United States and in other advanced economies.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Participants also noted that other factors, including inflation expectations and transitory changes in energy and import prices, can affect inflation.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: My view is that the data continue to show a relationship between the overall state of the labor market and the change in inflation over time.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: That connection has weakened over the past couple of decades, but it still persists, and I believe it continues to be meaningful for monetary policy.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Much of the shortfall in inflation in recent years is well explained by high unemployment during the early years of the recovery and by falling energy prices and the rise in the dollar in 2015 and 2016.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: But the decline in inflation last year, as labor market conditions improved significantly, was a bit of a surprise.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The 2017 shortfall from our 2 percent goal appears to reflect, at least partly, some unusual price declines, such as for mobile phone plans, that occurred nearly a year ago.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In fact, monthly inflation readings have been firmer over the past several months, and the 12-month change should move up notably this spring as last spring's soft readings drop out of the 12-month calculation.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Consistent with this view, the median of FOMC participants' projections in our March survey shows inflation moving up to 1.9 percent this year and to 2 percent in 2019.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Longer-Run ChallengesAlthough job creation is strong and unemployment is low, the U.S. economy continues to face some important longer-run challenges.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: GDP growth has averaged just over 2 percent per year in the current economic expansion, much slower than in previous expansions.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Even the higher growth seen in recent quarters remains below the trend before the crisis.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Nonetheless, the unemployment rate has come down 6 percentage points during the current expansion, suggesting that the trend growth necessary to keep the unemployment rate unchanged has shifted down materially.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The median of FOMC participants' projections of this longer-run trend growth rate is 1.8 percent.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The latest estimate from the Blue-Chip consensus of private forecasters is about 2 percent.7

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: To unpack this discussion a little further, we can think of output growth as composed of increases in hours worked and in output per hour, also known as productivity growth.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Here, a comparison with the 2001-to-2007 expansion is informative.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Output growth in that earlier expansion averaged nearly 3 percent per year, well above the pace in the current expansion.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Despite the faster output growth, however, average job growth in the early 2000s was 1/2 percentage point per year weaker than in the current expansion.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The difference, of course, is productivity, which grew at more than twice the pace in the early 2000s than it has in recent years.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Taking a longer view, the average pace of labor productivity growth since 2010 is the slowest since World War II and about one-fourth of the average postwar rate (figure 10).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Moreover, the productivity growth slowdown seems to be global and is evident even in countries that were little affected by the financial crisis (figure 11).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: This observation suggests that factors specific to the United States are probably not the main drivers.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As shown infigure 12, labor productivity growth can be broken down into the contributions from business investment (or capital deepening), changes in the skills and work experience of the workforce, and a residual component that is attributed to other factors such as technological change and efficiency gains (usually lumped together under the term total factor or multifactor productivity).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In the United States and in many other countries, some of the slowdown in labor productivity growth can be traced to weak investment after the crisis.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Investment has picked up recently in the United States, however, which suggests that capital deepening may pick up as well.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The other big contributor to the slowdown has been in total factor productivity growth.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The outlook for this dimension of productivity is considerably more uncertain.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Total factor productivity growth is notoriously difficult to predict, and there are sharply different views on where it might be heading.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Some argue that the productivity gains from the information technology revolution are largely behind us, and that more-recent technological innovations have less potential to boost productivity.8Others argue that a well-documented decline in measures of business dynamism--such as the number of start-ups, the closure of less-productive businesses, and the rates at which workers quit their jobs and move around the country to take a new job--has held back productivity growth, in part by slowing the movement of capital and labor toward their most productive uses.9

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: New technological breakthroughs in many areas--robotics, biotech, and artificial intelligence to name just a few--have led others to take a more optimistic view.10They point to substantial productivity gains from innovation in areas such as energy production and e-commerce.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In addition, the optimists point out that advances in technology often take decades to work their way into the economy before their ultimate effects on productivity are felt.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: That delay has been observed even for game-changing innovations like the steam engine and electrification, which ultimately produced broad increases in productivity and living standards.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In this view, we just need to be patient for new technologies to diffuse through the economy.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Only time will tell who has the better view‑‑the record provides little basis to believe that we can accurately forecast the rate of increase in productivity.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The other principal contributor to output growth is hours worked.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Hours growth, in turn, is largely determined by growth in the labor force, which has averaged just 1/2 percent per year since 2010, well below the average in previous decades (figure 13).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: One reason for slower growth of the labor force is that baby boomers are aging and retiring, and that trend will continue.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: But another reason is that labor force participation of people between the ages of 25 and 54--prime-age individuals--declined from 2010 to 2015 and remains low.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Indeed, the participation rate for prime-age men has been falling for more than 50 years, while women's participation in this age group rose through the 1990s but then turned downward, and it has fallen for the past 20 years.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: These trends in participation have been more pronounced in the United States than in other advanced economies.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In 1990, the United States had relatively high participation rates for prime-age women relative to other countries and was in the midrange of advanced economies for prime-age men.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: However, we now stand at the low end of participation for both men and women in this age group--just above Italy, but well below Germany, France, and Spain (figure 14).

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: There is no consensus about the reasons for the long-term decline in prime-age participation rates, and a variety of factors could have played a role.11For example, while automation and globalization have contributed positively to overall domestic production and growth, adjustment to these developments has resulted in dislocations of many workers without college degrees and those employed in manufacturing.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In addition, factors such as the increase in disability rolls in recent decades and the opioid crisis may have reduced the supply of prime-age workers.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Given that the declines have been larger here than in other countries, it seems likely that factors specific to the United States have played an important role.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As I noted earlier, the strong economy may continue to pull some prime-age individuals back into the labor force and encourage others not to drop out.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Research suggests that structurally-oriented measures--for example, improving education or fighting the opioid crisis--also will help raise labor force participation in this age group.12

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: To summarize this discussion, some of the factors weighing on longer-term growth are likely to be persistent, particularly the slowing in growth of the workforce.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Others are hard to predict, such as productivity.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: But as a nation, we are not bystanders.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: We can put policies in place that will support labor force participation and give us the best chance to achieve broad and sustained increases in productivity, and thus in living standards.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: These policies are mostly outside the toolkit of the Federal Reserve, such as those that support investment in education and workers' skills, business investment and research and development, and investment in infrastructure.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Monetary PolicyLet me turn now to monetary policy.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In the aftermath of the financial crisis, the FOMC went to extraordinary lengths to promote the recovery, support job growth, and prevent inflation from falling too low.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As the recovery advanced, it became appropriate to begin reducing monetary policy support.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Since monetary policy affects the economy with a lag, waiting until inflation and employment hit our goals before reducing policy support could have led to a rise in inflation to unwelcome levels.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In such circumstances, monetary policy might need to tighten abruptly, which could disrupt the economy or even trigger a recession.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As a result, to sustain the expansion, the FOMC adopted a gradual approach to reducing monetary policy support.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: We began in December 2015 by raising our target for the federal funds rate for the first time in nearly a decade.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Since then, with the economy improving but inflation still below target and some slack remaining, the Committee has continued to gradually raise interest rates.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: This patient approach also reduced the risk that an unforeseen blow to the economy might push the federal funds rate back near zero‑‑its effective lower bound--thus limiting our ability to provide appropriate monetary accommodation.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: In addition, after careful planning and public communication, last October the FOMC began to gradually and predictably reduce the size of the Fed's balance sheet.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Reducing our securities holdings is another way to move the stance of monetary policy toward neutral.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The balance sheet reduction process is going smoothly and is expected to contribute over time to a gradual tightening of financial conditions.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Over the next few years, the size of our balance sheet is expected to shrink significantly.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: At our meeting last month, the FOMC raised the target range for the federal funds rate by 1/4 percentage point, bringing it to 1-1/2 to 1-3/4 percent.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: This decision marked another step in the ongoing process of gradually scaling back monetary policy accommodation.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: The FOMC's patient approach has paid dividends and contributed to the strong economy we have today.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Over the next few years, we will continue to aim for 2 percent inflation and for a sustained economic expansion with a strong labor market.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: As I mentioned, my FOMC colleagues and I believe that, as long as the economy continues broadly on its current path, further gradual increases in the federal funds rate will best promote these goals.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: It remains the case that raising rates too slowly would make it necessary for monetary policy to tighten abruptly down the road, which could jeopardize the economic expansion.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: But raising rates too quickly would increase the risk that inflation would remain persistently below our 2 percent objective.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Our path of gradual rate increases is intended to balance these two risks.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Of course, our views about appropriate monetary policy in the months and years ahead will be informed by incoming economic data and the evolving outlook.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: If the outlook changes, so too will monetary policy.

title: The Outlook for the U.S. Economy
sentence_text: Our overarching objective will remain the same: fostering a strong economy for all Americans--one that provides plentiful jobs and low and stable inflation.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: It is both humbling and a great privilege to be standing here today.1I am particularly honored by the trust and faith that the President has placed in me and by the Senate's quick action in confirming me.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: There is no greater honor than public service, as Randy, Lael and all of our colleagues here at the Fed would agree.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: The Congress has assigned the Federal Reserve the goals of stable prices and maximum employment.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Price stability means that businesses and households can make important decisions without concern for high or volatile inflation.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Maximum employment means that those who want a job either have one or can find one reasonably quickly.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We also have important responsibilities for the stability of the financial system and for the regulation and supervision of financial institutions, including our largest banks.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Through regulation that is both effective and efficient, we seek to ensure that credit, which is vital for a healthy economy, will be available to families and businesses throughout the business cycle, so they can invest in a brighter future.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: These are awesome responsibilities, and the Congress has wisely entrusted us with an important degree of independence so that we can pursue our monetary policy goals without concern for short-term political pressures.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: As a public institution, we must be transparent about our actions so that the public, through its elected representatives, can hold us accountable.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Over the past 25 years, the Fed has been a leader among central banks in improving transparency.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Today, we are open and accountable.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We strive to explain our actions in a way that enhances the public's understanding of our goals and methods.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We will continue to pursue ways to improve transparency both in monetary policy and in regulation.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: When I joined the Board of Governors in 2012, unemployment was 8.2 percent.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Many millions of Americans were still suffering from the ravages of the crisis.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Since then, monetary policy has continued to support a full recovery in labor markets and a return to our inflation target; we have made great progress in moving much closer to those statutory objectives.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: In addition, the financial system is incomparably stronger and safer, with much higher capital and liquidity, better risk management, and other improvements.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Much credit for these results should go to Chairman Bernanke and Chair Yellen.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: I am grateful for their leadership and for their example and advice as colleagues.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: But there is more to the story than successful leadership.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: The success of our institution is really the result of the way all of us carry out our responsibilities.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We approach every issue through a rigorous evaluation of the facts, theory, empirical analysis and relevant research.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We consider a range of external and internal views; our unique institutional structure, with a Board of Governors in Washington and 12 Reserve Banks around the country, ensures that we will have a diversity of perspectives at all times.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We explain our actions to the public.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We listen to feedback and give serious consideration to the possibility that we might be getting something wrong.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: There is great value in having thoughtful, well-informed critics.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: While the challenges we face are always evolving, the Fed's approach will remain the same.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: Today, the global economy is recovering strongly for the first time in a decade.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We are in the process of gradually normalizing both interest rate policy and our balance sheet with a view to extending the recovery and sustaining the pursuit of our objectives.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We will also preserve the essential gains in financial regulation while seeking to ensure that our policies are as efficient as possible.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: We will remain alert to any developing risks to financial stability.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: I am deeply grateful for the opportunity to lead the Fed as we face these evolving challenges.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: I believe that the way we approach our work, the strong values we hold, and the dedication to public service I see throughout the Federal Reserve have been the keys to our success.

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
sentence_text: As Chairman, I will uphold these values and do my very best to further our pursuit of something we all seek--an economy that works for all Americans.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Over the past year, my colleagues and I on the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) have been conducting a first-ever public review of how we make monetary policy.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: As part of that review, we heldFed Listensevents around the country where representatives from a wide range of groups have been telling us how the economy is working for them and the people they represent and how the Federal Reserve might better promote the goals Congress has set for us: maximum employment and price stability.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We have heard two messages loud and clear.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: First, as this expansion continues into its 11th year—the longest in U.S. history—economic conditions are generally good.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Second, the benefits of the long expansion are only now reaching many communities, and there is plenty of room to build on the impressive gains achieved so far.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: These themes show through in many ways in official statistics.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: For example, more than a decade of steady advances has pushed the jobless rate near a 50-year low, where it has remained for well over a year.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: But the wealth of middle-income families—savings, home equity, and other assets—has only recently surpassed levels seen before the Great Recession, and the wealth of people with lower incomes, while growing, has yet to fully recover.1

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Fortunately, the outlook for further progress is good: Forecasters are generally predicting continued growth, a strong job market, and inflation near 2 percent.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Tonight I will begin by discussing the Fed's policy actions over the past year to support the favorable outlook.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Then I will turn to two important opportunities for further gains from this expansion: maintaining a stable and reliable pace of 2 percent inflation and spreading the benefits of employment more widely.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Monetary Policy and the Economy in 2019We started 2019 with a favorable outlook, and over the year the outlook has changed only modestly in the eyes of many forecasters (figure 1).

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: For example, in the Survey of Professional Forecasters, the forecast for inflation is a bit lower, but the unemployment forecast is unchanged and the forecast for gross domestic product (GDP) is nearly unchanged.2The key to the ongoing favorable outlook is household spending, which represents about 70 percent of the economy and continues to be strong, supported by the healthy job market, rising incomes, and solid consumer confidence.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: While events of the year have not much changed the outlook, the process of getting from there to here has been far from dull.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: I will describe how we grappled with incoming information and made important monetary policy changes through the year to help keep the favorable outlook on track.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: As the year began, growth appeared robust, but the economy faced some risks flowing mainly from weakening global economic growth and trade developments.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Foreign growth, which slipped in the second half of last year, slid further as 2019 progressed.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: While weaker foreign growth does not necessarily translate into similar weakness here, it does hurt our exporters and presents a risk that the weakness may spread more broadly.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: At the same time, business contacts around the country have been telling us that trade-related uncertainties are weighing on their decisions.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: These global developments have been holding back overall economic growth.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Manufacturing output, which had only recently surpassed its level before the Great Recession, has declined this year and is again below its pre-recession peak.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Business investment has also weakened.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: In addition, inflation pressures proved unexpectedly muted this year.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: After remaining close to our symmetric 2 percent objective for much of last year, inflation is now running below 2 percent.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Some of the softness in overall inflation is the result of a fall in oil prices and should not affect inflation going forward.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: But core inflation—which omits volatile food and energy prices—is also running somewhat below 2 percent.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: The main themes of our deliberations this year have been a continuing favorable outlook founded on strength in the household sector, with a few yellow flags including muted inflation and weakness in manufacturing.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: In addition, global growth and trade have presented ongoing risks and uncertainties.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We also faced some less prominent factors that always confront policymakers.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Specifically, we never have a crystal clear real-time picture of how the economy is performing.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: In addition, the precise timing and size of the effects of our policy decisions cannot be known in real time.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: In August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics previewed a likely revision to its count of payroll job creation for the 12 months ended March 2019.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: The preview indicated that job gains over that period were about half a million lower than previously reported.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: On a monthly basis, job gains were likely about 170,000 per month, rather than 210,000.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: While this news did not dramatically alter our outlook, it pointed to an economy with somewhat less momentum than we had thought.3

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Uncertainty about how our policies are affecting the economy also entered our discussions.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: As you know, we set our policy interest rate to achieve our goals of maximum employment and stable prices.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: In doing so, we often refer to certain benchmarks.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: One of these is the interest rate that would be neutral—neither restraining the economy nor pushing it upward.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We call that rate "r*" (pronounced "r star").

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: A policy rate above r* would tend to restrain economic activity, while a setting below r* would tend to speed up the economy.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: A second benchmark is the natural rate of unemployment, which is the lowest rate of unemployment that would not create upward pressure on inflation.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We call that rate "u*" (pronounced "u star").

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: You can think of r* and u* as two of the main stars by which we navigate.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: In an ideal world, policymakers could rely on these stars like mariners before the advent of GPS.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: But, unlike celestial stars on a clear night, we cannot directly observe these stars, and their values change in ways that are difficult to track in real time.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Standard estimates of r* and u* made by policymakers and other analysts have been falling since 2012 (figure 2).

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Since the end of last year, incoming data—especially muted inflation data—prompted analysts inside and outside the Fed to again revise down their estimates of r* and u*.4Taken at face value, a lower r* would suggest that monetary policy is providing somewhat less support for employment and inflation than previously believed, and the fall in u* would suggest that the labor market was less tight than believed.5Both could help explain the weakness in inflation.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: As with the revised jobs data, these revised estimates of the stars were not a game changer for policy, but they provided another reason why a somewhat lower setting of our policy interest rate might be appropriate.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: How did we add up all of these considerations?

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: To help keep the U.S. economy strong in the face of global developments and to provide some insurance against ongoing risks, we progressively eased the stance of monetary policy over the course of the year.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: First, we signaled that increases in our short-term interest rate were unlikely.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Then, from July to October, we reduced the target range for the federal funds rate by 3/4 percentage point.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: The full effects of these monetary policy actions will be felt over time, but we believe they are already helping to support consumer and business sentiment and boosting spending in interest-sensitive sectors, such as housing and consumer durable goods.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We see the current stance of monetary policy as likely to remain appropriate as long as incoming information about the economy remains broadly consistent with our outlook of moderate economic growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Looking ahead, we will be monitoring the effects of our policy actions, along with other information bearing on the outlook, as we assess the appropriate path of the target range for the federal funds rate.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Of course, if developments emerge that cause a material reassessment of our outlook, we would respond accordingly.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Policy is not on a preset course.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: I will wrap up with two areas where we have an opportunity to build on our gains.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: A Sustained Return of Inflation to 2 percentFor many years as the economy recovered from the Great Recession, inflation averaged around 1.5 percent—below our 2 percent objective (figure 3).

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We had long expected that inflation would gradually rise as the expansion continued, and, as I noted, both overall and core inflation ran at rates consistent with our goal for much of 2018.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: But this year, inflation is again running below 2 percent.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: It is reasonable to ask why inflation running somewhat below 2 percent is a big deal.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We have heard a lot about inflation at ourFed Listensevents.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: People are concerned about the rising cost of medical care, of housing, and of college, but nobody seems to be complaining about overall inflation running below 2 percent.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Even central bankers are not concerned about any particular minor fluctuation in inflation.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Around the world, however, we have seen that inflation running persistently below target can lead to an unhealthy dynamic in which inflation expectations drift down, pulling actual inflation further down.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Lower inflation can, in turn, pull interest rates to ever-lower levels.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: The experience of Japan, and now the euro area, suggests that this dynamic is very difficult to reverse, and once under way, it can make it harder for a central bank to support its economy by further lowering interest rates.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: That is why it is essential that we at the Fed use our tools to make sure that we do not permit an unhealthy downward drift in inflation expectations and inflation.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We are strongly committed to symmetrically and sustainably achieving our 2 percent inflation objective so that in making long-term plans, households and businesses can reasonably expect 2 percent inflation over time.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Spreading the Benefits of EmploymentMany people at ourFed Listensevents have told us that this long expansion is now benefiting low- and middle-income communities to a degree that has not been felt for many years.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We have heard about companies, communities, and schools working together to help employees build skills—and of employers working creatively to structure jobs so that employees can do their jobs while coping with the demands of family and life beyond the workplace.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: We have heard that many people who in the past struggled to stay in the workforce are now working and adding new and better chapters to their lives.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: These stories show clearly in the job market data.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Employment gains have been broad based across all racial and ethnic groups and all levels of educational attainment as well as among people with disabilities (figure 4).

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: The strong labor market is also encouraging more people in their prime working years—ages 25 to 54—to rejoin or remain in the labor force, meaning that they either have a job or are actively looking for one.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: This is a welcome development.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: For several decades up until the mid-1990s, the share of prime-age people in the labor force rose, as an influx of women more than offset some decline in male participation.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: In the mid-1990s, however, prime-age participation began to fall, and the drop-off became steeper in the Great Recession and the early years of the recovery (figure 5).

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Between 2007 and 2013, falling participation by both men and women contributed to a 2 percentage point overall decline.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Our falling participation rate stands out among advanced economies.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: While the United States was roughly in the middle of the pack among 32 economies as of 1995, in 2018 we ranked near the bottom (figure 6).

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Fortunately, in the strong job market since 2014, prime-age participation has been staging a comeback.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: So far, we have made up more than half the loss in the Great Recession, which translates to almost 2 million more people in the labor force.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: But prime age participation could be still higher.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Income growth of low- and middle-income households has shown a pattern similar to that of participation, with two decades of disappointing news turning to better news during the past few years.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: According to Census data, inflation-adjusted incomes for the lowest 20 percent of households declined slightly over the two decades through 2014, and income for the middle 20 percent rose only modestly.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Since then, incomes for these groups have risen more rapidly, as wage growth has picked up—and picked up most for the lower-paying jobs (figure 7).

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Recent years' data paint a hopeful picture of more people in their prime years in the workforce and wages rising for low- and middle-income workers.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: But as the people at ourFed Listensevents emphasized, this is just a start: There is still plenty of room for building on these gains.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: The Fed can play a role in this effort by steadfastly pursuing our goals of maximum employment and price stability.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: The research literature suggests a variety of policies, beyond the scope of monetary policy, that could spur further progress by better preparing people to meet the challenges of technological innovation and global competition and by supporting and rewarding labor force participation.6These policies could bring immense benefits both to the lives of workers and families directly affected and to the strength of the economy overall.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: Of course, the task of evaluating the costs and benefits of these policies falls to our elected representatives.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: ConclusionMonetary policy is now well positioned to support a strong labor market and return inflation decisively to our symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: If the outlook changes materially, policy will change as well.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: At this point in the long expansion, I see the glass as much more than half full.

title: Building on the Gains from the Long Expansion
sentence_text: With the right policies, we can fill it further, building on the gains so far and spreading the benefits more broadly to all Americans.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I am happy to be here in Kansas City for the 13th of 14Fed Listensevents.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I look forward to hearing the perspectives of the community and business leaders participating today.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Reserve Banks and the Board have been holdingFed Listensevents around the country as part of a comprehensive and public review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications practices.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Almost all of theFed Listensmeetings, like this one, have been open to the press and live-streamed on the internet.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Both the breadth and transparency of the review are unprecedented for us.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: One reason we are conducting this review is that it is always a good practice for any organization to occasionally take a step back and ask if it could be doing its job more effectively.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But we must pose that question not just to ourselves.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Because Congress has granted the Federal Reserve significant protections from short-term political pressures, we have an obligation to clearly explain what we are doing and why.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And we have an obligation to actively engage the people we serve so that they and their elected representatives can hold us accountable.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We have invited you here because we want to better understand how monetary policy affects your lives and the lives of the people your organizations represent.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We want to hear your perspective on maximum employment and price stability—the monetary policy goals Congress has assigned us.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Now is a good time to conduct the review.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Unemployment is at a half-century low, and inflation is running close to, but a bit below, our 2 percent objective.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While not everyone fully shares economic opportunities and the economy faces some risks, overall, it is—as I like to say—in a good place.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our job is to keep it there as long as possible.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While we believe our strategy and tools have been and remain effective, the U.S. economy, like other advanced economies around the world, is facing some longer-term challenges—from low growth, low inflation, and low interest rates.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While slow growth is obviously not good, you may be asking, "What's wrong with low inflation and low interest rates?"

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Low can be good, but when inflation—and, consequently, interest rates—are too low, the Fed and other central banks have less room to cut rates to support the economy during downturns.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: So, in this review, we are examining strategies that might better allow us to symmetrically and sustainably achieve 2 percent inflation.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Doing so would help prevent inflation expectations among consumers, businesses, and investors from slipping too low, as they appear to have done in several advanced economies.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: More-firmly anchored expectations, in a virtuous circle, would help keep actual inflation around our target, thus preserving our ability to change interest rates as appropriate to meet our mandate.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are also looking at whether our existing monetary policy tools will be adequate when the next downturn comes.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Finally, we are asking whether our communications practices can be improved to better support the effectiveness of our policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: After today, we have oneFed Listenssession remaining, later this month in Chicago.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: At the July meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, my colleagues and I began discussing what we have learned so far from theFed Listensevents.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We continued that discussion at our September meeting and have a lot left to do.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We plan to publicly report our conclusions during the first half of next year.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: One clear takeaway of the sessions so far is the importance of sustaining this historically strong job market.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: People from low- and moderate-income communities tell us that this long recovery, now in its 11th year, is benefiting them and their neighbors to a degree that has not been felt for many years.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Employers are partnering with community colleges and nonprofit organizations to offer training.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And people who have struggled to stay in the workforce in the past are getting new opportunities.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Once again, I'm happy to be here.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Now it is your turn to speak.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Thank you for this opportunity to speak at the 61st annual meeting of the National Association for Business Economics.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: At the Fed, we like to say that monetary policy is data dependent.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We say this to emphasize that policy is never on a preset course and will change as appropriate in response to incoming information.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: But that does not capture the breadth and depth of what data-dependent decisionmaking means to us.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: From its beginnings more than a century ago, the Federal Reserve has gone to great lengths to collect and rigorously analyze the best information to make sound decisions for the public we serve.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The topic of this meeting, "Trucks and Terabytes: Integrating the 'New' and 'Old' Economies," captures the essence of a major challenge for data-dependent policymaking.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We must sort out in real time, as best we can, what the profound changes underway in the economy mean for issues such as the functioning of labor markets, the pace of productivity growth, and the forces driving inflation.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Of course, issues like these have always been with us.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Indeed, 100 years ago, some of the first Fed policymakers recognized the need for more timely information on the rapidly evolving state of industry and decided to create and publish production indexes for the United States.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Today I will pay tribute to the 100 years of dedicated—and often behind the scenes—work of those tracking change in the industrial landscape.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: I will then turn to three challenges our dynamic economy is posing for policy at present: First, what would the consequences of a sharp rise in the price of oil be for the U.S. economy?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: This question, which never seems far from relevance, is again drawing our attention after recent events in the Persian Gulf.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: While the question is familiar, technological advances in the energy sector are rapidly changing our assessment of the answer.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Second, with terabytes of data increasingly competing with truckloads of goods in economic importance, what are the best ways to measure output and productivity?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Put more provocatively, might the recent productivity slowdown be an artifact of antiquated measurement?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Third, how tight is the labor market?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Given our mandate of maximum employment and price stability, this question is at the very core of our work.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: But answering it in real time in a dynamic economy as jobs are gained in one area but lost in others is remarkably challenging.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: In August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) announced that job gains over the year through March were likely a half-million lower than previously reported.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: I will discuss how we are using big data to improve our grasp of the job market in the face of such revisions.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
