sentence_text: These three quite varied questions highlight the broad range of issues that currently come under the simple heading "data dependent."

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: After exploring them, I will comment briefly on recent developments in money markets and on monetary policy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: A Century of Industrial ProductionOur story of data dependence in the face of change begins when the Fed opened for business in 1914.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: World War I was breaking out in Europe, and over the next four years the war would fuel profound growth and transformation in the U.S. economy.1But you could not have seen this change in the gross national product data; the Department of Commerce did not publish those until 1942.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The Census Bureau had been running a census of manufactures since 1905, but that came only every five years—an eternity in the rapidly changing economy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: In need of more timely information, the Fed began creating and publishing a series of industrial output reports that soon evolved into industrial production indexes.2The indexes initially comprised 22 basic commodities, chosen in part because they covered the major industrial groups, but also for the practical reason that data were available with less than a one-month lag.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The Fed's efforts were among the earliest in creating timely measures of aggregate production.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Over the century of its existence, our industrial production team has remained at the frontier of economic measurement, using the most advanced techniques to monitor U.S. industry and nimbly track changes in production.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: What Are the Consequences of an Oil Price Spike?Let's turn now to the first question of the consequences of an oil price spike.Figure 1shows U.S. oil production since 1920.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: After rising fairly steadily through the early 1970s, production began a long period of gradual decline.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: By 2005, production was at about the same level as it had been 50 years earlier.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Since then, remarkable advances in the technology for finding and extracting oil have led to a rapid increase in production to levels higher than ever before.3In 2018, the United States became the world's largest oil producer.4Oil exports have surged, imports have fallen (figure 2), and the U.S. Energy Information Administration projects that this month, for the first time in many decades, the United States will be a net exporter of oil.5

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: As monetary policymakers, we closely monitor developments in oil markets because disruptions in these markets have played a role in several U.S. recessions and in the Great Inflation of the 1960s and 1970s.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Traditionally, we assessed that a sharp rise in the price of oil would have a strong negative effect on consumers and businesses and, hence, on the U.S. economy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Today a higher oil price would still cause dislocations and hardship for many, but with exports and imports nearly balanced, the higher price paid by consumers is roughly offset by higher earnings of workers and firms in the U.S. oil industry.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Moreover, because it is now easier to ramp up oil production, a sustained price rise can quickly boost output, providing a shock absorber in the face of supply disruptions.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Thus, setting aside the effects of geopolitical uncertainty that may accompany higher oil prices, we now judge that a price spike would likely have nearly offsetting effects on U.S. gross domestic product (GDP).

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: How Should We Measure Output and Productivity?Let's now turn to the second question of how to best measure output and productivity.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: While there are some subtleties in measuring oil output, we know how to count barrels of oil.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Measuring the overall level of goods and services produced in the economy is fundamentally messier, because it requires adding apples and oranges—and automobiles and myriad other goods and services.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The hard-working statisticians creating the official statistics regularly adapt the data sources and methods so that, insofar as possible, the measured data provide accurate indicators of the state of the economy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Periods of rapid change present particular challenges, and it can take time for the measurement system to adapt to fully and accurately reflect the changes in the economy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The advance of technology has long presented measurement challenges.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: In 1987, Nobel Prize–winning economist Robert Solow quipped that "you can see the computer age everywhere but in the productivity statistics.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: "6In the second half of the 1990s, this measurement puzzle was at the heart of monetary policymaking.7Chairman Alan Greenspan famously argued that the United States was experiencing the dawn of a new economy, and that potential and actual output were likely understated in official statistics.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Where others saw capacity constraints and incipient inflation, Greenspan saw a productivity boom that would leave room for very low unemployment without inflation pressures.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: In light of the uncertainty it faced, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) judged that the appropriate risk‑management approach called for refraining from interest rate increases unless and until there were clearer signs of rising inflation.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Under this policy, unemployment fell near record lows without rising inflation, and later revisions to GDP measurement showed appreciably faster productivity growth.8

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: This episode illustrates a key challenge to making data-dependent policy in real time: Good decisions require good data, but the data in hand are seldom as good as we would like.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Sound decisionmaking therefore requires the application of good judgment and a healthy dose of risk management.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Productivity is again presenting a puzzle.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Official statistics currently show productivity growth slowing significantly in recent years, with the growth in output per hour worked falling from more than 3 percent a year from 1995 to 2003 to less than half that pace since then.9Analysts are actively debating three alternative explanations for this apparent slowdown: First, the slowdown may be real and may persist indefinitely as productivity growth returns to more‑normal levels after a brief golden age.10Second, the slowdown may instead be a pause of the sort that often accompanies fundamental technological change, so that productivity gains from recent technology advances will appear over time as society adjusts.11Third, the slowdown may be overstated, perhaps greatly, because of measurement issues akin to those at work in the 1990s.12At this point, we cannot know which of these views may gain widespread acceptance, and monetary policy will play no significant role in how this puzzle is resolved.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: As in the late 1990s, however, we are carefully assessing the implications of possibly mismeasured productivity gains.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Moreover, productivity growth seems to have moved up over the past year after a long period at very low levels; we do not know whether that welcome trend will be sustained.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Recent research suggests that current official statistics may understate productivity growth by missing a significant part of the growing value we derive from fast internet connections and smartphones.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: These technologies, which were just emerging 15 years ago, are now ubiquitous (figure 3).

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We can now be constantly connected to the accumulated knowledge of humankind and receive near instantaneous updates on the lives of friends far and wide.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: And, adding to the measurement challenge, many of these services are free, which is to say, not explicitly priced.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: How should we value the luxury of never needing to ask for directions?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Or the peace and tranquility afforded by speedy resolution of those contentious arguments over the trivia of the moment?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Researchers have tried to answer these questions in various ways.13For example, Fed researchers have recently proposed a novel approach to measuring the value of services consumers derive from cellphones and other devices based on the volume of data flowing over those connections.14Taking their accounting at face value, GDP growth would have been about 1/2 percentage point higher since 2007, which is an appreciable change and would be very good news.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Growth over the previous couple of decades would also have been about 1/4 percentage point higher as well, implying that measurement issues of this sort likely account for only part of the productivity slowdown in current statistics.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Research in this area is at an early stage, but this example illustrates the depth of analysis supporting our data-dependent decisionmaking.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: How Tight Is the Labor Market?Let me now turn from the measurement issues raised by the information age to an issue that has long been at the center of monetary policymaking: How tight is the labor market?

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Answering this question is central to our outlook for both of our dual-mandate goals of maximum employment and price stability.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: While this topic is always front and center in our thinking, I am raising it today to illustrate how we are using big data to inform policymaking.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Until recently, the official data showed job gains over the year through March 2019 of about 210,000 a month, which is far higher than necessary to absorb new entrants into the labor force and thus hold the unemployment rate constant.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: In August, the BLS publicly previewed the benchmark data revision coming in February 2020, and the news was that job gains over this period were more like 170,000 per month—a meaningfully lower number that itself remains subject to revision.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The pace of job gains is hard to pin down in real time largely because of the dynamism of our economy: Many new businesses open and others close every month, creating some jobs and ending others, and definitive data on this turnover arrive with a substantial lag.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Thus, initial data are, in part, sophisticated guesses based on what is known as the birth–death model of firms.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Several years ago, we began a collaboration with the payroll processing firm ADP to construct a measure of payroll employment from their data set, which covers about 20 percent of the nation's private workforce and is available to us with a roughly one-week delay.15As described in a recent research paper, we constructed a measure that provides an independent read on payroll employment that complements the official statistics.16While experience is still limited with the new measure, we find promising evidence that it can refine our real-time picture of job gains.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: For example, in the first eight months of 2008, as the Great Recession was getting underway, the official monthly employment data showed total job losses of about 750,000 (figure 4).

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: A later benchmark revision told a much bleaker story, with declines of about 1.5 million.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Our new measure, had it been available in 2008, would have been much closer to the revised data, alerting us that the job situation might be considerably worse than the official data suggested.17

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We believe that the new measure may help us better understand job market conditions in real time.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The preview of the BLS benchmark revision leaves average job gains over the year through March solidly above the pace required to accommodate growth in the workforce over that time, but where we had seen a booming job market, we now see more-moderate growth.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The benchmark revision will not directly affect data for job gains since March, but experience with past revisions suggests that some part of the benchmark will likely carry forward.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Thus, the currently reported job gains of 157,000 per month on average over the past three months may well be revised somewhat lower.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Based on a range of data and analysis, including our new measure, we now judge that, even allowing for such a revision, job gains remain above the level required to provide jobs for new entrants to the jobs market over time.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Of course, the pace of job gains is only one of many job market issues that figure into our assessment of how the economy is performing relative to our maximum-employment mandate and our assessment of any inflationary pressures arising in the job market.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: What Does Data Dependence Mean at Present?In summary, data dependence is, and always has been, at the heart of policymaking at the Federal Reserve.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We are always seeking out new and better sources of information and refining our analysis of that information to keep us abreast of conditions as our economy constantly reinvents itself.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Before wrapping up, I will discuss recent developments in money markets and the current stance of monetary policy.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Our influence on the financial conditions that affect employment and inflation is indirect.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve sets two overnight interest rates: the interest rate paid on banks' reserve balances and the rate on our reverse repurchase agreements.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We use these two administered rates to keep a market-determined rate, the federal funds rate, within a target range set by the FOMC.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We rely on financial markets to transmit these rates through a variety of channels to the rates paid by households and businesses—and to financial conditions more broadly.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: In mid-September, an important channel in the transmission process—wholesale funding markets—exhibited unexpectedly intense volatility.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Payments to meet corporate tax obligations and to purchase Treasury securities triggered notable liquidity pressures in money markets.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Overnight interest rates spiked, and the effective federal funds rate briefly moved above the FOMC's target range.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: To counter these pressures, we began conducting temporary open market operations.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: These operations have kept the federal funds rate in the target range and alleviated money market strains more generally.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: While a range of factors may have contributed to these developments, it is clear that without a sufficient quantity of reserves in the banking system, even routine increases in funding pressures can lead to outsized movements in money market interest rates.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: This volatility can impede the effective implementation of monetary policy, and we are addressing it.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Indeed, my colleagues and I will soon announce measures to add to the supply of reserves over time.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Consistent with a decision we made in January, our goal is to provide an ample supply of reserves to ensure that control of the federal funds rate and other short-term interest rates is exercised primarily by setting our administered rates and not through frequent market interventions.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Of course, we will not hesitate to conduct temporary operations if needed to foster trading in the federal funds market at rates within the target range.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Reserve balances are one among several items on the liability side of the Federal Reserve's balance sheet, and demand for these liabilities—notably, currency in circulation—grows over time.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Hence, increasing the supply of reserves or even maintaining a given level over time requires us to increase the size of our balance sheet.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: As we indicated in our March statement on balance sheet normalization, at some point, we will begin increasing our securities holdings to maintain an appropriate level of reserves.18That time is now upon us.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: I want to emphasize that growth of our balance sheet for reserve management purposes should in no way be confused with the large-scale asset purchase programs that we deployed after the financial crisis.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Neither the recent technical issues nor the purchases of Treasury bills we are contemplating to resolve them should materially affect the stance of monetary policy, to which I now turn.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Our goal in monetary policy is to promote maximum employment and stable prices, which we interpret as inflation running closely around our symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: At present, the jobs and inflation pictures are favorable.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Many indicators show a historically strong labor market, with solid job gains, the unemployment rate at half-century lows, and rising prime-age labor force participation.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Wages are rising, especially for those with lower-paying jobs.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Inflation is somewhat below our symmetric 2 percent objective but has been gradually firming over the past few months.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: FOMC participants continue to see a sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labor market conditions, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective as most likely.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: But there are risks to this favorable outlook, principally from global developments.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Growth around much of the world has weakened over the past year and a half, and uncertainties around trade, Brexit, and other issues pose risks to the outlook.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: As those factors have evolved, my colleagues and I have shifted our views about appropriate monetary policy toward a lower path for the federal funds rate and have lowered its target range by 50 basis points.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We believe that our policy actions are providing support for the outlook.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Looking ahead, policy is not on a preset course.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: The next FOMC meeting is several weeks away, and we will be carefully monitoring incoming information.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: We will be data dependent, assessing the outlook and risks to the outlook on a meeting-by-meeting basis.

title: Data-Dependent Monetary Policy in an Evolving Economy
sentence_text: Taking all that into account, we will act as appropriate to support continued growth, a strong job market, and inflation moving back to our symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Thank you, Randy, for the kind introduction.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: It is a great pleasure to join you all this morning for the premiere of KUED's documentaryMarriner Eccles: Father of the Modern Federal Reserve.It is also a great pleasure to be in Utah.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: It has been a long time since a Fed Chair made an official visit to Utah.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Alan Greenspan spoke in Salt Lake City 22 years ago.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: All of the Utahns here know about the Eccles family's enormous contributions to building the economies of the state and the region.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: The documentary will remind us of Marriner's immense contribution not just to the region, but also to our nation during the Great Depression, World War II, and thereafter.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Many Eccles family members are present here today.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: I would like to especially recognize Marriner's grandson, Chip Eccles; Marriner's nephew, Spencer Eccles; and Spencer's daughter, Hope Eccles.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Randy was fortunate to marry Hope, and he has a second Federal Reserve connection.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: He is our Vice Chair for Supervision.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: In a way, I feel that I know Marriner, too.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: I work in a building named after him.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: I sit in the office where he sat as Chair.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: And his portrait hangs in a room where I frequently meet with guests, Board colleagues, and staff.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: When I sit in my usual seat, he stands, looking over my left shoulder, an enigmatic expression—neither approving nor disapproving—on his face.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: More seriously, his legacy endures in much more than a name on a building and a portrait on a wall.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: As the Depression deepened, he presciently recognized that the federal government should act forcefully to put people back to work and stimulate business.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: In a speech delivered here in Utah in 1932, Marriner asked what was the purpose of an economic system if not to allow those willing and able to work the opportunity to do so, to "guarantee to them sustenance for their families and protection against want and destitution.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: "1His ideas helped form the basis of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal and anticipated the not-yet-published tenets of British economist John Maynard Keynes.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: After World War II, he recognized, again presciently, that high inflation, not contraction, posed the principal threat to the U.S. economy.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: And, perhaps most importantly from my perspective as Fed Chair, he is responsible more than any other person for the fact that the United States today has an independent central bank—a central bank able to make decisions in the long-term best interest of the economy, without regard to the political pressures of the moment.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: During his years on the Fed Board, Marriner played a crucial role in two landmark accomplishments that established the modern Federal Reserve—the Banking Act of 1935, near the start of his tenure at the Fed, and the Federal Reserve-Treasury Accord of 1951, at the end.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: FDR nominated Marriner to lead the Fed Board in 1934.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: He accepted on the condition that Roosevelt support a restructuring of the Fed, which had failed to counter the contraction gripping the nation's economy.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: The result was the Banking Act of 1935, which significantly strengthened the structural independence of the Federal Reserve.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: And, symbolically important, it authorized the Board to move its meetings from the Treasury Department to a new building—the building that now bears Marriner's name—on Constitution Avenue, across from the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: During World War II, the Fed effectively ceded control of monetary policy to the Treasury Department by agreeing to maintain a low interest rate peg on government bonds.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: The low rates helped the government finance the war, but after the war ended, inflation soared.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: It subsided for a time but, with the Korean War, spiked again.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: In 1951, Marriner led other Board members in precipitating a clean break with the peg arrangement, laying the foundation for the modern Fed.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve-Treasury Accord of that year separated government debt management from monetary policy and freed the Fed to combat high inflation and set short-term interest rates based on what was best for the economy.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Those are just the highlights of Marriner's Fed career.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: You will learn much more in the film we are about to see.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: In closing, I leave you with this statement from Marriner, inscribed on a plaque in the Eccles Building: "The management of the central bank must be absolutely free from the dangers of control by politics and by private interests, singly or combined."

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Welcome to the room where members of the Board of Governors and the presidents of the 12 Reserve Banks meet eight times a year—most recently, two weeks ago—to decide the stance of monetary policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It's a magnificent, formal—perhaps even imposing—room, with 26-foot ceilings, a monumental marble fireplace, and a 1,000-pound brass and glass chandelier.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It's seen a lot of history since Franklin Roosevelt dedicated this building in 1937.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: British and American military leaders conferred here during World War II.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And, through the decades, our Federal Reserve predecessors grappled with financial turmoil and the economy's ups and downs.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: So when my colleagues and I take our assigned places around this polished mahogany and granite table, the setting and its history lends a certain formality—dare I say, stuffiness—to the proceedings.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As we kick off this 12th of 14Fed Listensevents,Governor Brainard, Governor Bowman, and I hope that today's meeting is anything but stuffy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Reserve Banks and the Board have been holdingFed Listensevents around the country as part of a comprehensive and public review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications practices.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Almost all of theFed Listensmeetings, like this one, have been open to the press and live-streamed on the internet.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Both the breadth and transparency of the review are unprecedented for us.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: One reason we are conducting this review is that it is always a good practice for any organization to occasionally take a step back and ask if it could be doing its job more effectively.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But we must pose that question not just to ourselves.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Because Congress has granted the Federal Reserve significant protections from short-term political pressures, we have an obligation to clearly explain what we are doing and why.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And we have an obligation to actively engage the people we serve so that they and their elected representatives can hold us accountable.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We've invited you here because we want to better understand how monetary policy affects the lives of the people your organizations represent—union members, small business owners, residents of low- and moderate-income communities, retirees, and others.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We want to hear your perspective on maximum employment and price stability—the monetary policy goals Congress has assigned us.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Now is a good time to conduct the review.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Unemployment is near a half-century low, and inflation is running close to, but a bit below, our 2 percent objective.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While not everyone fully shares economic opportunities and the economy faces some risks, overall it is—as I like to say—in a good place.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our job is to keep it there as long as possible.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While we believe our strategy and tools have been and remain effective, the U.S. economy, like other advanced economies around the world, is facing some longer-term challenges—from low growth, low inflation, and low interest rates.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While slow growth is obviously not good, you may be asking, "What's wrong with low inflation and low interest rates?"

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Low can be good, but when inflation—and, consequently, interest rates—are too low, the Fed and other central banks have less room to cut rates to support the economy during downturns.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: So, in this review, we are examining strategies that might better allow us to symmetrically and sustainably achieve 2 percent inflation.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Doing so would help prevent inflation expectations among consumers, businesses, and investors from slipping too low, as they appear to have done in several advanced economies.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: More-firmly anchored expectations, in a virtuous circle, would help keep actual inflation around our target, thus preserving our ability to change interest rates as appropriate to meet our mandate.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are also looking at whether our existing monetary policy tools will be adequate when the next downturn comes.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Finally, we are asking whether our communications practices can be improved to better support the effectiveness of our policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: After today, we have twoFed Listenssessions remaining, both later this month: one in Kansas City and another in Chicago.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: At the July meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, my colleagues and I began discussing what we've learned so far from theFed Listensevents.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We continued that discussion at our September meeting and have a lot left to do.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We plan to publicly report our conclusions during the first half of next year.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: One clear takeaway of the sessions so far is the importance of sustaining our historically strong job market.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: People from low- and moderate-income communities tell us this long recovery, now in its 11th year, is benefiting them and their neighbors to a degree that has not been felt for many years.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Employers are partnering with community colleges and nonprofit organizations to offer training.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And people who have struggled to stay in the workforce in the past are getting new opportunities.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Now it is your turn to speak.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: This year's symposium topic is "Challenges for Monetary Policy," and for the Federal Reserve those challenges flow from our mandate to foster maximum employment and price stability.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: From this perspective, our economy is now in a favorable place, and I will describe how we are working to sustain these conditions in the face of significant risks we have been monitoring.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The current U.S. expansion has entered its 11th year and is now the longest on record.1The unemployment rate has fallen steadily throughout the expansion and has been near half-century lows since early 2018.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: But that rate alone does not fully capture the benefits of this historically strong job market.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Labor force participation by people in their prime working years has been rising.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: While unemployment for minorities generally remains higher than for the workforce as a whole, the rate for African Americans, at 6 percent, is the lowest since the government began tracking it in 1972.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: For the past few years, wages have been increasing the most for people at the lower end of the wage scale.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: People who live and work in low- and middle-income communities tell us that this job market is the best anyone can recall.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We increasingly hear reports that employers are training workers who lack required skills, adapting jobs to the needs of employees with family responsibilities, and offering second chances to people who need one.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Inflation has been surprisingly stable during the expansion: not falling much when the economy was weak and not rising much as the expansion gained strength.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Inflation ran close to our symmetric 2 percent objective for most of last year but has been running somewhat below 2 percent this year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Thus, after a decade of progress toward maximum employment and price stability, the economy is close to both goals.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Our challenge now is to do what monetary policy can do to sustain the expansion so that the benefits of the strong jobs market extend to more of those still left behind, and so that inflation is centered firmly around 2 percent.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Today I will explore what history tells us about sustaining long, steady expansions.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: A good place to start is with the passage of the Employment Act of 1946, which stated that it is the "continuing policy and responsibility of the Federal Government ... to promote maximum employment, production, and purchasing power.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: "2Some version of these goals has been in place ever since.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: I will divide the history since World War II into three eras organized around some well-known "Greats."

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The first era comprises the postwar years through the Great Inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The second era brought the Great Moderation but ended in the Great Recession.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The third era is still under way, and time will tell what "Greats" may emerge.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Each era presents a key question for the Fed and for society more generally.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The first era raises the question whether a central bank can resist the temptations that led to the Great Inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The second era raises the question whether long expansions supported by better monetary policy inevitably lead to destabilizing financial excesses like those seen in the Great Moderation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The third era confronts us with the question of how best to promote sustained prosperity in a world of slow global growth, low inflation, and low interest rates.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Near the end of my remarks, I will discuss the current context, and the ways these questions are shaping policy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Era I, 1950–1982: Policy Breeds Macroeconomic Instability and the Great InflationThe late 1940s were a period of adjustment to a peacetime economy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: As the 1940s turned to the 1950s, the state of knowledge about how best to promote macroeconomic stability was limited.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The 1950s and early 1960s saw the economy oscillating sharply between recession and growth above 6 percent (figure 1, panel A).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Three expansions and contractions came in quick succession.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: With the benefit of hindsight, the lack of stability is generally attributed to "stop and go" stabilization policy, as monetary and fiscal authorities grappled with how best to modulate the use of their blunt but powerful tools.3

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Beginning in the mid-1960s, "stop and go" policy gave way to "too much go and not enough stop"—not enough, that is, to quell rising inflation pressures.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Both inflation and inflation expectations ratcheted upward through four expansions until the Fed, under Chairman Paul Volcker, engineered a definitive stop in the early 1980s (figure 1, panel C).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Each of the expansions in the Great Inflation period ended with monetary policy tightening in response to rising inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Policymakers came out of the Great Inflation era with a clear understanding that it was essential to anchor inflation expectations at some low level.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: But many believed that central bankers would find it difficult to ignore the temptation of short-term employment gains at the cost of higher inflation down the road.4

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Era II, 1983 through 2009: the Great Moderation and Great RecessionAs the second era began, inflation was falling, and it continued to fall for about a decade (figure 2, panel C).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: In 1993, core inflation, which omits the volatile food and energy components, first fell below 2.5 percent, and has since remained in the narrow range of 0.9 percent to 2.5 percent.5Greater success on price stability came with greater success on employment.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Expansions in this era were longer and more stable than before (figure 2, panel A).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The era saw two of the three longest U.S. expansions up to that point in history.6

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Anchored inflation expectations helped make this win-win outcome possible, by giving the Fed latitude to support employment when necessary without destabilizing inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The Fed was cutting, not raising, rates in the months prior to the end of the first two expansions in this era, and the ensuing recessions were mild by historical standards.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: And twice during the long expansion of the 1990s, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) eased policy in response to threats to growth.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: In 1995, responding to evidence of slowing in the United States and abroad, the FOMC reduced the federal funds rate over a few months.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: In 1998, the Russian debt default and the related collapse of the hedge fund Long‑Term Capital Management rocked financial markets that were already fragile from the Asian financial crisis.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Given the risks posed to the U.S. economy, the FOMC again lowered the federal funds rate over a period of months until events quieted.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The 10-year expansion weathered both events with no discernible inflation cost.7

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: By the turn of the century, it was beginning to look like financial excesses and global events would pose the main threats to stability in this new era rather than overheating and rising inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The collapse of the tech stock bubble in 2000 and the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks played key roles in precipitating a slowdown that turned into a recession.8And the next expansion, as we are all painfully aware, ended with the collapse of a housing bubble and the Global Financial Crisis.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Thus, this second era provided good reason for optimism about the Fed's ability to deliver stable inflation, but also raised a question about whether long expansions inevitably lead to destabilizing financial excesses.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Era III, 2010 and After: Monetary Policy and the Emerging New NormalThe third era began in 2010 as the recovery from the Great Recession was taking hold.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: My focus in discussing this era will be on a "new normal" that is becoming apparent in the wake of the crisis.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: I will fast-forward past the early years of the expansion and pick up the story in December 2015.9The unemployment rate had fallen from a peak of 10 percent to 5 percent, roughly equal to the median FOMC participant's estimate of the natural rate of unemployment at the time.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: At this point, the Committee decided that it was prudent to begin gradually raising the federal funds rate based on the closely monitored premise that the increasingly healthy economy called for more-normal interest rates.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The premise was generally borne out: Growth from the end of 2015 to the end of 2018 averaged 2.5 percent, a bit above the 2.2 percent rate over the previous five years (figure 2, panel A).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The unemployment rate fell below 4 percent, and inflation moved up and remained close to our 2 percent objective through much of 2018 (figure 2, panels B and C).

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: That brings us to 2019.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Before turning to issues occupying center stage at present, I want to address a long-running issue that I discussed here last year: tracking the "stars" that serve as guideposts for monetary policy.10These include u*, the natural rate of unemployment, and r*, the neutral real rate of interest.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Unlike celestial stars, these stars move unpredictably and cannot be directly observed.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We must judge their locations as best we can based on incoming data and then add an element of risk management to be able to use them as guides.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Since 2012, declining unemployment has had surprisingly little effect on inflation, prompting a steady decline in estimates of u* (figure 3).11Standard estimates of r* have declined between 2 and 3 percentage points over the past two decades.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Some argue that the effective decline is even larger.12Incorporating a lower value of u* into policymaking does not require a significant change in our approach.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The significant fall in r*, however, may demand more fundamental change.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: A lower r* combined with low inflation means that interest rates will run, on average, significantly closer to their effective lower bound.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The key question raised by this era, then, is how we can best support maximum employment and price stability in a world with a low neutral interest rate.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Current Policy and the Three Key QuestionsLet me turn now to the current implications for monetary policy of the questions raised by these three eras.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The first era raised the question of whether the Fed can avoid excessive inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Inflation has averaged less than 2 percent over the past 25 years, and low inflation has been the main concern for the past decade.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Low inflation seems to be the problem of this era, not high inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Nonetheless, in the unlikely event that signs of too-high inflation return, we have proven tools to address such a situation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The second era's question—whether long expansions inevitably breed financial excesses—is a challenging and timely one.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Hyman Minsky long argued that, as an expansion continues and memories of the previous downturn fade, financial risk management deteriorates and risks are increasingly underappreciated.13This observation has spurred much discussion.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: At the end of the day, we cannot prevent people from finding ways to take excessive financial risks.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: But we can work to make sure that they bear the costs of their decisions, and that the financial system as a whole continues to function effectively.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Since the crisis, Congress, the Fed, and other regulatory authorities here and around the world have taken substantial steps to achieve these goals.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Banks and other key institutions have significantly more capital and more stable funding than before the crisis.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We comprehensively review financial stability every quarter and release our assessments twice a year to highlight areas of concern and allow oversight of our efforts.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We have not seen unsustainable borrowing, financial booms, or other excesses of the sort that occurred at times during the Great Moderation, and I continue to judge overall financial stability risks to be moderate.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: That leaves the third question of how, in this low r* world, the Fed can best support the economy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: A low neutral interest rate presents both near-term and longer-term challenges.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: I will begin with the current context.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Because today's setting is both challenging and unique in many ways, it may be useful to lay out some general principles for assessing and implementing appropriate policy and to describe how we have been applying those principles.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Through the FOMC's setting of the federal funds rate target range and our communications about the likely path forward for policy and the economy, we seek to influence broader financial conditions to promote maximum employment and price stability.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: In forming judgments about the appropriate stance of policy, the Committee digests a broad range of data and other information to assess the current state of the economy, the most likely outlook for the future, and meaningful risks to that outlook.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Because the most important effects of monetary policy are felt with uncertain lags of a year or more, the Committee must attempt to look through what may be passing developments and focus on things that seem likely to affect the outlook over time or that pose a material risk of doing so.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Risk management enters our decisionmaking because of both the uncertainty about the effects of recent developments and the uncertainty we face regarding structural aspects of the economy, including the natural rate of unemployment and the neutral rate of interest.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: It will at times be appropriate for us to tilt policy one way or the other because of prominent risks.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Finally, we have a responsibility to explain what we are doing and why we are doing it so the American people and their elected representatives in Congress can provide oversight and hold us accountable.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We have much experience in addressing typical macroeconomic developments under this framework.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: But fitting trade policy uncertainty into this framework is a new challenge.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Setting trade policy is the business of Congress and the Administration, not that of the Fed.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Our assignment is to use monetary policy to foster our statutory goals.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: In principle, anything that affects the outlook for employment and inflation could also affect the appropriate stance of monetary policy, and that could include uncertainty about trade policy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: There are, however, no recent precedents to guide any policy response to the current situation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Moreover, while monetary policy is a powerful tool that works to support consumer spending, business investment, and public confidence, it cannot provide a settled rulebook for international trade.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We can, however, try to look through what may be passing events, focus on how trade developments are affecting the outlook, and adjust policy to promote our objectives.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: This approach is illustrated by the way incoming data have shaped the likely path of policy this year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The outlook for the U.S. economy since the start of the year has continued to be a favorable one.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Business investment and manufacturing have weakened, but solid job growth and rising wages have been driving robust consumption and supporting moderate growth overall.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: As the year has progressed, we have been monitoring three factors that are weighing on this favorable outlook: slowing global growth, trade policy uncertainty, and muted inflation.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The global growth outlook has been deteriorating since the middle of last year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Trade policy uncertainty seems to be playing a role in the global slowdown and in weak manufacturing and capital spending in the United States.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Inflation fell below our objective at the start of the year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: It appears to be moving back up closer to our symmetric 2 percent objective, but there are concerns about a more prolonged shortfall.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Committee participants have generally reacted to these developments and the risks they pose by shifting down their projections of the appropriate federal funds rate path.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Along with July's rate cut, the shifts in the anticipated path of policy have eased financial conditions and help explain why the outlook for inflation and employment remains largely favorable.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Turning to the current context, we are carefully watching developments as we assess their implications for the U.S. outlook and the path of monetary policy.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The three weeks since our July FOMC meeting have been eventful, beginning with the announcement of new tariffs on imports from China.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We have seen further evidence of a global slowdown, notably in Germany and China.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Geopolitical events have been much in the news, including the growing possibility of a hard Brexit, rising tensions in Hong Kong, and the dissolution of the Italian government.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Financial markets have reacted strongly to this complex, turbulent picture.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Equity markets have been volatile.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Long-term bond rates around the world have moved down sharply to near post-crisis lows.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Meanwhile, the U.S. economy has continued to perform well overall, driven by consumer spending.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Job creation has slowed from last year's pace but is still above overall labor force growth.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Inflation seems to be moving up closer to 2 percent.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Based on our assessment of the implications of these developments, we will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near its symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The Three Questions in the Longer RunLooking back over the three eras, monetary policy has evolved to address new challenges as they have arisen.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The inflation targeting regime that emerged after the Great Inflation has led to vastly improved outcomes for employment and price stability around the world.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: One result has been much longer expansions, which often brought with them the buildup of financial risk.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: This new pattern has led us to understand that assuring financial stability over time requires much greater resilience in our financial system, particularly for our largest, most complex banks.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: As we look back over the decade since the end of the financial crisis, we can again see fundamental economic changes that call for a reassessment of our policy framework.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: The current era has been characterized by much lower neutral interest rates, disinflationary pressures, and slower growth.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We face heightened risks of lengthy, difficult-to-escape periods in which our policy interest rate is pinned near zero.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: To address this new normal, we are conducting a public review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications—the first of its kind for the Federal Reserve.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We are evaluating the pros and cons of strategies that aim to reverse past misses of our inflation objective.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We are examining the monetary policy tools we have used both in calm times and in crisis, and we are asking whether we should expand our toolkit.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: In addition, we are looking at how we might improve the communication of our policy framework.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: Public engagement, unprecedented in scope for the Fed, is at the heart of this effort.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: ThroughFed Listensevents live-streamed on the internet, we are hearing a diverse range of perspectives not only from academic experts, but also from representatives of consumer, labor, business, community, and other groups.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We have begun a series of FOMC meetings at which we will discuss these questions.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: We will continue reporting on our discussions in the FOMC minutes and share our conclusions when we finish the review next year.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
sentence_text: I will conclude by saying that we are deeply committed to fulfilling our mandate in this challenging era, and I look forward to the valuable insights that will, I am confident, be shared at this symposium.

title: Challenges for Monetary Policy
