title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Seventy-five years ago this month, the foremost economic and policy minds of their generation gathered in a sleepy mountain town in New England.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: While World War II still raged, they envisioned a new international monetary system with rules, procedures, and institutions—including the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank—to promote recovery and stability in a war-ravaged world.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Today we gather in Paris, the City of Light, to recognize their vision.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: The Bretton Woods institutions played a pivotal role after the war in rebuilding economies and in facilitating the international economic relations that are essential to prosperity.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Generations later, the World Bank and the IMF continue to play important roles in fostering global monetary cooperation, financial stability, and international trade, as well as in promoting sustainable economic growth and reducing poverty.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: In 1944, those who sat around the table at the Mount Washington Hotel knew that the trauma and tragedy of the war and the Great Depression had fundamentally altered the economic systems that preceded them.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: For us, around our dinner tables tonight, a decade has passed since the Global Financial Crisis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Although in no way comparable to the devastating events of the 1930s and 1940s, the crisis represents the deepest and broadest financial upheaval since that era, and in many ways, we, too, are grappling with a changed world.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Today's conference has looked at this post-crisis environment and the issues we now face from many angles.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: I am grateful to the Banque de France for organizing this important event and to the outstanding speakers for their deep insights.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Tonight I will offer some thoughts on this new environment.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: I will begin with a discussion of current economic conditions in the United States, and then highlight some significant structural changes in the environment facing monetary policymakers in the post-crisis era.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Finally, I will consider how these structural changes are affecting the framework in which we conduct monetary policy, highlighting the Federal Reserve System's ongoing review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: The U.S. economy is now in its 11th consecutive year of growth.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Unemployment has steadily declined from its 10 percent post-crisis peak and has now remained at or below 4 percent for more than a year, the longest stretch in a half century.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: A strong labor market with plentiful job openings has supported labor force participation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: After rising only grudgingly early in the recovery, wages have moved up the past few years.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Some groups, such as African Americans, Hispanics, and rural Americans, continue to face long-standing challenges, but the benefits of this strong job market are increasingly widely shared.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: At outreach events we are holding across the United States, we are hearing loud and clear that this long recovery is now benefiting low- and moderate-income communities to a greater extent than has been felt for decades.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Many people who have struggled to stay in the workforce are now getting an opportunity to add new and better chapters to their life stories.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Solid growth has sustained this strong labor market.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Most recently, U.S. gross domestic product (GDP) increased at an annual rate of just over 3 percent in the first quarter, similar to last year's strong pace.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: But first-quarter growth was driven largely by net exports and inventories—two volatile spending categories that are typically not dependable indicators of ongoing momentum.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Indeed, overall growth in the second quarter appears to have moderated.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Growth in consumer spending, which was soft in the first quarter, looks to have bounced back, but business fixed investment growth seems to have slowed notably.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Moreover, the manufacturing sector has been weak since the beginning of the year, in part weighed down by the softer business spending, weaker growth in the global economy, and, as our business contacts tell us, concerns about trade tensions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Despite low unemployment and solid overall growth, inflation pressures remain muted.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: After running close to the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) symmetric 2 percent objective over much of last year, both overall consumer price inflation and core inflation moved down earlier this year.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: We currently estimate that the change in the core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index was 1.7 percent over the 12 months ending in June.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: In our baseline outlook, we expect growth in the United States to remain solid, labor markets to stay strong, and inflation to move back up and run near 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Uncertainties about this outlook have increased, however, particularly regarding trade developments and global growth.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: In addition, issues such as the U.S. federal debt ceiling and Brexit remain unresolved.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: FOMC participants have also raised concerns about a more prolonged shortfall in inflation below our 2 percent target.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Market-based measures of inflation compensation have shifted down, and some survey-based expectations measures are near the bottom of their historical ranges.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Many FOMC participants judged at the time of our most recent meeting in June that the combination of these factors strengthens the case for a somewhat more accommodative stance of policy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: We are carefully monitoring these developments and assessing their implications for the U.S economic outlook and inflation, and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near its symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: We will also assess these developments in the context of the broader structural changes monetary policymakers have been facing since the Great Recession.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: I will focus on three tonight: the changed macroeconomic backdrop, the expanded toolkit, and the heightened focus on communication and transparency.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: In the United States, from the mid-1980s to right before the Great Recession, PCE inflation averaged 2.6 percent a year, GDP growth 3.4 percent, and the interest rate on a 10-year Treasury note 6.5 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Since the trough of the Great Recession, average inflation and output growth are around 1 percentage point lower, and the 10-year Treasury rate has averaged 2.4 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: These declines are not unique to the United States.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Average inflation rates for the other major advanced economies have declined by almost half, while the inflation rates of major emerging market economies are less than one-fifth of what they were.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Indeed, with few exceptions, we are all facing lower rates of interest, growth, and inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: In a number of countries, including the United States, these declines have been accompanied by strong labor markets and a much lower unemployment rate.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Such changes in the macroeconomic environment are significant because the long-run normal levels of inflation, output, interest rates, and the unemployment rate are important structural features by which we guide policy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Standard estimates of the natural rate of unemployment—u*—and the neutral rate of interest—r*—have been declining for 2 decades, and particularly since the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Many factors are contributing to these changes—well-anchored inflation expectations in the context of improved monetary policy, demographics, globalization, slower productivity growth, greater demand for safe assets, and weaker links between unemployment and inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: And these factors seem likely to persist.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: If that happens, the neutral rate of interest will remain low, and policymakers will continue to operate in an environment in which the risk of hitting the effective lower bound is much higher than before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: This proximity to the lower bound poses new complications for central banks and calls for new ideas.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: It is true that many of these features have been with us for some time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Trend inflation, productivity, and interest rates were declining well before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: But, for monetary policymakers in that era, the threat of high inflation felt proximate, the hard-fought battle to control high inflation having been just recently won.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Technological progress seemed likely to continue to sustain rapid increases in productivity—an outcome we continue to await.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: And the effective lower bound for interest rates was mainly a theoretical concern, except of course in Japan.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: The changes to the macroeconomic environment may have been in train earlier, but the crisis seems to have accelerated the process.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: The world in which policymakers are now operating is discretely different in important ways from the one before the Great Recession.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: I should also note, as is fitting given this event and this audience, that since the crisis policymakers are even more keenly aware of the relevance of global factors to our policies.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: The global nature of the financial crisis and the channels through which it spread sharply highlight the interconnectedness of our economic, financial, and policy environments.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: U.S. economic developments affect the rest of the world, and the reverse is also true.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: For example, the stresses surrounding the euro crisis and, later, the China-related volatility events in 2015 and 2016 led to a general pullback in demand for risky assets that put downward pressure on U.S. interest rates and weighed on U.S. confidence and growth.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: In addition, we have seen how monetary policy in one country can influence economic and financial conditions in others through financial markets, trade, and confidence channels.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Pursuing our domestic mandates in this new world requires that we understand the anticipated effects of these interconnections and incorporate them into our policy decisionmaking.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: A second important feature of this new world is the tools central bankers now have to fight recessions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: In the face of the dramatic economic and financial collapse during the crisis, policymakers quickly exhausted conventional monetary policy tools and employed a range of unconventional measures to support their economies.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: In the United States, these measures included new forms of forward guidance and a range of balance sheet policies.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Broadly across different economies, so-called unconventional monetary policies have generally been successful at lowering interest rates and supporting economic recovery, though cyclical and structural headwinds have made achieving our inflation targets a challenge.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: A legacy of the crisis is that policymakers now have a broader range of tested tools to turn to the next time the effective lower bound is reached.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: We must continue to assess additional strategies and tools to bolster our economies and meet our inflation and employment mandates.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Finally, the crisis and Great Recession brought into stark relief the need for transparency and accountability for central banks.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Central bank communication is increasingly important and increasingly challenging.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: It is important because clear, transparent communication about the economy, the risks, and our policy responses is critical for the effectiveness of our tools and for our accountability to the public in a democratic society.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: It is challenging, because we are operating in a changing macroeconomic environment with tools that, while no longer new, remain less familiar to the public.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Moreover, our audience has become more varied, more attuned to our actions, and less trusting of public institutions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Gone are the days when the Federal Reserve Chair could joke, as my predecessor Alan Greenspan did, "If I turn out to be particularly clear, you've probably misunderstood what I said.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: "1Central banks must speak to Main Street, as well as Wall Street, in ways we have not in the past, and Main Street is listening and engaged.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Where does this leave us, and how should policymakers adapt to this new environment?

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Recognizing challenges posed by the changing structure of the economy, the need for effective policy responses, and the importance of clear communication, central banks are taking a closer look at their strategies and the range of tools currently at their disposal.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: For example, the Bank of Canada examines its framework every five years as part of the renewal of its inflation-control agreement with the federal government.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Canadian officials have announced the bank will "assess a broad range of monetary policy frameworks ahead of the renewal in 2021" of this agreement.2The Bank of England commissioned a review over the past year of the future of the United Kingdom's financial system and what it might mean for the bank's agenda, toolkit, and capabilities.3For our part, the Federal Reserve is conducting, for the first time, a public review of the strategy, tools, and communications that we use to promote our goals of maximum employment and price stability.4The heart of this review has been a series ofFed Listensevents around the country, in every Reserve Bank District, to hear directly from the constituencies we serve.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: These events have been live-streamed on the internet.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Last month, we hosted a research conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago to explore ways to more effectively and sustainably achieve our mandated goals.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Beginning soon, the FOMC will devote time at its regular meetings to assessing the lessons from these events.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: We will publicly report the conclusions of our discussions, likely during the first half of next year.5

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Other central banks, many represented in this room, are also looking deeply at the challenges posed by the current environment and assessing tools and strategies.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: I look forward to learning from your experiences and sharing ours in the coming months and years as we face the trials and opportunities of this new era.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: For all of us, the turmoil that preceded this new world was severe, although not as extreme as that faced by those around the table in Bretton Woods 75 years ago.

title: Monetary Policy in the Post-Crisis Era
sentence_text: Tonight let us celebrate their success and strive so that our vision for the future of the global economic and financial system proves as durable and as effective.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Good morning everyone and thank you to President Rosengren and the Boston Fed for hosting this conference.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve is strongly committed to stress testing as a cornerstone of our bank supervisory and financial stability missions.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Stress testing is perhaps the most successful supervisory innovation of the post-crisis era.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: But if stress tests are to continue to serve their critical function, they will need to evolve in the years ahead to keep pace with the ever-changing financial system, as they have since the first round of tests in 2009.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Before looking to the future, let me recall a bit of history.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: A little more than 10 years ago, the United States and the world teetered on the brink of economic catastrophe.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: What was urgently needed was a way to restore confidence in the financial system—a daunting challenge.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Neither the banks, nor the regulators, nor the public had a reliable sense of the strength and resilience of our major banks.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: The announcement of forward-looking stress-testing results in May 2009 helped restore confidence and stabilize banks by providing a credible and independent picture of their finances.1These original stress tests evolved into the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, or CCAR, program, which has served to institutionalize capital planning by firms, and supervision by the Fed, as a forward-looking endeavor.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Since 2009, large banks have added more than $800 billion in common equity capital, giving them a much thicker cushion to deal with losses.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Banks have gotten much better at assessing and managing their risks, effectively tracking commitments across their organizations, anticipating capital needs, and planning for different scenarios.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: The stress tests of the future—5 and 10 years from now—will need to continue to ensure that banks remain able, even in a severe downturn, to provide the credit that households and businesses depend on.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: As financial institutions and the financial system evolve, stress testing will need to keep up.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: When the next episode of financial instability presents itself, it may do so in a messy and unexpected way.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Banks will need to be ready not just for expected risks, but for unexpected ones.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Thus, the tests will need to vary from year to year, and to explore even quite unlikely scenarios.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: If the stress tests do not evolve, they risk becoming a compliance exercise, breeding complacency from both supervisors and banks.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: We might also, inadvertently, encourage the development of a banking system where, over time, all banks would look much alike rather than the banking system we want and need, one with diverse institutions with different business models.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: We simply can't let these things happen.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: The purpose of today's gathering is to help us think about how to ensure the tests continue to foster a dynamic banking system, financial stability, and a healthy and growing economy.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: We have invited a wide range participants—fellow regulators, bankers, analysts, academics, and community groups—with diverse perspectives.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: Because we do not claim a monopoly on knowledge or wisdom, we have invited many who have disagreed with us in the past.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: I strongly believe that diverse perspectives and healthy debate will sharpen our thinking and lead us to better answers.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: I'm sorry I'm not able to be with you today.

title: Welcoming Remarks (via prerecorded video)
sentence_text: And I want to particularly thank all of the speakers, discussants, and other participants for helping us grapple with the challenges of ensuring that tomorrow's stress tests remain as effective and vigorous as they are today.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: It is a pleasure to speak at the Council on Foreign Relations.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: I will begin with a progress report on the broad public review my Federal Reserve colleagues and I are conducting of the strategy, tools, and communication practices we use to achieve the objectives Congress has assigned to us by law—maximum employment and price stability, or the dual mandate.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Then I will discuss the outlook for the U.S. economy and monetary policy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: I look forward to the discussion that will follow.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: During our public review, we are seeking perspectives from people across the nation, and we are doing so through open public meetings live-streamed on the internet.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Let me share some of the thinking behind this review, which is the first of its nature we have undertaken.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The Fed is insulated from short-term political pressures—what is often referred to as our "independence."

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Congress chose to insulate the Fed this way because it had seen the damage that often arises when policy bends to short-term political interests.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Central banks in major democracies around the world have similar independence.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Along with this independence comes the obligation to explain clearly what we are doing and why we are doing it, so that the public and their elected representatives in Congress can hold us accountable.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: But real accountability demands more of us than clear explanation: We must listen.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We must actively engage those we serve to understand how we can more effectively and faithfully use the powers they have entrusted to us.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: That is why we are formally and publicly opening our decisionmaking to suggestions, scrutiny, and critique.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: With unemployment low, the economy growing, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective, this is a good time to undertake such a review.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Another factor motivating the review is that the challenges of monetary policymaking have changed in a fundamental way in recent years.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Interest rates are lower than in the past, and likely to remain so.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The persistence of lower rates means that, when the economy turns down, interest rates will more likely fall close to zero—their effective lower bound (ELB).

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Proximity to the ELB poses new problems to central banks and calls for new ideas.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We hope to benefit from the best thinking on these issues.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: At the heart of the review are ourFed Listensevents, which include town hall–style meetings in all 12 Federal Reserve Districts.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: These meetings bring together people with wide-ranging perspectives, interests, and expertise.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We also want to benefit from the insights of leading economic researchers.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We recently held a conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago that combined research presentations by top scholars with roundtable discussions among leaders of organizations that serve union workers, low- and moderate-income communities, small businesses, and people struggling to find work.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Scholars at the Chicago event offered a range of views on how well our monetary policy tools have effectively promoted our dual mandate.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We learned more about cutting-edge ways to measure job market conditions.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We heard the latest perspectives on what financial and trade links with the rest of the world mean for the conduct of monetary policy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We heard scholarly views on the interplay between monetary policy and financial stability.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: And we heard a review of the clarity and the efficacy of our communications.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Like many others at the conference, I was particularly struck by two panels that included people who work every day in low- and middle-income communities.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: What we heard, loud and clear, was that today's tight labor markets mean that the benefits of this long recovery are now reaching these communities to a degree that has not been felt for many years.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We heard of companies, communities, and schools working together to bring employers the productive workers they need—and of employers working creatively to structure jobs so that employees can do their jobs while coping with the demands of family and life beyond the workplace.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We heard that many people who, in the past, struggled to stay in the workforce are now getting an opportunity to add new and better chapters to their life stories.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: All of this underscores how important it is to sustain this expansion.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The conference generated vibrant discussions.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We heard that we are doing many things well, that we have much we can improve, and that there are different views about which is which.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: That disagreement is neither surprising nor unwelcome.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The questions we are confronting about monetary policymaking and communication, particularly those relating to the ELB, are difficult ones that have grown in urgency over the past two decades.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: That is why it is so important that we actively seek opinions, ideas, and critiques from people throughout the economy to refine our understanding of how best to use the monetary policy powers Congress has granted us.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Beginning soon, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) will devote time at its regular meetings to assess the lessons from these events, supported by analysis by staff from around the Federal Reserve System.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We will publicly report the conclusions of our discussions, likely during the first half of next year.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: In the meantime, anyone who is interested in learning more can find information on the Federal Reserve Board's website.1

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Let me turn now from the longer-term issues that are the focus of the review to the nearer-term outlook for the economy and for monetary policy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: So far this year, the economy has performed reasonably well.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Solid fundamentals are supporting continued growth and strong job creation, keeping the unemployment rate near historic lows.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Although inflation has been running somewhat below our symmetric 2 percent objective, we have expected it to pick up, supported by solid growth and a strong job market.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Along with this favorable picture, we have been mindful of some ongoing crosscurrents, including trade developments and concerns about global growth.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: When the FOMC met at the start of May, tentative evidence suggested these crosscurrents were moderating, and we saw no strong case for adjusting our policy rate.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Since then, the picture has changed.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The crosscurrents have reemerged, with apparent progress on trade turning to greater uncertainty and with incoming data raising renewed concerns about the strength of the global economy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Our contacts in business and agriculture report heightened concerns over trade developments.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: These concerns may have contributed to the drop in business confidence in some recent surveys and may be starting to show through to incoming data.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: For example, the limited available evidence we have suggests that investment by businesses has slowed from the pace earlier in the year.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Against the backdrop of heightened uncertainties, the baseline outlook of my FOMC colleagues, like that of many other forecasters, remains favorable, with unemployment remaining near historic lows.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Inflation is expected to return to 2 percent over time, but at a somewhat slower pace than we foresaw earlier in the year.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: However, the risks to this favorable baseline outlook appear to have grown.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Last week, my FOMC colleagues and I held our regular meeting to assess the stance of monetary policy.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We did not change the setting for our main policy tool, the target range for the federal funds rate, but we did make significant changes in our policy statement.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Since the beginning of the year, we had been taking a patient stance toward assessing the need for any policy change.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We now state that the Committee will closely monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near its symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The question my colleagues and I are grappling with is whether these uncertainties will continue to weigh on the outlook and thus call for additional policy accommodation.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Many FOMC participants judge that the case for somewhat more accommodative policy has strengthened.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: But we are also mindful that monetary policy should not overreact to any individual data point or short-term swing in sentiment.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Doing so would risk adding even more uncertainty to the outlook.

title: Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We will closely monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I am very pleased to welcome you here today.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: This conference is part of a first-ever public review by the Federal Open Market Committee of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We have a distinguished group of experts from academics and other walks of life here to share perspectives on how monetary policy can best serve the public.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I’d like first to say a word about recent developments involving trade negotiations and other matters.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We do not know how or when these issues will be resolved.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are closely monitoring the implications of these developments for the U.S. economic outlook and, as always, we will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion, with a strong labor market and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: My comments today, like this conference, will focus on longer-run issues that will remain even as the issues of the moment evolve.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While central banks face a challenging environment today, those challenges are not entirely new.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In fact, in 1999 the Federal Reserve System hosted a conference titled "Monetary Policy in a Low Inflation Environment."

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Conference participants discussed new challenges that were emerging after the then-recent victory over the Great Inflation.1They focused on many questions posed by low inflation and, in particular, on what unconventional tools a central bank might use to support the economy if interest rates fell to what we now call the effective lower bound (ELB).

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Even though the Bank of Japan was grappling with the ELB as the conference met, the issue seemed remote for the United States.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The conference received little coverage in the financial press, but a Reuters wire service story titled "Fed Conference Timing on Inflation Odd, but Useful" emphasized the remoteness of the risk.2Participants at the conference could not have anticipated that only 10 years later, the world would be engulfed in a deep financial crisis, with unemployment soaring and central banks around the world making extensive use of new strategies, tools, and ways to communicate.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The next time policy rates hit the ELB—and there will be a next time—it will not be a surprise.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are now well aware of the challenges the ELB presents, and we have the painful experience of the Global Financial Crisis and its aftermath to guide us.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our obligation to the public we serve is to take those measures now that will put us in the best position deal with our next encounter with the ELB.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And with the economy growing, unemployment low, and inflation low and stable, this is the right time to engage the public broadly on these topics.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The review has several parts, all of which are intended to open our monetary policy to critical examination.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are holding a series ofFed Listensevents around the country to help us understand the perspectives of people from diverse backgrounds and with varied interests.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: This conference and many other engagements will help us bring to bear the best thinking from policymakers and experts.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Beginning later this year, the FOMC will devote time at a series of our regular meetings to assess lessons from these events, supported by staff analysis performed throughout the Federal Reserve System.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We will publicly report the outcome of our discussions.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In the meantime, anyone who is interested in participating or learning more can find information on the Federal Reserve Board's website.3

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Before turning to the specifics of the review, I want to focus a little more closely on the challenges we face today.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: For a reference point, at the time of the 1999 conference, the United States was eight years into an expansion; core inflation was 1.4 percent, and the unemployment rate was 4.1 percent—not so different from today.4Macroeconomists were puzzling over the flatness of the Phillips curve, the level of the natural rate of unemployment, and a possible acceleration in productivity growth—questions that are also with us today.5

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The big difference between then and now is that the federal funds rate was 5.2 percent—which, to underscore the point, put the rate 20 quarter-point rate cuts away from the ELB.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Since then, standard estimates of the longer-run normal or neutral rate of interest have declined between 2 and 3 percentage points, and some argue that the effective decline is even larger.6The combination of lower real interest rates and low inflation translates into lower nominal rates and a much higher likelihood that rates will fall to the ELB in a downturn.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As the experience of the past decade showed, extended ELB episodes can be associated with painfully high unemployment and slow growth or recession.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Economic weakness puts downward pressure on inflation, which can raise real interest rates and reinforce the challenge of supporting needed job growth.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In addition, over time, inflation has become much less sensitive to tightness in resource utilization.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: This insensitivity can be a blessing in avoiding deflation when unemployment is high, but it means that much greater labor market tightness may ultimately be required to bring inflation back to target in a recovery.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Using monetary policy to push sufficiently hard on labor markets to lift inflation could pose risks of destabilizing excesses in financial markets or elsewhere.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In short, the proximity of interest rates to the ELB has become the preeminent monetary policy challenge of our time, tainting all manner of issues with ELB risk and imbuing many old challenges with greater significance.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: For example, the behavior of inflation7now draws much sharper focus.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: When nominal interest rates were around 4 or 5 percent, a low-side surprise of a few tenths on inflation did not raise the specter of the ELB.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But the world has changed.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Core inflation is currently running a bit below 2 percent on a trailing 12-month basis.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In this setting, a similar low-side surprise, if it were to persist, would bring us uncomfortably closer to the ELB.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: My FOMC colleagues and I must—and do—take seriously the risk that inflation shortfalls that persist even in a robust economy could precipitate a difficult-to-arrest downward drift in inflation expectations.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: At the heart of the review is the evaluation of potential changes to our strategy designed to strengthen the credibility of our symmetric 2 percent inflation objective.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The ELB problem also complicates the FOMC's efforts to achieve transparency and accountability.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Fed, like most major central banks, is insulated from short-term political pressures.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In our democracy, that insulation carries with it an obligation for us to be transparent and publicly accountable.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: When policy rates reached the ELB during the crisis, central banks resorted to what were then new, untested tools to pursue their mandated goals.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: These tools are no longer new, but their efficacy, costs, and risks remain less well understood than the traditional approaches to central banking.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: My FOMC colleagues and I are committed to explaining why the use of these tools in the wake of the crisis was a prudent and effective approach to pursuing our congressional mandate and why tools like these are likely to be needed again.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our review is but one part of our efforts to engage with the public on these matters.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Let me turn to the specifics of the review, which is focused on three questions:

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: These questions are quite broad, and my colleagues and I come to them with open minds.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We believe our current policy framework is working well, and we have made no decisions about particular changes.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In fact, the review is still in its early stages.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The first question raises the issue of whether the FOMC should use makeup strategies in response to ELB risks.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: By the time of the 1999 conference, research was beginning to show that—in models, at least—such strategies could substantially reduce the unemployment and other costs of ELB spells.8The simplest version goes like this: Suppose that a spell with interest rates near the ELB leads to a persistent shortfall of inflation relative to the central bank's goal.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But what if the central bank promised credibly that it would deliberately make up for any lost inflation by stimulating the economy and temporarily pushing inflation modestly above the target?

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In the models, the prospect of future stimulus promotes anticipatory consumption and investment that could greatly reduce the pain of being at the ELB.9Policymakers discussed this reasoning in the wake of the crisis, but neither the Fed nor any other major central bank chose to pursue such a policy.10Why?

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: For makeup strategies to work, households and businesses must go out on a limb, so to speak, raising spending in the midst of a downturn.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In theory, they would do this based on their confidence that the central bank will deliver the makeup stimulus at some point—perhaps years in the future.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In models, great confidence in central bankers is achieved by assumption.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Despite the flattering nature of this assumption, crisis-era policymakers had major questions about whether their promise of good times to come would really have moved the hearts, minds, and pocketbooks of the public.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Part of the problem was that the groundwork had not been laid in advance of the downturn—a problem we could hope to fix well before next time.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Policymakers also had deeper concerns about the legitimacy and effectiveness of attempting to bind some future FOMC to take actions that could be objectionable from a short-term perspective when the time came to deliver.11

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Research on makeup strategies has begun to grapple more seriously with the credibility questions.12But important questions remain.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: To achieve buy-in by households and businesses, a comprehensible, credible, and actionable makeup strategy will need to be followed by years of central bank policy consistent with that strategy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The second question asks about the adequacy of the Fed's toolkit for providing stimulus when facing the ELB.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In the United States, we used several different formulations of both forward guidance and large‑scale purchases of longer-term securities.13While views differ on the effectiveness of these policies, with their use, the unemployment rate fell steadily and inflation expectations remained well anchored, outcomes that were favorable overall when viewed against the recoveries of many other advanced economies.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: My own view is that these policies provided meaningful support for demand, but that they should not be thought of as a perfect substitute for our traditional interest rate tool.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In any case, we have a responsibility to thoroughly evaluate what mix of these tools is likely to work best when the next ELB episode arrives.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Perhaps it is time to retire the term "unconventional" when referring to tools that were used in the crisis.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We know that tools like these are likely to be needed in some form in future ELB spells, which we hope will be rare.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We now have a significant body of evidence regarding the effectiveness, costs, and risks of these tools, including those used by the FOMC and others tried elsewhere.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our plans must take advantage of this growing understanding as assessments are refined.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The third question concerns improving communication, which I discussed earlier from the standpoint of governance and accountability.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But transparency also plays a central role in policy effectiveness through its effects on the expectations of households and businesses.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Of course, this was the major insight behind the transparency revolution in central banking over the past few decades.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Today, central banks publicly share a large and ever-increasing amount of information about policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But policymakers and commentators inside and outside central banks sometimes question whether all of the transparency adds up to effective communication.14

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The FOMC's famous dot plot is one example.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: A focus on the median forecast amounts to emphasizing what the typical FOMC participant would do if things go as expected.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But we have been living in times characterized by large, frequent, unexpected changes in the underlying structure of the economy.15In this environment, the most important policy message may be about how the central bank will respond to the unexpected rather than what it will do if there are no surprises.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Unfortunately, at times the dot plot has distracted attention from the more important topic of how the FOMC will react to unexpected economic developments.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In times of high uncertainty, the median dot might best be thought of as theleast unlikelyoutcome.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Let me conclude by saying that I look forward to our discussions here and to the ongoing work of the review that lies ahead.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We need the best tools and strategies possible for dealing with the challenges we now face, and we must communicate them in a clear and credible way.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: My colleagues and I welcome your best thinking on these issues.
