title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: It is a pleasure to be here at this important annual event sponsored and organized by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta's Center for Financial Innovation and Stability.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The risks in our financial system are constantly evolving.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Fifteen years ago, everyone was talking about whether households were borrowing too much.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Today everyone is talking about whether businesses are borrowing too much.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: This evening, I will focus on the implications of the increase in business debt over the past decade and review the steps the Federal Reserve and other agencies are taking to understand and limit the associated risks.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In public discussion of this issue, views seem to range from "This is a rerun of the subprime mortgage crisis" to "Nothing to worry about here."

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: At the moment, the truth is likely somewhere in the middle.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: To preview my conclusions, as of now, business debt does not present the kind of elevated risks to the stability of the financial system that would lead to broad harm to households and businesses should conditions deteriorate.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: At the same time, the level of debt certainly could stress borrowers if the economy weakens.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve continues to assess the potential amplification of such stresses on borrowers to the broader economy through possible vulnerabilities in the financial system, and I currently see such risks as moderate.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: DiscussionMany commentators have observed with a sense of déjà vu the buildup of risky business debt over the past few years.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The acronyms have changed a bit—"CLOs" (collateralized loan obligations) instead of "CDOs" (collateralized debt obligations), for example—but once again, we see a category of debt that is growing faster than the income of the borrowers even as lenders loosen underwriting standards.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Likewise, much of the borrowing is financed opaquely, outside the banking system.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Many are asking whether these developments pose a new threat to financial stability.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: At the Federal Reserve, we take this possibility seriously.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The Fed and other regulators are using our supervisory tools and closely monitoring risks from the buildup of risky business debt.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Business debt has clearly reached a level that should give businesses and investors reason to pause and reflect.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: If financial and economic conditions were to deteriorate, overly indebted firms could well face severe strains.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: However, the parallels to the mortgage boom that led to the Global Financial Crisis are not fully convincing.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Most importantly, the financial system today appears strong enough to handle potential business-sector losses, which was manifestly not the case a decade ago with subprime mortgages.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: And there are other differences: Increases in business borrowing are not outsized for such a long expansion, in contrast to the mortgage boom; business credit is not fueled by a dramatic asset price bubble, as mortgage debt was; and CLO structures are much sounder than the structures that were in use during the mortgage credit bubble.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Could the increase in business debt pose greater risks to the financial system than currently appreciated?

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: My colleagues and I continually ask ourselves that question.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We are also taking multiple steps to better understand and address the potential risks.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In conjunction with other U.S. regulatory agencies, both domestically through the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) and internationally through the Financial Stability Board (FSB), we are monitoring developments, assessing unknowns, and working to develop a clearer picture.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We are also using our supervisory tools to hold the banks we supervise to strong risk-management standards.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: And we are using our stress tests to ensure banks' resilience even in severely adverse business conditions.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The Rise of Business LeverageLet's start with the basic facts.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Many measures confirm that the business sector has significantly increased its borrowing as the economy has expanded over the past decade.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Business debt relative to the size of the economy is at historic highs.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Corporate debt relative to the book value of assets is at the upper end of its range over the past few decades (figure 1).

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: And investment-grade corporate debt has shifted closer to the edge of speculative grade.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: At the moment, the business sector is quite healthy overall.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Business income is strong, reflecting healthy profit margins.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: And because interest rates are quite low by historical standards, the costs of servicing today's higher levels of debt remain low relative to business income (figure 2).

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Despite crosscurrents, the economy is showing continued growth, strong job creation, and rising wages, all in a context of muted inflation pressures.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: But if a downturn were to arrive unexpectedly, some firms would face challenges.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Not only is the volume of debt high, but recent growth has also been concentrated in the riskier forms of debt.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Among investment-grade bonds, a near-record fraction is at the lowest rating—a phenomenon known as the "triple-B cliff."

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In a downturn, some of these borrowers could be downgraded into high-yield territory, which would require some investors to sell their holdings, thereby confronting traditional high-yield investors with a sudden influx of bonds.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: There have also been sizable shifts within the non-investment-grade, or riskier, debt universe.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Higher-risk businesses have traditionally funded themselves with a mix of high-yield bonds and leveraged loans.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Over time, the balance between the two has swung back and forth because of investor demand, the interest rate environment, and other factors.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In the past few years, leveraged loans have grown far more quickly (figure 3).

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In fact, while net new issuance of high-yield bonds in 2018 was close to nil, leveraged loans outstanding rose 20 percent and now stand at more than $1 trillion.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: So far this year, issuance of high-yield bonds and leveraged loans has been more balanced.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In addition, underwriting standards have weakened.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: With leveraged loans, covenants intended to protect lenders may be an endangered species; more loans now feature high debt-to-earnings ratios; and the use of optimistic projections including "earnings add-backs" is becoming more common.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The rise in riskier business borrowing has been funded principally by nonbank lenders.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Collateralized loan obligations are now the largest lenders, with about 62 percent of outstanding leveraged loans (figure 4).

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: These lenders are actively managed securitization vehicles that mostly buy higher-risk assets like leveraged loans.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: CLOs, in turn, are funded by a slice of equity and layers of debt of varying seniority.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: After CLOs, mutual funds are the next-largest vehicle for holding leveraged loans, with about 20 percent of the market.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: These funds allow investors to redeem their shares daily, although the underlying loans take longer to sell.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: As a result, investors may react to financial stress by trying to redeem their shares before the funds have sold their most liquid assets.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Widespread redemptions by investors, in turn, could lead to widespread price pressures, which could affect all holders of loans, including CLOs and those that hold CLOs.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Risks to Financial Stability: Using the Framework Deployed since the CrisisAs you can see, there are similarities to the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: As with the mortgage boom, the business debt story begins with rapid growth of debt to new highs and a surge in lending to risky borrowers made possible by aggressive underwriting using securitization vehicles.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: But there are also important differences.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: One difference is that financial authorities now closely monitor financial stability vulnerabilities on an ongoing basis, armed with lessons learned from the crisis.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The Board of Governors meets at least four times a year to assess threats to the financial system and is constantly monitoring developments.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We use a checklist of potential financial vulnerabilities that we have described elsewhere, most recently in theFinancial Stability Reportwe published earlier this month.1This approach gives us a way to organize and weigh the mass of facts, anecdotes, and speculation we confront as we monitor financial stability.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In assessing financial stability risks, we constantly consult our four-point checklist: borrowing by businesses and households, valuation pressures, leverage in the financial system, and funding risk.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: If households or businesses have borrowed too much, they will be forced to cut back spending and investing or even default if their incomes fall or the value of the collateral backing their loans declines.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Valuation pressures give us a sense of overall risk appetite and, should investors lose that appetite, how far prices could fall.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: If lenders face defaulting borrowers and have too little loss-absorbing capacity, they risk insolvency.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: At best, they will cut back on lending to other borrowers, dragging the economy down.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: At worst, they will fail, which can lead to severe economic damage to households and businesses.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Finally, when the financial system funds long-maturity assets with short-maturity liabilities, we risk a classic "fast burn" crisis—a bank run, or its equivalent involving investors and institutions outside traditional banking.2

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In our framework, the story of the mid-2000s goes something like this: Amid a self-reinforcing cycle of house price gains and mortgage credit expansion, households borrowed (and lenders lent) far too much, and property prices rose far too high.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Financial institutions of all shapes and sizes also borrowed too much.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: And the financial sector was highly susceptible to a run because it funded risky, long-maturity mortgages with extended chains of fragile and opaque financing structures that ultimately rested on short-maturity liabilities.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Let's compare this story with the current situation using our four-point checklist, beginning with borrowing by businesses and households.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Business debt has grown faster than gross domestic product (GDP) for several years and today is high.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: But the growth in the ratio of business debt to GDP in the past decade is much less than the growth in household debt to GDP that we saw in the run-up to the Global Financial Crisis.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Back then, household debt grew from 60 percent of GDP to 90 percent, or by half (figure 5).

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: At its recent low, business debt was 65 percent of GDP.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Now, even after rapid growth, it is still below 75 percent of GDP.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Overall, the increase in business debt relative to the size of the economy is one-third the increase in household debt seen in the previous decade.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Business debt rises in expansions.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: It is a steady upward plod in borrowing over the long expansion—not a rapid expansion—that has now brought business debt to GDP back to historic highs.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Seen this way, the current situation looks typical of business cycles.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The mortgage credit boom was, because of its magnitude and speed, far outside historical norms.3

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: As for household debt, we see that household debt-to-income ratios have steadily declined post-crisis.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Moreover, a high and rising fraction of this debt is rated prime.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: All told, household debt burdens appear much more manageable.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Our second factor—valuation pressures—also points to moderate risks to financial stability.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Valuations are high across several financial markets.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Equity prices have recently reached new highs, and corporate bond and loan spreads are narrow.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Both commercial and residential property prices have moved above their long-run relationship with rents, although price gains slowed substantially last year.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: All of these developments point to strong risk appetite—as might be expected given the strong economy.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: But there does not appear to be a feedback loop between borrowing and asset prices, as was the case in the run-up to the financial crisis.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: While borrowing by businesses has been strong, it is not fueling excessive prices or investment in a critical sector such as housing, whose collapse would undermine collateral values and lead to outsized losses.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Instead, the increase in business borrowing has been broad based across sectors, including technology, oil and gas production, and manufacturing.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Regarding the third factor—leverage in the financial system—today banks at the core of the financial system are fundamentally stronger and more resilient.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Our post-crisis regulatory framework is based on robust capital requirements backed by strong stress tests, resulting in much higher levels of capital in the banking system (figure 6).

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: These stress tests are a way to estimate the direct and indirect effects of extremely bad macroeconomic and financial developments on our banking system.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We publish the scenarios that describe the macro and financial developments every year by mid-February and release the test results in June.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In the pre-crisis environment, supervisors focused more on the most likely outcomes, not on these tail risks.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Since we began routine stress-testing in 2011, the scenarios we use have featured severe global recessions characterized by major stress in the corporate sector, where large numbers of firms default on their loans and bonds.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: As actual economic conditions have improved, the scenarios have gotten tougher.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The most recent stress tests indicate that, even after the losses from the scenario, capital levels at the largest banks would remain above the levels those banks had before the crisis.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Loss-absorbing capacity elsewhere in the financial system is also much improved.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Leverage at broker-dealers is far below levels before the crisis and remains low relative to the norms of the past several decades.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Insurers also appear well capitalized.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: As for our fourth factor—funding risk—the susceptibility of the financial system to runs also appears low.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In part because of the post-crisis regulatory regime, large banks hold substantial amounts of highly liquid assets and rely relatively little on short-term wholesale funding (figure 7).

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Money market funds hold much safer assets.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: And CLOs, which have facilitated the growth of leveraged loans, have stable funding: Investors commit funds for lengthy periods, so they cannot, through withdrawals, force CLOs to sell assets at distressed prices.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Addressing the Risks: Monitoring and ActingOverall, vulnerabilities to financial stability from business debt and other factors do not appear elevated.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We take the risks from business debt seriously but think that the financial system appears strong enough to handle potential losses.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We also know that our dynamic financial system does not stand still.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We can always learn more about financial markets, and we will always act to address emerging risks.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Together with our domestic and international counterparts, we are monitoring developments in business debt markets, working to develop and share data on how these markets operate, studying ways to further strengthen the system, and working to ensure that banks are properly managing the business debt risks they have taken on.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Through the FSOC, the banking and market regulators coordinate our monitoring of financial conditions.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In recent meetings, the FSOC has discussed leveraged lending in depth.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We recognize that each regulator directly sees only a part of the larger picture, and we are working to stitch these parts together so we can collectively see that larger picture and the risks it holds.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: For example, the Securities and Exchange Commission is examining the potential for liquidity strains at mutual funds, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is working to understand the use of derivatives to hedge risks associated with leveraged loans.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: What else are we watching for?

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Business debt growth has moderated somewhat since early 2018, but this might be just a pause.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Another sharp increase in debt, unless supported by strong fundamentals, could increase vulnerabilities appreciably.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Businesses, investors, and lenders need to focus on these vulnerabilities—as will the Federal Reserve.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: In addition, regulators, investors, and market participants around the world would benefit greatly from more information on who is bearing the ultimate risk associated with CLOs.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We know that the U.S. CLO market spans the globe, involving foreign banks and asset managers.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: But right now, we mainly know where the CLOs are not—only $90 billion of the roughly $700 billion in total CLOs are held by the largest U.S. banks.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: That is certainly good news for domestic banks, but in a downturn institutions anywhere could find themselves under pressure, especially those with inadequate loss-absorbing capacity or runnable short-term financing.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve is participating in international efforts, under the auspices of the FSB, to improve our knowledge of these key issues.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Through the FSB, we are focused on determining the size of the global leveraged loan market and the holders of the loans as an important step toward a better understanding of the underlying risks.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Beyond monitoring markets and collecting new data, several supervisory efforts are also under way.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: To complement the quantitative analysis in our stress tests, our supervisors have been qualitatively assessing how well banks are managing the risks associated with leveraged lending.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Through the Shared National Credit Program, which evaluates large syndicated loans, our supervisors are continuing to work with their counterparts at the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to ensure that banks are properly managing the risks of losses they face from participating in the leveraged lending market.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: ConclusionLet me wrap up with three thoughts.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: First, business debt is near record levels, and recent issuance has been concentrated in the riskiest segments.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: As a result, some businesses may come under severe financial strain if the economy deteriorates.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: A highly leveraged business sector could amplify any economic downturn as companies are forced to lay off workers and cut back on investments.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Investors, financial institutions, and regulators need to focus on this risk today, while times are good.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Second, today business debt does not appear to present notable risks to financial stability.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The debt-to-GDP ratio has moved up at a steady pace, in line with previous expansions and neither fueled by nor fueling an asset bubble.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Moreover, banks and other financial institutions have sizable loss-absorbing buffers.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: The growth in business debt does not rely on short-term funding, and overall funding risk in the financial system is moderate.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: Third, we cannot be satisfied with our current level of knowledge about these markets, particularly the vulnerability of financial institutions to potential losses and the possible strains on market liquidity and prices should investors exit investment vehicles holding leveraged loans.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: We are committed to better understanding the areas where our information is incomplete.

title: Business Debt and Our Dynamic Financial System
sentence_text: This commitment includes coordination with other domestic and international agencies to understand who is participating in business lending and how their behavior could potentially amplify stress events.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: It is my pleasure to welcome all of you to the Federal Reserve System's 11th Community Development Research Conference, cosponsored by the community development offices of all 12 Federal Reserve Banks and the Board of Governors.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: These biennial conferences are one manifestation of the Federal Reserve's deep commitment to supporting research that helps policymakers, community development practitioners, and researchers improve the economic well-being of families and communities.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: These gatherings also inform the Federal Reserve System's work in promoting consumer protection and community development, and I would like to thank all of you for your contributions to this conference.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: This year our conference focuses on pathways to the middle class.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: While there are many definitions of "middle class," I think we can agree that achieving a basic level of economic security is fundamental.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Surveys suggest that many Americans believe being middle class means having a secure job and the ability to save.1In recent decades, income growth for middle-income households has lagged behind that for high‑income households.2In addition, economic resources differ markedly by race, education, occupation, geography, and other factors.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Those circumstances underscore a two-fold challenge for our country: fostering the conditions that will help lower-income families reach the middle class, while ensuring that middle-class status still provides the basic economic security that it has traditionally offered.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The conference organizers have sorted through the many research questions that will be addressed today and tomorrow and have taken away three key observations that are fundamental to addressing the challenges related to the middle class.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The first observation is to note the long-term decline in relative income growth and upward economic mobility for those in the middle.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: According to a number of measures, income has grown more slowly for middle-class households since the 1970s than for those with higher incomes, resulting in wider income inequality.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The kind of generational improvements in living standards that were long the hallmark of the American middle class have steadily diminished.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: In the 1950s, better than 80 percent of children born in middle-class households grew up to out-earn their parents, but more recently only around half do.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: One factor in this decline is the increase in income inequality I just noted, and another is slower productivity growth.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: This conference will touch on other possible reasons for this decline in upward mobility and relative income, such as changes in the prospects for career advancement that vary by occupation and location.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The second observation is the widening gap in economic status and prospects between those with a college degree and those without one.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: In the 1960s, well over 90 percent of working-age men held a job, and there was very little difference in employment between those with or without a college degree.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: While the share of college-educated working-age men with a job has fallen from more than 95 percent in 1967 to around 90 percent in 2017, it has plunged for others.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Ninety-five percent of male high school graduates were working in 1967, but only about 80 percent of them were working as of 2017.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Among working-age men without a high school diploma, about 90 percent had a job in 1967 versus a bit more than 70 percent in 2017.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: For women of working age, the trends are less clear, but those without a college degree are also less likely to work today.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Research presented this morning will discuss some possible explanations for the divergence in employment, income, and other economic prospects between college grads and others.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The third observation is that the prospect of moving up the economic ladder depends on factors beyond effort and talent, including your family, the neighborhood you grow up in, and the quality of the primary and secondary schools you attend.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Your chances for attending college are much better if you are raised in a higher-income household, and that advantage has increased substantially since the 1980s.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Some research indicates that economic prospects are better for those who grow up in neighborhoods with less income inequality, less concentrated poverty, and better performing schools.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Finally, across so many dimensions, we continue to see disparities in economic outcomes by race and ethnicity.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Sound public policies can support families and businesses and help more Americans reach and remain in the middle class.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: I look forward to hearing about your discussions over the next two days, and thank you, again, for your contributions.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Good evening, and thank you for inviting me to speak to you today.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: The National Community Reinvestment Coalition (NCRC) and its member organizations are at the forefront of an important conversation about how to ensure that low- and moderate-income communities are fairly served by the banking industry.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: The work that you do to promote access to basic banking services, affordable housing, and entrepreneurship opportunities supports the Federal Reserve and other agencies that enforce fair lending laws.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: The large number and variety of NCRC's local member organizations allow the NCRC to draw a detailed picture of how the Federal Reserve's policies affect lower-income communities, and we deeply appreciate the information that you share with us and the work that it represents.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: As you know all too well, the current strength of the overall economy masks the struggles many individuals and families face in lower-income urban and rural communities.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Low- and moderate-income homeowners saw their wealth stripped away as home values dropped during the financial crisis and have not recovered as quickly or completely as others.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Because home equity has been the main source of wealth among low- and moderate-income people, the crisis dealt a particularly severe blow to these households.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Most Americans rely on home equity to send their children to college, invest in their own education and training, or start or grow a business.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: These aspirations are the basis upon which a strong economy is built.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: That is why your work as NCRC member organizations offering financial counseling, homeownership education, and technical assistance for small businesses is as important as ever.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: When lower-income individuals and families struggle, it harms their health and well-being and also weakens our economy.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: When people are connected to education, training, and other resources that help them secure good jobs and other opportunities, they are better prepared to care for themselves and their families and contribute to a strong economy.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve has an extensive community development function, related to our responsibilities under the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA), that promotes partnerships between banks and community organizations to address local community and economic development needs.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: As you know, the CRA requires federal banking regulators--the Federal Reserve, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation--to encourage banks to help meet the credit needs of the communities they are chartered to serve, including low- and moderate-income neighborhoods.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: To complement the work we do with the other regulators to write regulations and guidance implementing CRA, the Federal Reserve System's community development staff help banks understand and meet their responsibilities under the law.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: Fed staff members also act as liaisons between banks and community organizations to identify local community development needs and solutions.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: I know that you all are very interested in the agencies' activities related to possible revisions to the current CRA regulations.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: My colleague, Governor Brainard, who represents the Board in our interagency CRA discussions, will be speaking to you tomorrow, so I will leave it to her to discuss our efforts in detail.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: But I do want to express my support for an interagency effort to revise the regulations to promote clarity and consistency in our evaluations of banks, particularly in light of the changes in the way bank products and services are delivered.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: We value the CRA's role in meeting the credit needs of low- and moderate-income neighborhoods and want to be very careful that any revisions serve to strengthen the CRA's purpose.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: I commend your dedication to ensuring that all Americans have fair access to the economic opportunities that our nation offers.

title: Brief Remarks
sentence_text: I hope you have a productive conference, and I look forward to our ongoing conversation about how the Federal Reserve can help.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Thank you for the opportunity to speak here today at the Stanford Institute for Economic Policy Research, a place dedicated to scholarship supporting policies to better peoples' lives.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: As today is International Women's Day, I would like to preface my remarks by commending the American Economic Association for highlighting the diversity challenges of the economics profession and charting a way forward.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Diversity is also a priority at the Fed: I want the Fed to be known within the economics profession as a great place for women, minorities, and others of diverse backgrounds to be respected, listened to, and happy.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Just over 10 years ago, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC, or the Committee) lowered the federal funds rate close to zero, which we refer to as the effective lower bound, or ELB.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Unable to lower rates further, the Committee turned to two novel tools to promote the recovery.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The first was forward guidance, which is communication about the future path of interest rates.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The second was large-scale purchases of longer-term securities, which became known as quantitative easing, or QE.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: There is a range of views, but most studies have found that these tools provided significant support for the recovery.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: From the outset, the Committee viewed them as extraordinary measures to be unwound, or "normalized," when conditions ultimately warranted.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Today I will explore some important features of normalization and then turn to what comes after.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In some ways, we are returning to the pre-crisis normal.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In other ways, things will be different.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The world has moved on in the last decade, and attempting to re-create the past would be neither practical nor wise.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: As normalization moves into its later stages, my colleagues and I also believe that this is an important moment to take stock of issues raised by the remarkable experiences of the past decade.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: We are therefore conducting a review of the Fed's monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications practices.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: I will conclude with some thoughts on the review.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Balance Sheet NormalizationBetween December 2008 and October 2014, the Federal Reserve purchased $3.7 trillion in longer-term Treasury and agency securities in order to support the economy both by easing dislocations in market functioning and by driving down longer-term interest rates.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Consistent with the Committee's long-stated intention, in October 2017 we started the process of balance sheet normalization.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: We began gradually reducing the reinvestment of payments received as assets matured or were prepaid, allowing our holdings to shrink.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The process of reducing the size of the portfolio is now well along.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: To frame the discussion of the final stages of normalization of the size of the balance sheet, it is useful to consider what the phrase "normal balance sheet" meant in the decades before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: During that period, the main monetary policy decision for the FOMC was choosing a target value for the federal funds rate.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Subject to that choice, the Fed allowed the demand for its liabilities to determine the size of the balance sheet.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: This is a feature of "normal" that we are returning to: After normalization, the size of the Fed's balance sheet will once again be driven by the demand for our liabilities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: To see what this means, considerfigure 1, which shows the size of the Fed's balance sheet through time, as measured by total liabilities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The values are stated as a percentage of the dollar value of GDP, or gross domestic product.1Liabilities began to grow sharply at the end of 2008 and continued to increase until the end of 2014.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Since that time, liabilities relative to GDP have fallen appreciably.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: To understand these changes, it is useful to focus on a snapshot of the balance sheet at three points in time: before the crisis, when the balance sheet was at its largest, and a rough projection for the end of this year (table 1).

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In 2006, the dominant liability was currency held by the public, and the dominant asset was Treasury securities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The Fed's asset purchase programs increased the balance sheet from just below 6 percent to nearly 25 percent of GDP by the end of 2014.2Balance sheets must balance, of course, and the Fed issued reserves as payment for the assets purchased.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: This action pushed reserves to nearly 15 percent of GDP.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The Committee has long said that the size of the balance sheet will be considered normalized when the balance sheet is once again at the smallest level consistent with conducting monetary policy efficiently and effectively.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Just how large that will be is uncertain, because we do not yet have a clear sense of the normal level of demand for our liabilities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Current estimates suggest, however, that something in the ballpark of the 2019:Q4 projected values may be the new normal.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The normalized balance sheet may be smaller or larger than that estimate and will grow gradually over time as demand for currency rises with the economy.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In all plausible cases, the balance sheet will be considerably larger than before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: To understand the differences between the new and old normal, consider the final column in the table, which shows the change, measured in percentage points of GDP, between 2006:Q4 and the 2019:Q4 projection in the table.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In this estimate, relative to before the crisis, the balance sheet will have grown as a share of GDP by about 10.6 percentage points.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Bank reserves account for the biggest part of the growth, or about 5.6 percent of GDP.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The crisis revealed that banks, especially the largest and most complex, faced much more liquidity risk than had previously been thought.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Because of both new liquidity regulations and improved management, banks now hold much higher levels of high-quality liquid assets than before the crisis.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Many banks choose to hold reserves as an important part of their strong liquidity positions.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The rest of the increase in liabilities is accounted for by three other categories.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: First, public currency holdings will have grown by 2.4 percentage points as a share of GDP.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Second, the U.S. Treasury maintains an account at the Fed, which has been running 1.4 percentage points higher as a share of GDP.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: And, third, other liabilities, which are mainly associated with the mechanics of the national and international financial system, will have grown by 1.1 percentage points.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: As was the case before the crisis, the FOMC's chosen operating regime for controlling short-term interest rates also plays a role in determining the appropriate quantity of reserves.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In January, the Committee stated its intention to continue in our current regime in which our main policy rate, the federal funds rate or possibly some successor, is held within its target range by the interest rates we set on reserves and on the overnight reverse repo facility.3In this system, active management of the supply of reserves is not required.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Thus, the supply of reserves must be "ample," in the sense of being sufficient to satisfy reserve demands even in the face of volatility in factors affecting the reserve market.4Put another way, the quantity of reserves will equal the typical reserve demands of depositories plus a buffer to allow for reserve market fluctuations.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: While the precise level of reserves that will prove ample is uncertain, standard projections, such as those in the table, suggest we could be near that level later this year.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: As we feel our way cautiously to this goal, we will move transparently and predictably in order to minimize needless market disruption and risks to our dual-mandate objectives.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The Committee is now well along in our discussions of a plan to conclude balance sheet runoff later this year.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Once balance sheet runoff ends, we may, if appropriate, hold the size of the balance sheet constant for a time to allow reserves to very gradually decline to the desired level as other liabilities, such as currency, increase.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: We expect to announce further details of this plan reasonably soon.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: There is no real precedent for the balance sheet normalization process, and we have adapted our approach along the way.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In these final phases, we will adjust the details of our normalization plans if economic and financial conditions warrant.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: After decisions regarding the size of the balance sheet have been made, we will turn to remaining issues, such as the ultimate maturity composition of the portfolio.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The Committee has long stated that it intends to return to a portfolio consisting primarily of Treasury securities.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Forward Guidance and the Normalization of Policy CommunicationThe Committee has also been normalizing communication about our policy after a decade of forward guidance.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Since December 2008, the FOMC's postmeeting statement had contained ever-evolving forms of guidance about keeping the federal funds rate at the ELB or about the gradual pace at which that rate would return to more normal levels.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: We removed the last elements of this crisis-era guidance in January.5The federal funds rate is now within the broad range of estimates of the neutral rate--the interest rate that tends neither to stimulate nor to restrain the economy.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Committee participants generally agree that this policy stance is appropriate to promote our dual mandate of maximum employment and price stability.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Future adjustments will depend on what incoming data tell us about the baseline outlook and risks to that outlook.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Policy communication will not simply revert to the ways of the early 2000s, however, for transparency advances have continued apace since then.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The most significant change from the standpoint of forward guidance is that, since January 2012, the FOMC's quarterly Summary of Economic Projections (SEP) has included federal funds rate projections reaching up to three years into the future--often referred to as the "dot plot."

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Returning to a world of little or no explicit forward guidance in the FOMC's postmeeting statement presents a challenge, for the dot plot has, on occasion, been a source of confusion.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Until now, forward guidance in the statement has been a main tool for communicating committee intentions and minimizing that confusion.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: For example, in early 2014, the Committee's intentions were at odds with a common misreading of the dots, and Chair Yellen explained, "[O]ne should not look to the dot plot, so to speak, as the primary way in which the Committee wants to or is speaking about policy to the public at large.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The FOMC statement is the device that the Committee as a policymaking group uses to express its opinions .

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: about the likely path of rates.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: "6If the Committee remains largely out of the business of explicit forward guidance, we will need to find other ways to address the collateral confusion that sometimes surrounds the dots.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: As readers of the FOMC minutes will know, at our last meeting in January there was an impromptu discussion among some participants of general concerns about the dots.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: My own view is that, if properly understood, the dot plot can be a constructive element of comprehensive policy communication.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Let me follow my two predecessors as Chair in attempting to advance that proper understanding.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Each participant's dots reflect that participant's view of the policy that would be appropriate in the scenario that he or she sees as most likely.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: As someone who has filled out an SEP projection 27 times over the last seven years, I can say that there are times when I feel that something like the "most likely" scenario I write down is, indeed, reasonably likely to happen.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: At other times, when uncertainty around the outlook is unusually high, I dutifully write down what I see as the appropriate funds rate path in the most likely scenario, but I do so aware that this projection may be easily misinterpreted, for what is "most likely" may not be particularly likely.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Very different scenarios may be similarly likely.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Further, at times downside risks may deserve significant weight in policy deliberations.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In short, as Chairman Bernanke explained, the SEP projections are merely "inputs" to policy that do not convey "the risks, the uncertainties, all the things that inform our collective judgment.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Effectively conveying our views about risks and their role in policy projections can be challenging at times, and we are always looking for ways to improve our communications.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: I have asked the communications subcommittee of the FOMC to explore ways in which we can more effectively communicate about the role of the rate projections.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: For now, let me leave you with a cautionary tale about focusing too much on dots.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Here is a picture composed of different colored dots (figure 2).

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The meaning of it is not clear, although if you stare at it long enough you might see a pattern.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: But let's take a step back (figure 3).

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: As you can see, if you are too focused on a few dots, you may miss the larger picture.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Delivering on the FOMC's intention to ultimately normalize policy continues to be a major priority at the Fed.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Normalization is far along, and, considering the unprecedented nature of the exercise, it is proceeding smoothly.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: I am confident that we can effectively manage the remaining stages.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Beyond NormalizationWe live in a time of intense scrutiny and declining trust in public institutions around the world.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: At the Fed, we are committed to working hard to build and sustain the public's trust.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The Fed has special responsibilities in this regard.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Our monetary policy independence allows us to serve the public without regard to short-term political considerations, which, as history has shown, is critical for sound monetary policymaking.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: But that precious grant of independence brings with it a special obligation to be open and transparent, welcoming scrutiny by the public and their elected representatives in Congress.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Only in this way can the Fed maintain its legitimacy in our democratic system.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Among other initiatives, my colleagues and I on the FOMC are undertaking a year-long review of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy strategy, tools, and communication practices.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The review will involve a series of "Fed Listens" events around the country.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: These will include town-hall-style meetings and a conference where academic and nonacademic experts will share their views.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: These events will inform staff work and FOMC discussions as we plan for the future.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: While this is the first time the Fed has opened itself up in this way, many central banks around the world have conducted similar reviews, and our approach builds on their experiences.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: We believe that our existing framework for conducting monetary policy has generally served the public well, and the review may or may not produce major changes.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Consistent with the experience of other central banks with these reviews, the process is more likely to produce evolution rather than revolution.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: We seek no changes in law and we are not considering fundamental changes in the structure of the Fed, or in the 2 percent inflation objective.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: While there is a high bar for adopting fundamental change, it simply seems like good institutional practice to engage broadly with the public as part of a comprehensive approach to enhanced transparency and accountability.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Without ruling out other topics, we have highlighted three questions that seem particularly important at present (figure 4):

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Can the Federal Reserve best meet its statutory objectives with its existing monetary policy strategy, or should it consider strategies that aim to reverse past misses of the inflation objective?

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Are the existing monetary policy tools adequate to achieve and maintain maximum employment and price stability, or should the toolkit be expanded?

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: How can the FOMC's communication of its policy framework and implementation be improved?

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: I would like to spend a few minutes discussing the first topic.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Because interest rates around the world have steadily declined for several decades, rates in normal times now tend to be much closer to zero than in the past (figure 5).8Thus, when a recession comes, the Fed is likely to have less capacity to cut interest rates to stimulate the economy than in the past, suggesting that trips to the ELB may be more frequent.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: The post-crisis period has seen many economies around the world stuck for an extended period at the ELB, with slow growth and inflation well below target.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Persistently weak inflation could lead inflation expectations to drift downward, which would imply still lower interest rates, leaving even less room for central banks to cut interest rates to support the economy during a downturn.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: It is therefore very important for central banks to find more effective ways to battle the low-inflation syndrome that seems to accompany proximity to the ELB.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In the late 1990s, motivated by the Japanese experience with deflation and sluggish economic performance, economists began developing the argument that a central bank might substantially reduce the economic costs of ELB spells by adopting a makeup strategy.9The simplest version goes like this: If a spell with interest rates near the ELB leads to a persistent shortfall of inflation relative to the central bank's goal, once the ELB spell ends, the central bank would deliberately make up for the lost inflation by stimulating the economy and temporarily pushing inflation modestly above the target.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In standard macroeconomic models, if households and businesses are confident that this future inflationary stimulus will be coming, that prospect will promote anticipatory consumption and investment.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: This can substantially reduce the economic costs of ELB spells.10Researchers have suggested many variations on makeup strategies.11For example, the central bank could target average inflation over time, implying that misses on either side of the target would be offset.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: By the time of the crisis, there was a well-established body of model-based research suggesting that some kind of makeup policy could be beneficial.12In light of this research, one might ask why the Fed and other major central banks chose not to pursue such a policy.13The answer lies in the uncertain distance between models and reality.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: For makeup strategies to achieve their stabilizing benefits, households and businesses must be quite confident that the "makeup stimulus" is really coming.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: This confidence is what prompts them to raise spending and investment in the midst of a downturn.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In models, confidence in the policy is merely an assumption.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In practice, when policymakers considered these policies in the wake of the crisis, they had major questions about whether a central bank's promise of good times to come would have moved the hearts, minds, and pocketbooks of the public.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Part of the problem is that when the time comes to deliver the inflationary stimulus, that policy is likely to be unpopular--what is known as the time consistency problem in economics.14

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Experience in the United States and around the world suggests that more frequent ELB episodes could prove quite costly in the future.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: My FOMC colleagues and I believe that we have a responsibility to the American people to consider policies that might promote significantly better economic outcomes.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Makeup strategies are probably the most prominent idea and deserve serious attention.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: They are largely untried, however, and we have reason to question how they would perform in practice.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Before they could be successfully implemented, there would have to be widespread societal understanding and acceptance--as I suggested, a high bar for any fundamental change.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: In this review, we seek to start a discussion about makeup strategies and other policies that might broadly benefit the American people.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: ConclusionTonight I have focused on policy normalization and our efforts to engage the public in what may come after.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Before concluding, I will say a few words on current conditions and the outlook.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Right now, most measures of the health and strength of the labor market look as favorable as they have in many decades.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Inflation will probably run a bit below our objective for a time due to declines in energy prices, but those effects are likely to prove transitory.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Core inflation, which is often a reliable indicator of where inflation is headed over time, is quite close to 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Despite this favorable picture, we have seen some cross-currents in recent months.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: With nothing in the outlook demanding an immediate policy response and particularly given muted inflation pressures, the Committee has adopted a patient, wait-and-see approach to considering any alteration in the stance of policy.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Considering monetary policy more broadly, we are inviting thorough public scrutiny and are hoping to foster conversation regarding how the Fed can best exercise the precious monetary policy independence we have been granted.

title: Monetary Policy: Normalization and the Road Ahead
sentence_text: Our goal is to enhance the public's trust in the Federal Reserve--our most valuable asset.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: It is a pleasure to speak here this evening at the 87th Awards Dinner.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Tonight I will start with the near-term outlook for the U.S. economy.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Then I will turn to a topic that is inspired by the Citizens Budget Commission's mission statement, which focuses on the "well-being of future New Yorkers."

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: I imagine that future New Yorkers attending this dinner in 50 years may not look back on the near-term outlook in February 2018 as very interesting or important.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: So, tonight, after a brief review of the here and now, I will focus on an issue that is likely to be of more lasting importance: the need for policies that will support and encourage participation in the labor force, promote longer-term growth in our rapidly evolving economy, and spread the benefits of prosperity as widely as possible.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: The State of the Economy and Near-Term ProspectsBeginning with the here and now, Congress has charged the Federal Reserve with achieving maximum employment and stable prices, two objectives that together are called the dual mandate.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: I am pleased to say that, judged against these goals, the economy is in a good place.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: The current economic expansion has been under way for almost 10 years.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: This long period of growth has pushed the unemployment rate down near historic lows (figure 1).

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: The employment gains have been broad based across all racial and ethnic groups and all levels of educational attainment as well as among the disabled (figure 2).1And while the unemployment rate for African Americans and Hispanics remains above the rates for whites and Asians, the disparities have narrowed appreciably as the economic expansion has continued.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Nearly all job market indicators are better than a few years ago, and many are at their most favorable levels in decades.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: After lagging earlier in the expansion, wages and overall compensation--pay plus benefits­­--are now growing faster than a few years ago (figure 3).

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: It is especially encouraging that the labor force participation rate of people in their prime working years, ages 25 to 54, has been rising for the past three years.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: More plentiful jobs and rising wages are drawing more people into the workforce and encouraging others who might have left to stay.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: In addition, business-sector productivity growth, which had been disappointing during the expansion, moved up in the first three quarters of 2018.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Rising productivity allows wages to increase without adding to inflation pressures.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Sustained productivity growth is a necessary ingredient for longer-run improvements in living standards.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: The price stability side of our mandate is also in a good place.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: After remaining below our target for several years, inflation by our preferred measure averaged roughly 2 percent last year (figure 4).

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Inflation has softened a bit since then, largely reflecting the recent drop in oil prices.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Futures markets and other indicators suggest that oil prices are unlikely to fall further, and if this proves correct, oil's drag on overall inflation will subside.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Consistent with that view, core inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy prices and often provides a better signal of where inflation is heading, is currently running just a touch below our 2 percent objective.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Signs of upward pressure on inflation appear muted despite the strong labor market.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: While the data I have discussed so far give a favorable picture of the economy, it is also important to acknowledge that not everyone has shared in the benefits of the expansion to the same extent, and that too many households still struggle to make ends meet.2In addition, over the past few months we have seen some crosscurrents and conflicting signals about the near-term outlook.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: For instance, growth has slowed in some major economies, particularly China and Europe.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Uncertainty is elevated around some unresolved government policy issues, including Brexit and ongoing trade negotiations.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: And financial conditions have tightened since last fall.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: While most of the incoming domestic economic data have been solid, some surveys of business and consumer sentiment have moved lower.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Unexpectedly weak retail sales data for December also give reason for caution.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Given the positive outlook but also muted inflation pressures and the crosscurrents I just mentioned, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) will be patient as we determine what future adjustments to the target range for the federal funds rate may be appropriate to support our dual-mandate objectives.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: This common-sense risk-management approach has served the Committee well in the past.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: I will turn now from the near-term outlook to the question of how the economy will perform over the long haul.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Longer-Term Challenges and OpportunitiesFrom 1991 through 2007, the economy expanded annually at about 3 percent, similar to the pace for much of second half of the 20th century.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Since 2007, however, growth has averaged just 1.6 percent.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: If the earlier 3 percent growth had persisted over the past 12 years, incomes today would be almost 20 percent higher than they now are.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: From the standpoint of future Americans, if the slower growth persists for a half-century, incomes will end up roughly half of what they would have been.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Why has growth slowed, and what can we do about it?

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: To understand the causes of the slowdown, it is useful to divide growth into two components: (1) growth in the cumulative number of hours of worked by all workers and (2) growth in the amount of output derived, on average, from each hour of work.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: We refer to output per hour of work as "labor productivity."

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: From 1991 through 2007, when the economy expanded at a 3 percent average rate, hours worked increased about 1 percent a year and economy-wide productivity grew about 2 percent (figure 5).3Since 2007, both of these growth factors have slowed by about half, with hours worked annually increasing only 0.5 percent from 2008 to 2018 and productivity rising just 1 percent on average.4

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
sentence_text: Growth in hours worked has slowed, in part, because of slower U.S. population growth.

title: Recent Economic Developments and Longer-Term Challenges
