sentence_text: The 15 events involved a wide range of participants—workforce development groups, union members, small business owners, residents of low- and moderate-income communities, retirees, and others—to hear about how our policies affect peoples' daily lives and livelihoods.19The stories we heard atFed Listensevents became a potent vehicle for us to connect with the people and communities that our policies are intended to benefit.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: One of the clear messages we heard was that the strong labor market that prevailed before the pandemic was generating employment opportunities for many Americans who in the past had not found jobs readily available.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: A clear takeaway from these events was the importance of achieving and sustaining a strong job market, particularly for people from low- and moderate-income communities.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The research conference brought together some of the world's leading academic experts to address topics central to our review, and the presentations and robust discussion we engaged in were an important input to our review process.20

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Finally, the Committee explored the range of issues that were brought to light during the course of the review in five consecutive meetings beginning in July 2019.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Analytical staff work put together by teams across the Federal Reserve System provided essential background for each of the Committee's discussions.21

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Our plans to conclude the review earlier this year were, like so many things, delayed by the arrival of the pandemic.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: When we resumed our discussions last month, we turned our attention to distilling the most important lessons of the review in a revised Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: New Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy StrategyThe federated structure of the Federal Reserve, reflected in the FOMC, ensures that we always have a diverse range of perspectives on monetary policy, and that is certainly the case today.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Nonetheless, I am pleased to say that the revised consensus statement was adopted today with the unanimous support of Committee participants.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Our new consensus statement, like its predecessor, explains how we interpret the mandate Congress has given us and describes the broad framework that we believe will best promote our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Before addressing the key changes in our statement, let me highlight some areas of continuity.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We continue to believe that specifying a numerical goal for employment is unwise, because the maximum level of employment is not directly measurable and changes over time for reasons unrelated to monetary policy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The significant shifts in estimates of the natural rate of unemployment over the past decade reinforce this point.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: In addition, we have not changed our view that a longer-run inflation rate of 2 percent is most consistent with our mandate to promote both maximum employment and price stability.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Finally, we continue to believe that monetary policy must be forward looking, taking into account the expectations of households and businesses and the lags in monetary policy's effect on the economy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Thus, our policy actions continue to depend on the economic outlook as well as the risks to the outlook, including potential risks to the financial system that could impede the attainment of our goals.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The key innovations in our new consensus statement reflect the changes in the economy I described.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Our new statement explicitly acknowledges the challenges posed by the proximity of interest rates to the effective lower bound.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: By reducing our scope to support the economy by cutting interest rates, the lower bound increases downward risks to employment and inflation.22To counter these risks, we are prepared to use our full range of tools to support the economy.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: With regard to the employment side of our mandate, our revised statement emphasizes that maximum employment is a broad-based and inclusive goal.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: This change reflects our appreciation for the benefits of a strong labor market, particularly for many in low- and moderate-income communities.23In addition, our revised statement says that our policy decision will be informed by our "assessments of theshortfallsof employment from its maximum level" rather than by "deviationsfrom its maximum level" as in our previous statement.24This change may appear subtle, but it reflects our view that a robust job market can be sustained without causing an outbreak of inflation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: In earlier decades when the Phillips curve was steeper, inflation tended to rise noticeably in response to a strengthening labor market.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: It was sometimes appropriate for the Fed to tighten monetary policy as employment rose toward its estimated maximum level in order to stave off an unwelcome rise in inflation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The change to "shortfalls" clarifies that, going forward, employment can run at or above real-time estimates of its maximum level without causing concern, unless accompanied by signs of unwanted increases in inflation or the emergence of other risks that could impede the attainment of our goals.25Of course, when employment is below its maximum level, as is clearly the case now, we will actively seek to minimize that shortfall by using our tools to support economic growth and job creation.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We have also made important changes with regard to the price-stability side of our mandate.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Our longer-run goal continues to be an inflation rate of 2 percent.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Our statement emphasizes that our actions to achieve both sides of our dual mandate will be most effective if longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: However, if inflation runs below 2 percent following economic downturns but never moves above 2 percent even when the economy is strong, then, over time, inflation will average less than 2 percent.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Households and businesses will come to expect this result, meaning that inflation expectations would tend to move below our inflation goal and pull realized inflation down.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: To prevent this outcome and the adverse dynamics that could ensue, our new statement indicates that we will seek to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Therefore, following periods when inflation has been running below 2 percent, appropriate monetary policy will likely aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: In seeking to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time, we are not tying ourselves to a particular mathematical formula that defines the average.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Thus, our approach could be viewed as a flexible form of average inflation targeting.26Our decisions about appropriate monetary policy will continue to reflect a broad array of considerations and will not be dictated by any formula.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Of course, if excessive inflationary pressures were to build or inflation expectations were to ratchet above levels consistent with our goal, we would not hesitate to act.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: The revisions to our statement add up to a robust updating of our monetary policy framework.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: To an extent, these revisions reflect the way we have been conducting policy in recent years.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: At the same time, however, there are some important new features.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Overall, our new Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy conveys our continued strong commitment to achieving our goals, given the difficult challenges presented by the proximity of interest rates to the effective lower bound.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: In conducting monetary policy, we will remain highly focused on fostering as strong a labor market as possible for the benefit of all Americans.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: And we will steadfastly seek to achieve a 2 percent inflation rate over time.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: Looking AheadOur review has provided a platform for productive discussion and engagement with the public we serve.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: TheFed Listensevents helped us connect with our core constituency, the American people, and hear directly how their everyday lives are affected by our policies.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: We believe that conducting a review at regular intervals is a good institutional practice, providing valuable feedback and enhancing transparency and accountability.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: And with the ever-changing economy, future reviews will allow us to take a step back, reflect on what we have learned, and adapt our practices as we strive to achieve our dual-mandate goals.

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
sentence_text: As our statement indicates, we plan to undertake a thorough public review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communication practices roughly every five years.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: Thank you, President Mester and Treye Johnson, and thanks to everyone for joining us.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: My job today is to listen, so I will keep my remarks short.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: But I do want to say that these conversations are incredibly valuable.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: They give context to reams of data and definition to a huge and complex economic picture.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: They also help solve problems on a practical level.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: Feedback from our Investing in America's Workforce initiative found a pronounced need for workforce and economic development programs to more closely align, for instance.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: And employers' input has influenced work across the Fed System, including the Cleveland Fed, as they look at how skills on the lower end of the pay scale can transfer to higher-earning jobs.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: So from me, and on behalf of my colleagues: Thank you for your time today and for your ongoing insight.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: It is not lost on me that we are meeting on Juneteenth amid a renewed reckoning of racial injustice.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: The pandemic has again exposed a range of troubling inequalities, most of them of long standing.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: As the national discussion continues, it is critical to remember that equity includes access to education, work, and economic opportunity.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: I am reminded that Dr. King delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech, just a few short blocks from the Federal Reserve, at a rally whose full title was the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: We meet today amid the immense hardship and suffering the coronavirus has caused.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: Lives and livelihoods have been lost, and uncertainty looms large.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: We are all grateful to our frontline health-care workers who put themselves in harm's way every day and to the essential workers helping us meet our needs.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: While we are all affected, the burden has fallen disproportionately on those least able to bear it.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: Before the virus swept across the globe, the American economy was in a good place.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: We were experiencing the longest expansion on record, and unemployment had reached historic lows.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: However, that is a national average that can gloss over stark realities.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: That economic good fortune had eluded pockets across the country, including Youngstown.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: A particular cruelty of the pandemic has been its disproportionate effects on many areas that were already suffering.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: We will make our way back from this, but it will take time and work.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: Some of the most valuable information we get from these discussions is how people are working to create growth.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: Your feedback can be an invaluable example for other communities with similar challenges.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: The Lordstown closure served as a reminder of how interconnected local economies can be, and other areas have experienced similar losses.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: Your work on diversifying the economy, on skills development, on small business support programs, and in so many other areas can all serve as models for others to replicate.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: The path ahead is likely to be challenging.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: But given the opportunity, I'll always bet on the American people and on the kind of community resolve and dedication we're hearing about today.

title: Introductory Comments
sentence_text: I'm looking forward to your insight and to hearing more about how you've been working to revitalize Youngstown's economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I just want to say a few words of welcome and thank everyone for being here—albeit in much different circumstances than would otherwise be expected.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We've held manyFed Listensevents over the past 16 months, and it's important to note that these conversations aren't just a nice way to talk to people from around the country, although they are that.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: What they provide—what you provide—is insight that we just can't get anywhere else.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: You add depth and definition to the flood of data that flows through the Fed each day.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: You give us perspective on the economic realities that don't show up on a spreadsheet.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: You help us see those complex sets of data that analyze the American economy through the eyes of the people, businesses, and communities that make up the American economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And that information is very helpful to us as we make our policy decisions.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: So this is a valuable exercise for us.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And an enjoyable one as well, so we truly do appreciate it on a number of levels.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Reserve Banks are also continuing to host conversations in communities across the country to help capture economic realities on the ground.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are in the midst of an economic downturn without modern precedent.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It was sudden, and it is severe.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It has already erased the job gains of the past decade and has inflicted acute pain across the country.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And while the burden is widespread, it is not evenly spread.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Those taking the brunt of the fallout are those least able to bear it.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The pain of this downturn is compounded by the upending of normal life, along with great uncertainty about the future.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In the best of times, predicting the path of the economy with any certainty is difficult.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: John Kenneth Galbraith famously said that economic forecasting exists to make astrology look respectable.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are now experiencing a whole new level of uncertainty, as questions only the virus can answer complicate the outlook.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Policies that address the resumption of economic activity are the province of elected officials at all levels of government, in close consultation with public health and medical professionals.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But all of us have our own decisions to make as well, and those decisions will depend on public confidence that it is again safe to undertake various activities.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: From an economic perspective, we hope to learn a lot from your experiences and from what you're hearing from your colleagues, customers, and communities: How they're coping with that uncertainty now, how they're thinking about a future that's harder to plan for, and what matters most as they navigate the path.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The feedback we get from our community and business contacts has always been crucial in how we conduct monetary policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In extraordinary times such as these, it takes on even greater importance.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I want to thank you again for providing that insight and look forward to the conversation.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The coronavirus has left a devastating human and economic toll in its wake as it has spread around the globe.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: This is a worldwide public health crisis, and health-care workers have been the first responders, showing courage and determination and earning our lasting gratitude.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: So have the legions of other essential workers who put themselves at risk every day on our behalf.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: As a nation, we have temporarily withdrawn from many kinds of economic and social activity to help slow the spread of the virus.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Some sectors of the economy have been effectively closed since mid-March.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: People have put their lives and livelihoods on hold, making enormous sacrifices to protect not just their own health and that of their loved ones, but also their neighbors and the broader community.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: While we are all affected, the burden has fallen most heavily on those least able to bear it.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The scope and speed of this downturn are without modern precedent, significantly worse than any recession since World War II.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: We are seeing a severe decline in economic activity and in employment, and already the job gains of the past decade have been erased.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Since the pandemic arrived in force just two months ago, more than 20 million people have lost their jobs.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: A Fed survey being released tomorrow reflects findings similar to many others: Among people who were working in February, almost 40 percent of those in households making less than $40,000 a year had lost a job in March.1This reversal of economic fortune has caused a level of pain that is hard to capture in words, as lives are upended amid great uncertainty about the future.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: This downturn is different from those that came before it.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Earlier in the post– World War II period, recessions were sometimes linked to a cycle of high inflation followed by Fed tightening.2The lower inflation levels of recent decades have brought a series of long expansions, often accompanied by the buildup of imbalances over time—asset prices that reached unsupportable levels, for instance, or important sectors of the economy, such as housing, that boomed unsustainably.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The current downturn is unique in that it is attributable to the virus and the steps taken to limit its fallout.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: This time, high inflation was not a problem.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: There was no economy-threatening bubble to pop and no unsustainable boom to bust.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The virus is the cause, not the usual suspects—something worth keeping in mind as we respond.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Today I will briefly discuss the measures taken so far to offset the economic effects of the virus, and the path ahead.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Governments around the world have responded quickly with measures to support workers who have lost income and businesses that have either closed or seen a sharp drop in activity.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The response here in the United States has been particularly swift and forceful.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: To date, Congress has provided roughly $2.9 trillion in fiscal support for households, businesses, health-care providers, and state and local governments—about 14 percent of gross domestic product.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: While the coronavirus economic shock appears to be the largest on record, the fiscal response has also been the fastest and largest response for any postwar downturn.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: At the Fed, we have also acted with unprecedented speed and force.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: After rapidly cutting the federal funds rate to close to zero, we took a wide array of additional measures to facilitate the flow of credit in the economy, which can be grouped into four areas.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: First, outright purchases of Treasuries and agency mortgage-backed securities to restore functionality in these critical markets.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Second, liquidity and funding measures, including discount window measures, expanded swap lines with foreign central banks, and several facilities with Treasury backing to support smooth functioning in money markets.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Third, with additional backing from the Treasury, facilities to more directly support the flow of credit to households, businesses, and state and local governments.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: And fourth, temporary regulatory adjustments to encourage and allow banks to expand their balance sheets to support their household and business customers.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The Fed takes actions such as these only in extraordinary circumstances, like those we face today.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: For example, our authority to extend credit directly to private nonfinancial businesses and state and local governments exists only in "unusual and exigent circumstances" and with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: When this crisis is behind us, we will put these emergency tools away.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: While the economic response has been both timely and appropriately large, it may not be the final chapter, given that the path ahead is both highly uncertain and subject to significant downside risks.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Economic forecasts are uncertain in the best of times, and today the virus raises a new set of questions: How quickly and sustainably will it be brought under control?

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Can new outbreaks be avoided as social-distancing measures lapse?

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: How long will it take for confidence to return and normal spending to resume?

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: And what will be the scope and timing of new therapies, testing, or a vaccine?

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The answers to these questions will go a long way toward setting the timing and pace of the economic recovery.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Since the answers are currently unknowable, policies will need to be ready to address a range of possible outcomes.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The overall policy response to date has provided a measure of relief and stability, and will provide some support to the recovery when it comes.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: But the coronavirus crisis raises longer-term concerns as well.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The record shows that deeper and longer recessions can leave behind lasting damage to the productive capacity of the economy.3Avoidable household and business insolvencies can weigh on growth for years to come.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Long stretches of unemployment can damage or end workers' careers as their skills lose value and professional networks dry up, and leave families in greater debt.4The loss of thousands of small- and medium-sized businesses across the country would destroy the life's work and family legacy of many business and community leaders and limit the strength of the recovery when it comes.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: These businesses are a principal source of job creation—something we will sorely need as people seek to return to work.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: A prolonged recession and weak recovery could also discourage business investment and expansion, further limiting the resurgence of jobs as well as the growth of capital stock and the pace of technological advancement.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: The result could be an extended period of low productivity growth and stagnant incomes.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: We ought to do what we can to avoid these outcomes, and that may require additional policy measures.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: At the Fed, we will continue to use our tools to their fullest until the crisis has passed and the economic recovery is well under way.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Recall that the Fed has lending powers, not spending powers.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: A loan from a Fed facility can provide a bridge across temporary interruptions to liquidity, and those loans will help many borrowers get through the current crisis.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: But the recovery may take some time to gather momentum, and the passage of time can turn liquidity problems into solvency problems.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: Additional fiscal support could be costly, but worth it if it helps avoid long-term economic damage and leaves us with a stronger recovery.

title: Current Economic Issues
sentence_text: This tradeoff is one for our elected representatives, who wield powers of taxation and spending.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: The challenge we face today is different in scope and character from those we have faced before.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: The coronavirus has spread quickly around the world, leaving a tragic and growing toll of illness and lost lives.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: This is first and foremost a public health crisis, and the most important response is coming from those on the front lines in hospitals, emergency services, and care facilities.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: We watch in collective awe and gratitude as these dedicated individuals put themselves at risk in service to others and to our nation.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: Like other countries, we are taking forceful measures to control the spread of the virus.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: Businesses have shuttered, workers are staying home, and we have suspended many basic social interactions.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: People have been asked to put their lives and livelihoods on hold, at significant economic and personal cost.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: We are moving with alarming speed from 50-year lows in unemployment to what will likely be very high, although temporary, levels.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: All of us are affected, but the burdens are falling most heavily on those least able to carry them.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: It is worth remembering that the measures we are taking to contain the virus represent an essential investment in our individual and collective health.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: As a society, we should do everything we can to provide relief to those who are suffering for the public good.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: The recently passed Cares Act is an important step in honoring that commitment, providing $2.2 trillion in relief to those who have lost their jobs, to low- and middle-income households, to employers of all sizes, to hospitals and health-care providers, and to state and local governments.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: And there are reports of additional legislation in the works.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: The critical task of delivering financial support directly to those most affected falls to elected officials, who use their powers of taxation and spending to make decisions about where we, as a society, should direct our collective resources.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: The Fed can also contribute in important ways: by providing a measure of relief and stability during this period of constrained economic activity, and by using our tools to ensure that the eventual recovery is as vigorous as possible.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: To those ends, we have lowered interest rates to near zero in order to bring down borrowing costs.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: We have also committed to keeping rates at this low level until we are confident that the economy has weathered the storm and is on track to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: Even more importantly, we have acted to safeguard financial markets in order to provide stability to the financial system and support the flow of credit in the economy.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: As a result of the economic dislocations caused by the virus, some essential financial markets had begun to sink into dysfunction, and many channels that households, businesses, and state and local governments rely on for credit had simply stopped working.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: We acted forcefully to get our markets working again, and, as a result, market conditions have generally improved.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: Many of the programs we are undertaking to support the flow of credit rely on emergency lending powers that are available only in very unusual circumstances—such as those we find ourselves in today—and only with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: We are deploying these lending powers to an unprecedented extent, enabled in large part by the financial backing from Congress and the Treasury.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: We will continue to use these powers forcefully, proactively, and aggressively until we are confident that we are solidly on the road to recovery.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: I would stress that these arelendingpowers, notspendingpowers.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: The Fed is not authorized to grant money to particular beneficiaries.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: The Fed can only make secured loans to solvent entities with the expectation that the loans will be fully repaid.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: In the situation we face today, many borrowers will benefit from these programs, as will the overall economy.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: But there will also be entities of various kinds that need direct fiscal support rather than a loan they would struggle to repay.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: Our emergency measures are reserved for truly rare circumstances, such as those we face today.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: When the economy is well on its way back to recovery, and private markets and institutions are once again able to perform their vital functions of channeling credit and supporting economic growth, we will put these emergency tools away.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: None of us has the luxury of choosing our challenges; fate and history provide them for us.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: Our job is to meet the tests we are presented.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: At the Fed, we are doing all we can to help shepherd the economy through this difficult time.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: When the spread of the virus is under control, businesses will reopen, and people will come back to work.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: There is every reason to believe that the economic rebound, when it comes, can be robust.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: We entered this turbulent period on a strong economic footing, and that should help support the recovery.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: In the meantime, we are using our tools to help build a bridge from the solid economic foundation on which we entered this crisis to a position of regained economic strength on the other side.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: I want to close by thanking the millions on the front lines: those working in health care, sanitation, transportation, grocery stores, warehouses, deliveries, security—including our own team at the Federal Reserve—and countless others.

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
sentence_text: Day after day, you have put yourselves in harm's way for others: to care for us, to ensure we have access to the things we need, and to help us through this difficult time.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It is a pleasure to welcome everyone, including colleagues from the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) and in particular from the BIS Innovation Hub, to the opening of the New York Innovation Center.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The pace of technological change and innovation over the last decade has led some to argue that we are on the brink of a fourth industrial revolution—a digital revolution.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Certainly, rapid innovation, including through the application of advanced digital technologies, machine learning, artificial intelligence, and big data, is revolutionizing the financial sector.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve has a mandate to understand and, in some cases, manage these changes, but it also has a responsibility to be at the forefront of change to deliver to the American people—and the international community—a reliable, efficient, and inclusive monetary and financial system.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Furthering the efforts around the Federal Reserve System to harness the power of innovation, I am delighted to welcome the opening of the New York Innovation Center.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Located at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in the heart of the most important financial center in the world, this Innovation Center will draw on the expertise at the bank, in the Federal Reserve System, and from the broader financial community, as well as experts around the world to analyze and bring technology to bear on improving the global financial system.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Increasing the synergies of the New York Innovation Center will be its strategic partnership with the BIS Innovation Hub, recently established to foster dialogue, collaboration and knowledge-sharing among central banks and other authorities and institutions.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In particular, the partnership will support our analysis of digital currencies—including central bank digital currencies; help to improve our current payment system—with a particular focus on making cross-border payments faster and less expensive; and it will provide new tools to aid our supervision of the financial system.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Linking up with the BIS in this way will enhance our ability to collaborate with central banks around the world and will ensure that the best and most up-to-date information, research, and practices are flowing freely.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Since its inception in January 2020, I have served as head of the BIS Innovation Hub Advisory Committee and am very pleased that the Federal Reserve will be able to partner with the Hub in this important way.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: So I want to extend my thanks to President Williams, Agustin Carstens, and all those that worked on the establishment of this center.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And I look forward to the advances of both these institutions in supporting innovation in service to the safety and soundness of the financial system.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It is a pleasure to welcome you to today's discussion and to host this third Conference on Diversity and Inclusion in Economics, Finance, and Central Banking.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: My colleagues and I are proud to cosponsor this conference along with the Bank of Canada, the Bank of England, and the European Central Bank.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are truly honored by this impressive array of panelists, discussants, and speakers, which include eminent research economists as well as current and former policymakers from here and around the world.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are grateful for the time, energy, and insights you have committed to this work, and we look forward to the day when we can gather together again in person.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: To kick off today's discussions, I would like to touch briefly on these subjects from two distinct perspectives.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: First, I will discuss some of the ways we at the Federal Reserve approach issues of persistent economic inequities.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Then I will review some of how we as central banks are addressing the issues around diversity and inclusion in economics as institutions and employers.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: PolicymakingTaking the first of these topics, we know, of course, that an economy is healthier and stronger when as many people as possible are able to work.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: If entrenched inequities prevent some Americans from participating fully in our labor markets, not only will they be held back from opportunities, but our economy overall will not realize its potential.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And those who have historically been left behind stand the best chance of prospering in a strong economy with plentiful job opportunities.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our recent history highlights both the benefits of a strong economy and the severe costs of a weak one.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In the later years of the long expansion that ended with the pandemic, the benefits of employment continued to spread more widely and to reach those at the margins of the economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Prior to the pandemic, unemployment was at 50‑year lows.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Wages had been moving up, and meaningfully so, especially on the lower ends of the pay scale.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Many who had struggled for years were finding jobs.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Racial disparities in unemployment were narrowing.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In contrast, one of the great cruelties of the COVID-19 recession is the toll it took on workers who were finally beginning to experience the benefits of a period of historically long economic growth.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Those same groups, unfortunately, disproportionately shouldered the brunt of the pandemic's burden.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Most entrenched inequities are beyond the power of monetary policy to address.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The specific goals given to us by Congress, however, to foster achievement of our dual mandate of maximum employment and price stability, form the foundation of a strong and stable economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It was with this in mind that my colleagues and I on the Federal Open Market Committee, as part of last year's update to the Fed's monetary policy framework, defined maximum employment as a broad and inclusive goal.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: This innovation recognizes that a strong labor market delivers broad-reaching benefits and extends those benefits in particular to low- and moderate-income communities.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While monetary policy does not target any particular group of people, when we assess whether we are at maximum employment, we purposely look at a wide range of indicators, and we are attentive to disparities in the labor market, rather than just the headline numbers.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Diversity and inclusion play a role in policymaking as well.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As policymakers working on behalf of the entire public, we benefit greatly by seeking out and listening to the perspectives and experiences of people who represent the diverse landscape of the economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We regularly meet with a broad range of groups as we assess the economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And as we worked to update our monetary policy framework, we hosted a series of listening events across the country before and during the pandemic, and these conversations factored importantly into our thinking and our new framework.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Diversity in EconomicsNext, I would like to turn to an issue facing many of us at this conference—namely, how central banks as institutions and employers grapple with and confront diversity and inclusion within economics.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Collectively, we are among the largest employers in the field of economics, which both affects our own workplaces and affords us an opportunity to help influence and shape the evolution of the profession.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Throughout my career, in both the public and the private sectors, I have seen that the best and most successful organizations are often the ones that have a strong and persistent commitment to diversity and inclusion.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: These organizations consistently attract the best talent, by investing in and retaining a world-class workforce.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I know that the central banks represented here today are indeed working diligently to do just that.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: At the Fed, we are hosting events like this one, where high-quality economic research is brought to bear.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are working to foster an inclusive workplace environment where staff can feel comfortable at work and to promote a similarly inclusive culture within the profession.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are working to broaden our reach by recruiting at historically black colleges and universities and Hispanic-serving institutions, as well as by hosting events to promote career opportunities at the Fed.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: My colleagues and I know that both the opportunities and the challenges are great and that the work is never truly done.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Whether you are a researcher bringing your analytical skills to bear, or you are on the front lines of improving the diversity of the economics pipeline, or perhaps you are in an institution where you are redoubling your efforts to attract diverse talent, your endeavors are making a difference.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As a group, we are fortunate to have opportunities like this to reaffirm the importance of diversity in our professions, in our research, and in our policymaking, and I am glad that we are here today to continue this work.
