title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I am pleased to welcome everyone to today's conference on gender and the economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Thank you for being here, for participating, and for lending your expertise on this important topic.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We have gathered an impressive lineup of speakers and panelists, who will address a range of timely and important issues.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: To open the conference, I will give a brief tour of the important research on display here, then discuss how the pandemic has affected the economy along gender lines.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: ResearchThe speakers and panelists will be exploring a wide range of topics, from a historical review of gender issues and the economy to how someone's education options—and the financing of those choices—affect that person's early career and financial stability.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Speakers and panelists will also be looking at the influence of family and caregiving on career advancement and will discuss timely topics of wealth and retirement.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Pandemic and GenderThe pandemic widened deep-rooted inequities in our economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Along racial, gender, and socioeconomic lines, those least able to bear it, unfortunately, were those who were most affected.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Women make up the majority of frontline workers, who have been under substantial strain—and subject to personal risks—during the pandemic.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Additionally, women took on the majority of caring responsibilities, for older relatives and children alike.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As schools closed and childcare services shuttered during the worst of the pandemic, that added responsibility and stress made working more difficult for some and took many away from their jobs.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: These burdens are real and have been an additional challenge during an already challenging time.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In a reversal of previous recessions, women suffered more from job losses in the COVID-19 recession than men.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In April 2020, the unemployment rate for women was 16.1 percent, compared with 13.6 percent for men.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The gap persisted until September of that year, and while it has since reversed, it does not account for the many women who left the workforce entirely.1

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Increased childcare responsibilities during the pandemic also affected many parents' working lives.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Mothers of small children were more likely to exit the labor force during the pandemic compared with previous periods.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: These increases were larger among mothers who earned less before the pandemic.2

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: This issue was widespread and had significant financial consequences on many households.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve's 2020 Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking shows that the pandemic disrupted childcare or in-person schooling for nearly 70 percent of parents, with 25 percent of mothers reporting they did not work or worked less as a result.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Many faced substantial financial difficulty.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Only 37 percent of mothers who reported not working or working less because of childcare or schooling disruptions would cover a $400 expense with cash or its equivalent.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As households and the economy continue to recover, the lessons learned during this era will help inform how policymakers and communities work to bridge those gaps.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Long-standing disparities weigh on the productive capacity of our economy, which can only realize its full potential if everyone has a solid chance to contribute to, and to reap the benefits of, broad-reaching prosperity.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: ConclusionIn closing, I want to thank you all for taking the time to join this discussion.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: These are vital issues not just to the economy, but to families across the country.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: There is more to be done, but this conference highlights the number of world-class researchers, practitioners, and policymakers who are dedicated to understanding and addressing these deeply entrenched issues.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As a group, we have an opportunity to reaffirm the importance of gender parity and diversity in our professions, in our research, and in our policymaking.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: Nearly three years after we started holding Fed Listens events around the country, the program has proved to be even more valuable than we could have imagined.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: Its original purpose was to elicit broad feedback as part of our monetary policy framework review.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: However, the Fed has long viewed community outreach as a vital part of our economic understanding, and these discussions have delivered such value that Fed Listens has evolved to join the other regular staples of our outreach work.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: These events enable us to hear directly from people on the ground, at the heart of the sectors and industries you represent, from communities across the country, to add tone, contour and greater depth to the nation's economic portrait.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: These insights are particularly valuable as we move through this challenging and precedent shattering period.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: The speed and intensity of this downturn – and the rapidity of the recovery in many areas – are without modern precedent.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: I am very glad you could all join us today to offer your thoughts, and I want to thank you on behalf of the entire Federal Reserve System for both your presence today and for your continued feedback and participation.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: Some of the issues you are confronting are shared across sectors, while others are unique to your fields.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: Most of you are contending with changed workplaces, from safety protocols whose half-lives are unclear to fundamental shifts in how your industries operate, in everything from feeding people to how movies are released.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: Business plans have been reworked, outlooks have been revised, and the future continues to be tinged with uncertainty.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: While uncertainty often results in immobility for businesses, it can also spell opportunity, and the creativity and adaptability on display over the past 18 months have been among the few bright spots.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: I have been amazed and inspired by the flexibility and ingenuity, particularly that of small businesses, in shifting to meet the demands of a new reality.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: All of us are very much looking forward to the discussion today.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: You provide a wealth of information by sharing your experiences and those of your colleagues, customers, and communities.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: That has always been crucial in how we conduct monetary policy but means even more in extraordinary times such as these.

title: Introductory Remarks
sentence_text: I want to thank you again for providing that insight and look forward to the conversation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Seventeen months have passed since the U.S. economy faced the full force of the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: This shock led to an immediate and unprecedented decline as large parts of the economy were shuttered to contain the spread of the disease.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The path of recovery has been a difficult one, and a good place to begin is by thanking those on the front line fighting the pandemic: the essential workers who kept the economy going, those who have cared for others in need, and those in medical research, business, and government, who came together to discover, produce, and widely distribute effective vaccines in record time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We should also keep in our thoughts those who have lost their lives from COVID, as well as their loved ones.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Strong policy support has fueled a vigorous but uneven recovery—one that is, in many respects, historically anomalous.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: In a reversal of typical patterns in a downturn, aggregate personal income rose rather than fell, and households massively shifted their spending from services to manufactured goods.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Booming demand for goods and the strength and speed of the reopening have led to shortages and bottlenecks, leaving the COVID-constrained supply side unable to keep up.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The result has been elevated inflation in durable goods—a sector that has experienced an annual inflation rate well below zero over the past quarter century.1Labor market conditions are improving but turbulent, and the pandemic continues to threaten not only health and life, but also economic activity.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Many other advanced economies are experiencing similarly unusual conditions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: In my comments today, I will focus on the Fed's efforts to promote our maximum employment and price stability goals amid this upheaval, and suggest how lessons from history and a careful focus on incoming data and the evolving risks offer useful guidance for today's unique monetary policy challenges.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The Recession and Recovery So FarThe pandemic recession—the briefest yet deepest on record—displaced roughly 30 million workers in the space of two months.2The decline in output in the second quarter of 2020 was twice the full decline during the Great Recession of 2007–09.3But the pace of the recovery has exceeded expectations, with output surpassing its previous peak after only four quarters, less than half the time required following the Great Recession.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: As is typically the case, the recovery in employment has lagged that in output; nonetheless, employment gains have also come faster than expected.4

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been hardest hit.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: In particular, despite progress, joblessness continues to fall disproportionately on lower-wage workers in the service sector and on African Americans and Hispanics.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The unevenness of the recovery can further be seen through the lens of the sectoral shift of spending into goods—particularly durable goods such as appliances, furniture, and cars—and away from services, particularly in-person services in areas such as travel and leisure (figure 1).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: As the pandemic struck, restaurant meals fell 45 percent, air travel 95 percent, and dentist visits 65 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Even today, with overall gross domestic product and consumption spending more than fully recovered, services spending remains about 7 percent below trend.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Total employment is now 6 million below its February 2020 level, and 5 million of that shortfall is in the still-depressed service sector.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: In contrast, spending on durable goods has boomed since the start of the recovery and is now running about 20 percent above the pre-pandemic level.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: With demand outstripping pandemic-afflicted supply, rising durables prices are a principal factor lifting inflation well above our 2 percent objective.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Given the ongoing upheaval in the economy, some strains and surprises are inevitable.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The job of monetary policy is to promote maximum employment and price stability as the economy works through this challenging period.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: I will turn now to a discussion of progress toward those goals.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The Path Ahead: Maximum EmploymentThe outlook for the labor market has brightened considerably in recent months.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: After faltering last winter, job gains have risen steadily over the course of this year and now average 832,000 over the past three months, of which almost 800,000 have been in services (figure 2).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The pace of total hiring is faster than at any time in the recorded data before the pandemic.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The levels of job openings and quits are at record highs, and employers report that they cannot fill jobs fast enough to meet returning demand.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: These favorable conditions for job seekers should help the economy cover the considerable remaining ground to reach maximum employment.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The unemployment rate has declined to 5.4 percent, a post-pandemic low, but is still much too high, and the reported rate understates the amount of labor market slack.5Long-term unemployment remains elevated, and the recovery in labor force participation has lagged well behind the rest of the labor market, as it has in past recoveries.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: With vaccinations rising, schools reopening, and enhanced unemployment benefits ending, some factors that may be holding back job seekers are likely fading.6While the Delta variant presents a near-term risk, the prospects are good for continued progress toward maximum employment.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The Path Ahead: InflationThe rapid reopening of the economy has brought a sharp run-up in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Over the 12 months through July, measures of headline and core personal consumption expenditures inflation have run at 4.2 percent and 3.6 percent, respectively—well above our 2 percent longer-run objective.7Businesses and consumers widely report upward pressure on prices and wages.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Inflation at these levels is, of course, a cause for concern.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: But that concern is tempered by a number of factors that suggest that these elevated readings are likely to prove temporary.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: This assessment is a critical and ongoing one, and we are carefully monitoring incoming data.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The dynamics of inflation are complex, and we assess the inflation outlook from a number of different perspectives, as I will now discuss.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The absence so far of broad-based inflation pressuresThe spike in inflation is so far largely the product of a relatively narrow group of goods and services that have been directly affected by the pandemic and the reopening of the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Durable goods alone contributed about 1 percentage point to the latest 12‑month measures of headline and core inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Energy prices, which rebounded with the strong recovery, added another 0.8 percentage point to headline inflation, and from long experience we expect the inflation effects of these increases to be transitory.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: In addition, some prices—for example, for hotel rooms and airplane tickets—declined sharply during the recession and have now moved back up close to pre-pandemic levels.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The 12-month window we use in computing inflation now captures the rebound in prices but not the initial decline, temporarily elevating reported inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: These effects, which are adding a few tenths to measured inflation, should wash out over time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We consult a range of measures meant to capture whether price increases for particular items are spilling over into broad-based inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: These include trimmed mean measures and measures excluding durables and computed from just before the pandemic.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: These measures generally show inflation at or close to our 2 percent longer-run objective (figure 3).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We would be concerned at signs that inflationary pressures were spreading more broadly through the economy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Moderating inflation in higher-inflation itemsWe are also directly monitoring the prices of particular goods and services most affected by the pandemic and the reopening, and are beginning to see a moderation in some cases as shortages ease.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Used car prices, for example, appear to have stabilized; indeed, some price indicators are beginning to fall.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: If that continues, as many analysts predict, then used car prices will soon be pulling measured inflation down, as they did for much of the past decade.8

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: This same dynamic of upward inflation pressure dissipating and, in some cases, reversing seems likely to play out in durables more generally.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Over the 25 years preceding the pandemic, durables prices actually declined, with inflation averaging negative 1.9 percent per year (figure 5).9As supply problems have begun to resolve, inflation in durable goods other than autos has now slowed and may be starting to fall.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: It seems unlikely that durables inflation will continue to contribute importantly over time to overall inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We will be looking for evidence that supports or undercuts that expectation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: WagesWe also assess whether wage increases are consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Wage increases are essential to support a rising standard of living and are generally, of course, a welcome development.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: But if wage increases were to move materially and persistently above the levels of productivity gains and inflation, businesses would likely pass those increases on to customers, a process that could become the sort of "wage–price spiral" seen at times in the past.10Today we see little evidence of wage increases that might threaten excessive inflation (figure 6).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Broad-based measures of wages that adjust for compositional changes in the labor force, such as the employment cost index and the Atlanta Wage Growth Tracker, show wages moving up at a pace that appears consistent with our longer-term inflation objective.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We will continue to monitor this carefully.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Longer-term inflation expectationsPolicymakers and analysts generally believe that, as long as longer-term inflation expectations remain anchored, policy can and should look through temporary swings in inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Our monetary policy framework emphasizes that anchoring longer-term expectations at 2 percent is important for both maximum employment and price stability.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We carefully monitor a wide range of indicators of longer-term inflation expectations.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: These measures today are at levels broadly consistent with our 2 percent objective (figure 4).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Because measures of inflation expectations are individually noisy, we also focus on common patterns across the measures.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: One approach to summarizing these patterns is the Board staff's index of common inflation expectations (CIE), which combines information from a broad range of survey and market-based measures.11This index captures a general move down in expectations starting around 2014, a time when inflation was running persistently below 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: More recently, the index shows a welcome reversal of that decline and is now at levels more consistent with our 2 percent objective.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Longer-term inflation expectations have moved much less than actual inflation or near-term expectations, suggesting that households, businesses, and market participants also believe that current high inflation readings are likely to prove transitory and that, in any case, the Fed will keep inflation close to our 2 percent objective over time.12

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The prevalence of global disinflationary forces over the past quarter centuryFinally, it is worth noting that, since the 1990s, inflation in many advanced economies has run somewhat below 2 percent even in good times (figure 7).

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The pattern of low inflation likely reflects sustained disinflationary forces, including technology, globalization and perhaps demographic factors, as well as a stronger and more successful commitment by central banks to maintain price stability.13In the United States, unemployment ran below 4 percent for about two years before the pandemic, while inflation ran at or below 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Wages did move up across the income spectrum—a welcome development—but not by enough to lift price inflation consistently to 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: While the underlying global disinflationary factors are likely to evolve over time, there is little reason to think that they have suddenly reversed or abated.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: It seems more likely that they will continue to weigh on inflation as the pandemic passes into history.14

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We will continue to monitor incoming inflation data against each of these assessments.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: To sum up, the baseline outlook is for continued progress toward maximum employment, with inflation returning to levels consistent with our goal of inflation averaging 2 percent over time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Let me now turn to how the baseline outlook and the associated risks and uncertainties figure in our monetary policymaking.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Implications for Monetary PolicyThe period from 1950 through the early 1980s provides two important lessons for managing the risks and uncertainties we face today.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The early days of stabilization policy in the 1950s taught monetary policymakers not to attempt to offset what are likely to be temporary fluctuations in inflation.15Indeed, responding may do more harm than good, particularly in an era where policy rates are much closer to the effective lower bound even in good times.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The main influence of monetary policy on inflation can come after a lag of a year or more.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: If a central bank tightens policy in response to factors that turn out to be temporary, the main policy effects are likely to arrive after the need has passed.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The ill-timed policy move unnecessarily slows hiring and other economic activity and pushes inflation lower than desired.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Today, with substantial slack remaining in the labor market and the pandemic continuing, such a mistake could be particularly harmful.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We know that extended periods of unemployment can mean lasting harm to workers and to the productive capacity of the economy.16

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: History also teaches, however, that central banks cannot take for granted that inflation due to transitory factors will fade.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The 1970s saw two periods in which there were large increases in energy and food prices, raising headline inflation for a time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: But when the direct effects on headline inflation eased, core inflation continued to run persistently higher than before.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: One likely contributing factor was that the public had come to generally expect higher inflation—one reason why we now monitor inflation expectations so carefully.17

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Central banks have always faced the problem of distinguishing transitory inflation spikes from more troublesome developments, and it is sometimes difficult to do so with confidence in real time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: At such times, there is no substitute for a careful focus on incoming data and evolving risks.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: If sustained higher inflation were to become a serious concern, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) would certainly respond and use our tools to assure that inflation runs at levels that are consistent with our goal.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Incoming data should provide more evidence that some of the supply–demand imbalances are improving, and more evidence of a continued moderation in inflation, particularly in goods and services prices that have been most affected by the pandemic.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We also expect to see continued strong job creation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: And we will be learning more about the Delta variant's effects.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: For now, I believe that policy is well positioned; as always, we are prepared to adjust policy as appropriate to achieve our goals.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: That brings me to a concluding word on the path ahead for monetary policy.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The Committee remains steadfast in our oft-expressed commitment to support the economy for as long as is needed to achieve a full recovery.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The changes we made last year to our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy are well suited to address today's challenges.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We have said that we would continue our asset purchases at the current pace until we see substantial further progress toward our maximum employment and price stability goals, measured since last December, when we first articulated this guidance.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: My view is that the "substantial further progress" test has been met for inflation.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: There has also been clear progress toward maximum employment.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: At the FOMC's recent July meeting, I was of the view, as were most participants, that if the economy evolved broadly as anticipated, it could be appropriate to start reducing the pace of asset purchases this year.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The intervening month has brought more progress in the form of a strong employment report for July, but also the further spread of the Delta variant.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We will be carefully assessing incoming data and the evolving risks.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Even after our asset purchases end, our elevated holdings of longer-term securities will continue to support accommodative financial conditions.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: The timing and pace of the coming reduction in asset purchases will not be intended to carry a direct signal regarding the timing of interest rate liftoff, for which we have articulated a different and substantially more stringent test.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We have said that we will continue to hold the target range for the federal funds rate at its current level until the economy reaches conditions consistent with maximum employment, and inflation has reached 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: We have much ground to cover to reach maximum employment, and time will tell whether we have reached 2 percent inflation on a sustainable basis.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: These are challenging times for the public we serve, as the pandemic and its unprecedented toll on health and economic activity linger.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: But I will end on a positive note.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Before the pandemic, we all saw the extraordinary benefits that a strong labor market can deliver to our society.

title: Monetary Policy in the Time of COVID
sentence_text: Despite today's challenges, the economy is on a path to just such a labor market, with high levels of employment and participation, broadly shared wage gains, and inflation running close to our price stability goal.
