title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Thank you, Gigi and Scott, and thanks to everyone for your work in bringing us together today, particularly the Economic Education Group.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Congratulations on the launch of Economic Education Month as well.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: We're very proud of this initiative and looking forward to what you have in store for us in October.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: It's a pleasure to be here, albeit in a very different format than we're used to.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The downside is that we don't get to connect in quite the same way as we do in person.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The upside is that we're able to include a lot more people.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: And wear much more comfortable clothes.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Before I turn to your questions, I want to say a few words to recognize the incredibly powerful work you all do as teachers.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: It would be important to mention this in any year, but especially now, in the 17th month of our upended reality.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: At the Fed, we take the value and responsibility of public service pretty seriously, and there really is no greater contribution to the common good than teaching.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The pandemic has been tough on everyone, but it has asked more of some than others.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Making it through this time has been no small feat for anyone, but teachers deserve distinct praise and appreciation.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Educators have had to restructure their teaching, adapt to new platforms, and help their students make their way through added stresses and pitfalls.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: That must have been especially tough without the day-to-day interactions that help you connect.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: It is clear that so many teachers have gone above and beyond the call of duty to remain a consistent, reliable resource for their students.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Parents deserve a shout-out as well for their part in helping reconstruct something as enormous and consequential as our entire education system.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: And students have also shown remarkable courage and resilience.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: For all of us, daily life has been disrupted, milestones like birthdays and graduations have been missed, and a once-in-a-lifetime crisis has cast a shadow of insecurity and uncertainty.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: But to take on that burden as a formative experience is extraordinary.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: You should all feel proud.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Finding the bright side to the past 17 months is not easy, but the crisis has given us a unique opportunity to see the big picture and consider our place in it.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: This is a historical inflection point, and this generation of students is in a position to turn its lessons into profound tools of change.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: And I hope some of you will use those tools in public service.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The students here today are the policymakers and legislators of the future.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Your teachers are the ones with the daunting task of preparing you for that future.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: You will see the world differently than your predecessors.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: You have been forced, sooner than most people, to consider what in life is truly important.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: You have seen a world upended, but you have also seen a world that is rapidly changing—sometimes more in one week than some of us have experienced over the course of decades.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: I hope this will cause you to think about how you want to make your mark, knowing that things do change, and sometimes they change quickly.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: This is an extraordinary time, and I believe that it will result in an extraordinary generation.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: As long as we continue to have extraordinary educators to guide them there.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Education is the foundation of our economy, indeed, of our society.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Teachers have always been tasked with nurturing and overseeing our most valuable national resource.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: It is the highest call within the higher calling of public service.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: I want to thank all of the teachers—those here today and the rest across the country—as well as the parents and students who have come together to make it through the past year and a half.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: It is a pleasure to be with you today.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Together, over the past year, we have been making our way through a very difficult time.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: We are not out of the woods yet, but I am glad to say that we are now making real progress.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: While some countries are still suffering terribly in the grip of COVID-19, the economic outlook here in the United States has clearly brightened.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Fiscal and monetary policy are providing strong support.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: The economy is reopening, bringing stronger economic activity and job creation.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: That is the high-level perspective—let's call it the 30,000 foot view—and from that vantage point, we see improvement.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: But we should also take a look at what is happening at street level.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Lives and livelihoods have been affected in ways that vary from person to person, family to family, and community to community.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: The economic downturn has not fallen evenly on all Americans, and those least able to bear the burden have been the hardest hit.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: The pain is all the greater in light of the gains we had seen in the years prior to the pandemic.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: COVID swept in as the United States was experiencing the longest expansion on record.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Unemployment was at 50-year lows, and inflation remained under control.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Wages were moving up, particularly for the lowest-paid workers.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Long-standing racial disparities in unemployment were narrowing, and many who had struggled for years were finding jobs.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: It was not until the later years of that expansion that its benefits had started to reach those on the margins.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: During ourFed Listensevents, we met with people around the country and heard repeatedly about the life-changing gains of the strong labor market, particularly at the lower end of the income spectrum.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Just a few months later, those stories changed to ones of job losses, overextended support services, and businesses built over generations closing their doors for good.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: While the recovery is gathering strength, it has been slower for those in lower-paid jobs: Almost 20 percent of workers who were in the lowest earnings quartile in February of 2020 were not employed a year later, compared to 6 percent for workers in the highest quartile.1

title: Community Development
sentence_text: The Fed's latest Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking—or SHED report—which will be published later this month, will show that, for prime-age adults without a bachelor's degree, 20 percent saw layoffs in 2020 versus 12 percent for college-educated workers.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: And more than 20 percent of Black and Hispanic prime-age workers were laid off compared to 14 percent of white workers over the same period.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Small businesses have also faced immense difficulties.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Fed research found that 80 percent of those surveyed reported a decline in revenue, with two-thirds of those businesses experiencing losses of at least 25 percent.2A recent Federal Reserve special report looked specifically at the impact on businesses owned by people of color, who reported greater challenges.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: For example, 67 percent of both Asian- and Black-owned firms and 63 percent of Hispanic-owned firms had to reduce their operations compared to 54 percent for their white counterparts.3

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Our upcoming SHED report notes that 22 percent of parents were either not working or working less because of disruptions to childcare or in-person schooling.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Black and Hispanic mothers—36 percent and 30 percent, respectively—were disproportionately affected.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: In a similar vein, labor force participation declined around 4 percentage points for Black and Hispanic women compared to 1.6 percentage points for white women and about 2 percentage points for men overall.4The Fed is focused on these long-standing disparities because they weigh on the productive capacity of our economy.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: We will only reach our full potential when everyone can contribute to, and share in, the benefits of prosperity.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Achieving broadly shared prosperity will take action from across society, from fiscal and other government policy to private-sector initiatives to the work everyone here does.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: The Fed can contribute as well.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Using our monetary policy tools, the Fed promotes maximum employment and price stability—two foundations of a strong, stable economy that can improve economic outcomes for all Americans.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: We view maximum employment as a broad and inclusive goal.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Those who have historically been left behind stand the best chance of prospering in a strong economy with plentiful job opportunities.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Our recent history highlights both the benefits of a strong economy and the severe costs of a weak one.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Supervisory tools also have a role to play.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: As part of our policy responsibilities, the Board of Governors enforces both the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, the federal fair lending laws that prohibit discrimination in lending.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Violations of the fair lending laws, along with other illegal credit practices, are taken into account during bank evaluations under the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA).

title: Community Development
sentence_text: We see our robust supervisory approach as critical to addressing racial discrimination, which can limit consumers' ability to improve their economic circumstances, including through access to homeownership and education.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: The Fed's community development function plays a role as well, studying what works, convening stakeholders on both the national and District level, and helping financial institutions find opportunities to invest and expand credit opportunities in low- and moderate-income communities.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: The economic landscape has changed, and efforts to provide access and credit to communities must change with it.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Last year, the Fed issued a proposal for a strengthened, modernized CRA framework, with the objective of building broad support among both external stakeholders and participating agencies.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Our goal is to strengthen the core purpose of meeting the credit needs of low- and moderate-income communities.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: We especially appreciated NCRC's feedback on the proposal.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: We will continue to do our part, and we appreciate the ways our work and that of NCRC members have intersected.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Last April, for instance, the Fed expanded the Paycheck Protection Program Liquidity Facility in order to broaden its reach to include some nondepository lenders.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: That included CDFI (community development financial institution) loan funds, which many of the people here represent.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: Your work provided small businesses with invaluable technical assistance to help them weather the downturn, and you have helped them get the funds they need to support their businesses.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: NCRC member groups have contributed in so many ways.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: You helped workers who lost their jobs get retrained.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: You helped homeowners struggling with payments and connected renters to federal assistance programs.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: You brought more people into the banking system, helped strengthen financial literacy and capabilities, and worked to address digital divides in areas of need—particularly in rural communities—at a time when connectivity is essential.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: I would like to close by saying thank you.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: You have been working hard through this crisis, and an enormous amount of work still lies ahead.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: But what you do is essential.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: You provide an invaluable service: You make people's lives better.

title: Community Development
sentence_text: There is no higher calling.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: I would like to thank Sir Jon Cunliffe and the Committee on Payments and Market Infrastructures (CPMI) for inviting me to close out the first day of this conference on pushing the frontiers of payments.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: Last year, the Group of Twenty (G-20) asked the Financial Stability Board (FSB) to coordinate the development of a roadmap on how the global community could enhance cross-border payments.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: It has long been acknowledged that the existing system, while safe and dependable, suffers from frictions, including processes that make it difficult to comply with anti-money-laundering and countering-terrorist-financing requirements, difficulty in managing payments across time zones, and, in certain areas, a reliance on outdated technology.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: Moreover, these frictions contribute to higher costs for cross-border transactions.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: As with many aspects of life these days, the COVID-19 pandemic has shined a light on the less efficient areas of our current payment system and accelerated the desire for improvement and digitalization.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: Even before the pandemic, advancements in the private sector served as a catalyst to get the attention of consumers and to prompt more engagement by the public sector.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: The goal of the FSB roadmap is simple—to create an ecosystem for cross-border payments that is faster, cheaper, more transparent, and more inclusive.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: A year into the process, I am encouraged that we are making meaningful progress.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: The stage 3 report released in October laid out a practical set of steps for moving ahead on the 19 building blocks that will bring about an improved system.1

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: Indeed, the themes discussed in the four sessions of the conference today correspond well to approaches described in the building blocks.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: The title of the first panel sets up a choice between "improving existing rails or laying new tracks."

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: As the roadmap makes clear, one of the keys to moving forward will be doing both—improving the existing system where we can while also evaluating the potential of and the best uses for emerging technologies.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: As an example, the Federal Reserve is working to improve the current system through the introduction of instant or fast payments via the FedNow Service.2The service will be designed to maintain uninterrupted processing—24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year—with security features that will ensure payment integrity and data security.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: The target launch date is sometime in 2023.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: The Federal Reserve is also doing its part to examine the role of new technologies.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: Experiments with central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) are being conducted at the Board of Governors, as well as complementary efforts by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston in collaboration with researchers at MIT.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: In addition, a recent report from the Bank for International Settlements and a group of seven central banks, which includes the Fed, assessed the feasibility of CBDCs in helping central banks deliver their public policy objectives.3Relevant to today's topic, one of the three key principles highlighted in the report is that a CBDC needs to coexist with cash and other types of money in a flexible and innovative payment system.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: Improvements in the global payments system will come not just from the public sector, but from the private sector as well.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: As today's second panel, "Of Lions and Unicorns," described, the private sector has the experience and expertise to develop consumer-facing infrastructure that improves and simplifies how the public engages with the financial system.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: Digitalization of financial services, combined with an improved consumer experience, can help increase financial inclusion, particularly in countries or areas with a large unbanked population.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: And the last two panels of the day, "Addressing Legal Barriers to Cross-Border Payments" and "Harmonised Data to Oil the Cross-Border Payments Machinery," highlight that improving the system must be a collaborative effort.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: By definition, cross-border payments involve multiple jurisdictions.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: So it will only be through countries working together, via all of the international forums—the Group of Seven, the G-20, the CPMI, the FSB, and others—that solutions will be possible.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: And, finally, it is only by engaging all stakeholders—policymakers, private-sector participants, and academia—as this conference is doing, that we will achieve the improved payments ecosystem we are striving toward.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: The COVID crisis has brought into even sharper focus the need to address the limitations of our current arrangements for cross-border payments.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: And as this conference amply demonstrates, despite the challenges of this last year, we still have been able to make important progress.

title: Closing Remarks
sentence_text: I again thank the CPMI and Jon Cunliffe for their leadership and look forward to working together as we improve these payments for businesses and individuals alike.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Today I will discuss the state of our labor market, from the recent past to the present and then over the longer term.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: A strong labor market that is sustained for an extended period can deliver substantial economic and social benefits, including higher employment and income levels, improved and expanded job opportunities, narrower economic disparities, and healing of the entrenched damage inflicted by past recessions on individuals' economic and personal well-being.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: At present, we are a long way from such a labor market.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Fully realizing the benefits of a strong labor market will take continued support from both near-term policy and longer-run investments so that all those seeking jobs have the skills and opportunities that will enable them to contribute to, and share in, the benefits of prosperity.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The Labor Market of a Year AgoWe need only look to February of last year to see how beneficial a strong labor market can be.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The overall unemployment rate was 3.5 percent, the lowest level in a half-century.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The unemployment rate for African Americans had also reached historical lows (figure 1).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Prime-age labor force participation was the highest in over a decade, and a high proportion of households saw jobs as "plentiful.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: "1Overall wage growth was moderate, but wages were rising more rapidly for earners on the lower end of the scale.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: These encouraging statistics were reaffirmed and given voice by those we met and conferred with, including the community, labor, and business leaders; retirees; students; and others we met with during the 14Fed Listensevents we conducted in 2019.2

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Many of these gains had emerged only in the later years of the expansion.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The labor force participation rate, for example, had been steadily declining from 2008 to 2015 even as the recovery from the Global Financial Crisis unfolded.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: In fact, in 2015, prime-age labor force participation—which I focus on because it is not significantly affected by the aging of the population—reached its lowest level in 30 years even as the unemployment rate declined to a relatively low 5 percent.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Also concerning was that much of the decline in participation up to that point had been concentrated in the population without a college degree (figure 2).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: At the time, many forecasters worried that globalization and technological change might have permanently reduced job opportunities for these individuals, and that, as a result, there might be limited scope for participation to recover.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Fortunately, the participation rate after 2015 consistently outperformed expectations, and by the beginning of 2020, the prime-age participation rate had fully reversed its decline from the 2008-to-2015 period.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Moreover, gains in participation were concentrated among people without a college degree.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Given that U.S. labor force participation has lagged relative to other advanced economy nations, this progress was especially welcome (figure 3).3

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: As I mentioned, we also saw faster wage growth for low earners once the labor market had strengthened sufficiently.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Nearly six years into the recovery, wage growth for the lowest earning quartile had been persistently modest and well below the pace enjoyed by other workers.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: At the tipping point of 2015, however, as the labor market continued to strengthen, the trend reversed, with wage growth for the lowest quartile consistently and significantly exceeding that of other workers (figure 4).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: At the end of 2015, the Black unemployment rate was still quite elevated, at 9 percent, despite the relatively low overall unemployment rate.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: But that disparity too began to shrink; as the expansion continued beyond 2015, Black unemployment reached a historic low of 5.2 percent, and the gap between Black and white unemployment rates was the narrowest since 1972, when data on unemployment by race started to be collected.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Black unemployment has tended to rise more than overall unemployment in recessions but also to fall more quickly in expansions.4Over the course of a long expansion, these persistent disparities can decline significantly, but, without policies to address their underlying causes, they may increase again when the economy ultimately turns down.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: These late-breaking improvements in the labor market did not result in unwanted upward pressures on inflation, as might have been expected; in fact, inflation did not even rise to 2 percent on a sustained basis.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: There was every reason to expect that the labor market could have strengthened even further without causing a worrisome increase in inflation were it not for the onset of the pandemic.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The Labor Market TodayThe state of our labor market today could hardly be more different.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Despite the surprising speed of recovery early on, we are still very far from a strong labor market whose benefits are broadly shared.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Employment in January of this year was nearly 10 million below its February 2020 level, a greater shortfall than the worst of the Great Recession's aftermath (figure 5).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: After rising to 14.8 percent in April of last year, the published unemployment rate has fallen relatively swiftly, reaching 6.3 percent in January.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: But published unemployment rates during COVID have dramatically understated the deterioration in the labor market.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Most importantly, the pandemic has led to the largest 12-month decline in labor force participation since at least 1948.5Fear of the virus and the disappearance of employment opportunities in the sectors most affected by it, such as restaurants, hotels, and entertainment venues, have led many to withdraw from the workforce.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: At the same time, virtual schooling has forced many parents to leave the work force to provide all-day care for their children.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: All told, nearly 5 million people say the pandemic prevented them from looking for work in January.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: In addition, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that many unemployed individuals have been misclassified as employed.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Correcting this misclassification and counting those who have left the labor force since last February as unemployed would boost the unemployment rate to close to 10 percent in January (figure 6).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Unfortunately, even those grim statistics understate the decline in labor market conditions for the most economically vulnerable Americans.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Aggregate employment has declined 6.5 percent since last February, but the decline in employment for workers in the top quartile of the wage distribution has been only 4 percent, while the decline for the bottom quartile has been a staggering 17 percent (figure 7).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Moreover, employment for these workers has changed little in recent months, while employment for the higher-wage groups has continued to improve.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Similarly, the unemployment rates for Blacks and Hispanics have risen significantly more than for whites since February 2020 (figure 8).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: As a result, economic disparities that were already too wide have widened further.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: In the past few months, improvement in labor market conditions stalled as the rate of infections sharply increased.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: In particular, jobs in the leisure and hospitality sector dropped over 1/2 million in December and a further 61,000 in January.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The recovery continues to depend on controlling the spread of the virus, which will require mass vaccinations in addition to continued vigilance in social distancing and mask wearing in the meantime.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Since the onset of the pandemic, we have been concerned about its longer-term effects on the labor market.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Extended periods of unemployment can inflict persistent damage on lives and livelihoods while also eroding the productive capacity of the economy.6And we know from the previous expansion that it can take many years to reverse the damage.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: At the start of the pandemic, the increase in unemployment was almost entirely due to temporary job losses.7Temporarily laid-off workers tend to return to work much more quickly, on average, than those whose ties to their former employers are permanently severed.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: But as some sectors of the economy have continued to struggle, permanent job loss has increased (figure 9).

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: So too has long-term unemployment.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Still, as of January, the level of permanent job loss, as a fraction of the labor force, was considerably smaller than during the Great Recession.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Research shows that the Paycheck Protection Program has played an important role in limiting permanent layoffs and preserving small businesses.8The renewal of the program this year in the face of another surge in COVID-related job cuts is an encouraging development.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Of course, in a healthy market-based economy, perpetual churn will always render some jobs obsolete as they are replaced by new employment opportunities.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Over time, workers and capital move from firm to firm and from sector to sector.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: It is likely that the pandemic has both increased the need for such movements and brought forward some movement that would have occurred eventually.9

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Getting Back to a Strong Labor MarketSo how do we get from where we are today back to a strong labor market that benefits all Americans and that starts to heal the damage already done?

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: And what can we do to sustain those benefits over time?

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Experience tells us that getting to and staying at full employment will not be easy.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: In the near term, policies that bring the pandemic to an end as soon as possible are paramount.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: In addition, workers and households who struggle to find their place in the post-pandemic economy are likely to need continued support.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The same is true for many small businesses that are likely to prosper again once the pandemic is behind us.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Also important is a patiently accommodative monetary policy stance that embraces the lessons of the past—about the labor market in particular and the economy more generally.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: I described several of those important lessons, as well as our new policy framework, at the Jackson Hole conference last year.10I have already mentioned the broad-based benefits that a strong labor market can deliver and noted that many of these benefits only arose toward the end of the previous expansion.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: I also noted that these benefits were achieved with low inflation.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Indeed, inflation has been much lower and more stable over the past three decades than in earlier times.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: In addition, we have seen that the longer-run potential growth rate of the economy appears to be lower than it once was, in part because of population aging, and that the neutral rate of interest—or the rate consistent with the economy being at full employment with 2 percent inflation—is also much lower than before.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: A low neutral rate means that our policy rate will be constrained more often by the effective lower bound.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: That circumstance can lead to worse economic outcomes—particularly for the most economically vulnerable Americans.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: To take these economic developments into account, we made substantial revisions to our monetary policy framework, as described in the FOMC's Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy.11This revised statement shares many features with its predecessor, including our view that longer-run inflation of 2 percent is most consistent with our mandate to promote maximum employment and price stability.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: But it also has some innovations.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The revised statement emphasizes that maximum employment is a broad and inclusive goal.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: This change reflects our appreciation for the benefits of a strong labor market, particularly for many in low- and moderate-income communities.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Recognizing the economy's ability to sustain a robust job market without causing an unwanted increase in inflation, the statement says that our policy decisions will be informed by our "assessments of theshortfallsof employment from its maximum level" rather than by "deviationsfrom its maximum level.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: "12This means that we will not tighten monetary policy solely in response to a strong labor market.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Finally, to counter the adverse economic dynamics that could ensue from declines in inflation expectations in an environment where our main policy tool is more frequently constrained, we now explicitly seek to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: This means that following periods when inflation has been running persistently below 2 percent, appropriate monetary policy will likely aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time in the service of keeping inflation expectations well anchored at our 2 percent longer-run goal.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Our January postmeeting statement on monetary policy implements this new framework.13In particular, we expect that it will be appropriate to maintain the current accommodative target range of the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: In addition, we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities and agency mortgage-backed securities by $80 billion and $40 billion per month, respectively, until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The Broad Responsibility for Achieving Maximum EmploymentSeventy-five years ago, in the wake of WWII, the United States faced the challenge of reemploying millions amid a major restructuring of the economy toward peacetime ends.14Part of Congress's response was the Employment Act of 1946, which states that "it is the continuing policy and responsibility of the federal government to use all practicable means .

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: "15As later amended in the Humphrey-Hawkins Act, this provision formed the basis of the employment side of the Fed's dual mandate.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: My colleagues and I are strongly committed to doing all we can to promote this employment goal.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Given the number of people who have lost their jobs and the likelihood that some will struggle to find work in the post-pandemic economy, achieving and sustaining maximum employment will require more than supportive monetary policy.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: It will require a society-wide commitment, with contributions from across government and the private sector.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: The potential benefits of investing in our nation's workforce are immense.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: Steady employment provides more than a regular paycheck.

title: Getting Back to a Strong Labor Market
sentence_text: It also bestows a sense of purpose, improves mental health, increases lifespans, and benefits workers and their families.16I am confident that with our collective efforts across the government and the private sector, our nation will make sustained progress toward our national goal of maximum employment.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Today I will offer a progress report on the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) efforts to restore price stability to the U.S. economy for the benefit of the American people.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: The report must begin by acknowledging the reality that inflation remains far too high.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation is imposing significant hardship, straining budgets and shrinking what paychecks will buy.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: This is especially painful for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve and serves as the bedrock of our economy.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: We currently estimate that 12-month personal consumption expenditures (PCE) inflation through October ran at 6.0 percent (figure 1).1While October inflation data received so far showed a welcome surprise to the downside, these are a single month's data, which followed upside surprises over the previous two months.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: As figure 1 makes clear, down months in the data have often been followed by renewed increases.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: It will take substantially more evidence to give comfort that inflation is actually declining.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: By any standard, inflation remains much too high.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: For purposes of this discussion, I will focus my comments on core PCE inflation, which omits the food and energy inflation components, which have been lower recently but are quite volatile.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Our inflation goal is for total inflation, of course, as food and energy prices matter a great deal for household budgets.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: But core inflation often gives a more accurate indicator of where overall inflation is headed.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Twelve-month core PCE inflation stands at 5.0 percent in our October estimate, approximately where it stood last December when policy tightening was in its early stages.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Over 2022, core inflation rose a few tenths above 5 percent and fell a few tenths below, but it mainly moved sideways.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: So when will inflation come down?

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: I could answer this question by pointing to the inflation forecasts of private-sector forecasters or of FOMC participants, which broadly show a significant decline over the next year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: But forecasts have been predicting just such a decline for more than a year, while inflation has moved stubbornly sideways.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: The truth is that the path ahead for inflation remains highly uncertain.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: For now, let's put aside the forecasts and look instead to the macroeconomic conditions we think we need to see to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: For starters, we need to raise interest rates to a level that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: There is considerable uncertainty about what rate will be sufficient, although there is no doubt that we have made substantial progress, raising our target range for the federal funds rate by 3.75 percentage points since March.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: As our last postmeeting statement indicates, we anticipate that ongoing increases will be appropriate.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: It seems to me likely that the ultimate level of rates will need to be somewhat higher than thought at the time of the September meeting and Summary of Economic Projections.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: I will return to policy at the end of my comments, but for now, I will simply say that we have more ground to cover.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: We are tightening the stance of policy in order to slow growth in aggregate demand.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Slowing demand growth should allow supply to catch up with demand and restore the balance that will yield stable prices over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Restoring that balance is likely to require a sustained period of below-trend growth.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Last year, the ongoing reopening of the economy boosted real gross domestic product (GDP) growth to a very strong 5.7 percent.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: This year, GDP was roughly flat through the first three quarters, and indicators point to modest growth this quarter, which seems likely to bring the year in with very modest growth overall.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Several factors contributed to this slowing growth, including the waning effects of reopening and of pandemic fiscal support, the global implications of Russia's war against Ukraine, and our policy actions, which tightened financial conditions and are affecting economic activity, particularly in interest-sensitive sectors such as housing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: We can say that demand growth has slowed, and we expect that this growth will need to remain at a slower pace for a sustained period.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Despite the tighter policy and slower growth over the past year, we have not seen clear progress on slowing inflation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: To assess what it will take to get inflation down, it is useful to break core inflation into three component categories: core goods inflation, housing services inflation, and inflation in core services other than housing (figure 2).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Core goods inflation has moved down from very high levels over the course of 2022, while housing services inflation has risen rapidly.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Inflation in core services ex housing has fluctuated but shown no clear trend.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: I will discuss each of these items in turn.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Early in the pandemic, goods prices began rising rapidly, as abnormally strong demand was met by pandemic-hampered supply.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Reports from businesses and many indicators suggest that supply chain issues are now easing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Both fuel and nonfuel import prices have fallen in recent months, and indicators of prices paid by manufacturers have moved down.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: While 12-month core goods inflation remains elevated at 4.6 percent, it has fallen nearly 3 percentage points from earlier in the year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: It is far too early to declare goods inflation vanquished, but if current trends continue, goods prices should begin to exert downward pressure on overall inflation in coming months.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Housing services inflation measures the rise in the price of all rents and the rise in the rental-equivalent cost of owner-occupied housing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Unlike goods inflation, housing services inflation has continued to rise and now stands at 7.1 percent over the past 12 months.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Housing inflation tends to lag other prices around inflation turning points, however, because of the slow rate at which the stock of rental leases turns over.2The market rate on new leases is a timelier indicator of where overall housing inflation will go over the next year or so.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Measures of 12-month inflation in new leases rose to nearly 20 percent during the pandemic but have been falling sharply since about midyear (figure 3).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: As figure 3 shows, however, overall housing services inflation has continued to rise as existing leases turn over and jump in price to catch up with the higher level of rents for new leases.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: This is likely to continue well into next year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: But as long as new lease inflation keeps falling, we would expect housing services inflation to begin falling sometime next year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Indeed, a decline in this inflation underlies most forecasts of declining inflation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Finally, we come to core services other than housing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: This spending category covers a wide range of services from health care and education to haircuts and hospitality.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: This is the largest of our three categories, constituting more than half of the core PCE index.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Thus, this may be the most important category for understanding the future evolution of core inflation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Because wages make up the largest cost in delivering these services, the labor market holds the key to understanding inflation in this category.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: In the labor market, demand for workers far exceeds the supply of available workers, and nominal wages have been growing at a pace well above what would be consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.3Thus, another condition we are looking for is the restoration of balance between supply and demand in the labor market.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Signs of elevated labor market tightness emerged suddenly in mid-2021.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: The unemployment rate at the time was much higher than the 3.5 percent that had prevailed without major signs of tightness before the pandemic.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Employment was still millions below its level on the eve of the pandemic.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Looking back, we can see that a significant and persistent labor supply shortfall opened up during the pandemic—a shortfall that appears unlikely to fully close anytime soon.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Comparing the current labor force with the Congressional Budget Office's pre-pandemic forecast of labor force growth reveals a current labor force shortfall of roughly 3-1/2 million people (figure 4, left panel).4This shortfall reflects both lower-than-expected population growth and a lower labor force participation rate (figure 4, right panel).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Participation dropped sharply at the onset of the pandemic because of many factors, including sickness, caregiving, and fear of infection.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Many forecasters expected that participation would move back up fairly quickly as the pandemic faded.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: And for workers in their prime working years, it mostly has.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Overall participation, however, remains well below pre-pandemic trends.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Some of the participation gap reflects workers who are still out of the labor force because they are sick with COVID-19 or continue to suffer lingering symptoms from previous COVID infections ("long COVID").5But recent research by Fed economists finds that the participation gap is now mostly due to excess retirements—that is, retirements in excess of what would have been expected from population aging alone.6These excess retirements might now account for more than 2 million of the 3‑1/2 million shortfall in the labor force.7

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: What explains these excess retirements?

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Health issues have surely played a role, as COVID has posed a particularly large threat to the lives and health of the elderly.8In addition, many older workers lost their jobs in the early stages of the pandemic, when layoffs were historically high.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: The cost of finding new employment may have appeared particularly large for these workers, given pandemic-related disruptions to the work environment and health concerns.9Also, gains in the stock market and rising house prices in the first two years of the pandemic contributed to an increase in wealth that likely facilitated early retirement for some people.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: The data so far do not suggest that excess retirements are likely to unwind because of retirees returning to the labor force.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Older workers are still retiring at higher rates, and retirees do not appear to be returning to the labor force in sufficient numbers to meaningfully reduce the total number of excess retirees.10

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: The second factor contributing to the labor supply shortfall is slower growth in the working-age population.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: The combination of a plunge in net immigration and a surge in deaths during the pandemic probably accounts for about 1-1/2 million missing workers.11

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Policies to support labor supply are not the domain of the Fed: Our tools work principally on demand.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Without advocating any particular policy, however, I will say that policies to support labor force participation could, over time, bring benefits to the workers who join the labor force and support overall economic growth.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Such policies would take time to implement and have their effects, however.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: For the near term, a moderation of labor demand growth will be required to restore balance to the labor market.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Currently, the unemployment rate is at 3.7 percent, near 50-year lows, and job openings exceed available workers by about 4 million—that is about 1.7 job openings for every person looking for work (figure 5).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: So far, we have seen only tentative signs of moderation of labor demand.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: With slower GDP growth this year, job gains have stepped down from more than 450,000 per month over the first seven months of the year to about 290,000 per month over the past three months.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: But this job growth remains far in excess of the pace needed to accommodate population growth over time—about 100,000 per month by many estimates.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Job openings have fallen by about 1.5 million this year but remain higher than at any time before the pandemic.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Wage growth, too, shows only tentative signs of returning to balance.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Some measures of wage growth have ticked down recently (figure 6).

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: But the declines are very modest so far relative to earlier increases and still leave wage growth well above levels consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: To be clear, strong wage growth is a good thing.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: But for wage growth to be sustainable, it needs to be consistent with 2 percent inflation.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Let's sum up this review of economic conditions that we think we need to see to bring inflation down to 2 percent.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Growth in economic activity has slowed to well below its longer-run trend, and this needs to be sustained.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Bottlenecks in goods production are easing and goods price inflation appears to be easing as well, and this, too, must continue.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Housing services inflation will probably keep rising well into next year, but if inflation on new leases continues to fall, we will likely see housing services inflation begin to fall later next year.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Finally, the labor market, which is especially important for inflation in core services ex housing, shows only tentative signs of rebalancing, and wage growth remains well above levels that would be consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Despite some promising developments, we have a long way to go in restoring price stability.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Returning to monetary policy, my FOMC colleagues and I are strongly committed to restoring price stability.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: After our November meeting, we noted that we anticipated that ongoing rate increases will be appropriate in order to attain a policy stance that is sufficiently restrictive to move inflation down to 2 percent over time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Monetary policy affects the economy and inflation with uncertain lags, and the full effects of our rapid tightening so far are yet to be felt.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Thus, it makes sense to moderate the pace of our rate increases as we approach the level of restraint that will be sufficient to bring inflation down.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: The time for moderating the pace of rate increases may come as soon as the December meeting.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: Given our progress in tightening policy, the timing of that moderation is far less significant than the questions of how much further we will need to raise rates to control inflation, and the length of time it will be necessary to hold policy at a restrictive level.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: It is likely that restoring price stability will require holding policy at a restrictive level for some time.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: History cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy.

title: Inflation and the Labor Market
sentence_text: We will stay the course until the job is done.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Good morning, and welcome to the 10th annual Community Banking Research Conference.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: I have attended this conference twice before, including the first one back in 2013, and I can attest to the quality of the research and discussions.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: While I am coming to you virtually today, many of you are gathering in person for the first time in three years.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: I am sure it will make an excellent event even more enjoyable.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The Community Banking Research Conference brings together researchers, regulators, policymakers, and community bankers to discuss the unique and important role community banks play in our economy.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The conference was launched in the years following the financial crisis, in a collaboration by the Federal Reserve, the Conference of State Bank Supervisors (CSBS), and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC).

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The conference was developed to deepen our understanding of the community bank business model and to provide a forum to discuss research with academics, policymakers, regulators, and community bankers.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The research presented over the years has informed supervisory and regulatory policy debates and continues to challenge our thinking.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: It has highlighted the vital links between community banks and small businesses, the availability of credit in low- and moderate-income communities, how community banks support their local communities in times of crisis, and the impact of technology.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: A critical feature of the research sessions is that community bankers join academic moderators to provide feedback from a practitioner's perspective.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: The challenges facing community banks have changed significantly over the past 10 years.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Community banks have demonstrated remarkable resilience, and conferences like this have helped regulators and supervisors to better understand those changes.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: I want to congratulate the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis for a decade of hosting an important and informative conference.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: And I want to thank our colleagues at the Fed, the FDIC, and the Conference of State Bank Supervisors.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: On a sadder note, I want to recognize the passing of John Ryan, who was president of the CSBS, this past May.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: John's impact on the CSBS and his contributions to the financial services sector overall were significant, and he is missed by all who knew and worked with him.

title: Welcoming Remarks
sentence_text: Thanks also to the researchers and all the community banking professionals for their insight and contributions over the years.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: At past Jackson Hole conferences, I have discussed broad topics such as the ever-changing structure of the economy and the challenges of conducting monetary policy under high uncertainty.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Today, my remarks will be shorter, my focus narrower, and my message more direct.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) overarching focus right now is to bring inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve and serves as the bedrock of our economy.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The burdens of high inflation fall heaviest on those who are least able to bear them.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Restoring price stability will take some time and requires using our tools forcefully to bring demand and supply into better balance.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Reducing inflation is likely to require a sustained period of below-trend growth.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Moreover, there will very likely be some softening of labor market conditions.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: While higher interest rates, slower growth, and softer labor market conditions will bring down inflation, they will also bring some pain to households and businesses.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: These are the unfortunate costs of reducing inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: But a failure to restore price stability would mean far greater pain.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The U.S. economy is clearly slowing from the historically high growth rates of 2021, which reflected the reopening of the economy following the pandemic recession.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: While the latest economic data have been mixed, in my view our economy continues to show strong underlying momentum.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The labor market is particularly strong, but it is clearly out of balance, with demand for workers substantially exceeding the supply of available workers.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Inflation is running well above 2 percent, and high inflation has continued to spread through the economy.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: While the lower inflation readings for July are welcome, a single month's improvement falls far short of what the Committee will need to see before we are confident that inflation is moving down.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: We are moving our policy stance purposefully to a level that will be sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: At our most recent meeting in July, the FOMC raised the target range for the federal funds rate to 2.25 to 2.5 percent, which is in the Summary of Economic Projection's (SEP) range of estimates of where the federal funds rate is projected to settle in the longer run.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: In current circumstances, with inflation running far above 2 percent and the labor market extremely tight, estimates of longer-run neutral are not a place to stop or pause.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: July's increase in the target range was the second 75 basis point increase in as many meetings, and I said then that another unusually large increase could be appropriate at our next meeting.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: We are now about halfway through the intermeeting period.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Our decision at the September meeting will depend on the totality of the incoming data and the evolving outlook.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: At some point, as the stance of monetary policy tightens further, it likely will become appropriate to slow the pace of increases.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Restoring price stability will likely require maintaining a restrictive policy stance for some time.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The historical record cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Committee participants' most recent individual projections from the June SEP showed the median federal funds rate running slightly below 4 percent through the end of 2023.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Participants will update their projections at the September meeting.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Our monetary policy deliberations and decisions build on what we have learned about inflation dynamics both from the high and volatile inflation of the 1970s and 1980s, and from the low and stable inflation of the past quarter-century.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: In particular, we are drawing on three important lessons.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The first lesson is that central bankscanandshouldtake responsibility for delivering low and stable inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: It may seem strange now that central bankers and others once needed convincing on these two fronts, but as former Chairman Ben Bernanke has shown, both propositions were widely questioned during the Great Inflation period.1Today, we regard these questions as settled.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Our responsibility to deliver price stability is unconditional.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: It is true that the current high inflation is a global phenomenon, and that many economies around the world face inflation as high or higher than seen here in the United States.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: It is also true, in my view, that the current high inflation in the United States is the product of strong demand and constrained supply, and that the Fed's tools work principally on aggregate demand.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: None of this diminishes the Federal Reserve's responsibility to carry out our assigned task of achieving price stability.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: There is clearly a job to do in moderating demand to better align with supply.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: We are committed to doing that job.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The second lesson is that the public's expectations about future inflation can play an important role in setting the path of inflation over time.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Today, by many measures, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: That is broadly true of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, and of market-based measures as well.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: But that is not grounds for complacency, with inflation having run well above our goal for some time.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: If the public expects that inflation will remain low and stable over time, then, absent major shocks, it likely will.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Unfortunately, the same is true of expectations of high and volatile inflation.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: During the 1970s, as inflation climbed, the anticipation of high inflation became entrenched in the economic decisionmaking of households and businesses.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The more inflation rose, the more people came to expect it to remain high, and they built that belief into wage and pricing decisions.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: As former Chairman Paul Volcker put it at the height of the Great Inflation in 1979, "Inflation feeds in part on itself, so part of the job of returning to a more stable and more productive economy must be to break the grip of inflationary expectations.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: One useful insight into how actual inflation may affect expectations about its future path is based in the concept of "rational inattention.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: "3When inflation is persistently high, households and businesses must pay close attention and incorporate inflation into their economic decisions.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: When inflation is low and stable, they are freer to focus their attention elsewhere.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Former Chairman Alan Greenspan put it this way: "For all practical purposes, price stability means that expected changes in the average price level are small enough and gradual enough that they do not materially enter business and household financial decisions.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Of course, inflation has just about everyone's attention right now, which highlights a particular risk today: The longer the current bout of high inflation continues, the greater the chance that expectations of higher inflation will become entrenched.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: That brings me to the third lesson, which is that we must keep at it until the job is done.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: History shows that the employment costs of bringing down inflation are likely to increase with delay, as high inflation becomes more entrenched in wage and price setting.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: The successful Volcker disinflation in the early 1980s followed multiple failed attempts to lower inflation over the previous 15 years.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: A lengthy period of very restrictive monetary policy was ultimately needed to stem the high inflation and start the process of getting inflation down to the low and stable levels that were the norm until the spring of last year.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: Our aim is to avoid that outcome by acting with resolve now.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: These lessons are guiding us as we use our tools to bring inflation down.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: We are taking forceful and rapid steps to moderate demand so that it comes into better alignment with supply, and to keep inflation expectations anchored.

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
sentence_text: We will keep at it until we are confident the job is done.
