title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Hello, everyone, and welcome to the 10th Annual U.S. Treasury Market Conference.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: "Tenth annual" is a phrase that generates a bit of surprise, and much pride.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It is surprising because it does not seem like the first of these gatherings, which I was honored to play a role in organizing, was all that long ago.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But we can also take pride because the conference has proven useful and important for a full decade, as I expect it will do for many more years to come.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Much has changed in the economy since we first gathered in 2015—but the importance of the U.S. Treasury market has not.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As you all know, this market is the deepest and most liquid in the world.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In addition to meeting the financing needs of the federal government, it plays a critical role in the implementation of monetary policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It is no exaggeration to say that the Treasury market is part of the bedrock of our economy and indeed of the world economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The October '14 flash crash and the subsequent publication of the Interagency Working Group report on that event are what brought us together for the first annual conference.1October 2014 was a wakeup call because there had never been such a large swing in Treasury prices in such a short period of time.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Interagency Working Group report shed light on how much the structure of the Treasury market had changed and how large a role high-speed, electronic trading firms were playing in it.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It also showed the value of cooperation and communication between the five agencies in the working group, something that proved again to be vital during the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I am pleased to see that all working group members are represented here today.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: You will be hearing directly from many senior leaders, including your host, President Williams; Vice Chair Barr; and Secretary Yellen, who, of course, was Fed chair at the time of the first conference.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It is essential that our Treasury markets are able to efficiently transform Treasury securities into cash, even at times of elevated stress.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As I noted at this event in 2015, "these markets need to keep functioning at a high level, and we all have a stake in making sure that they do."

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I remain wholly dedicated to that goal.2

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I wish you a productive and educational conference.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Note: On September 26, 2024, the text of the speech was updated to reflect the delivered remarks in the video version of this speech.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Four and a half years after COVID-19's arrival, the worst of the pandemic-related economic distortions are fading.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The labor market is no longer overheated, and conditions are now less tight than those that prevailed before the pandemic.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: And the balance of the risks to our two mandates has changed.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Our objective has been to restore price stability while maintaining a strong labor market, avoiding the sharp increases in unemployment that characterized earlier disinflationary episodes when inflation expectations were less well anchored.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: While the task is not complete, we have made a good deal of progress toward that outcome.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Today, I will begin by addressing the current economic situation and the path ahead for monetary policy.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: I will then turn to a discussion of economic events since the pandemic arrived, exploring why inflation rose to levels not seen in a generation, and why it has fallen so much while unemployment has remained low.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Near-Term Outlook for PolicyLet's begin with the current situation and the near-term outlook for policy.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: For much of the past three years, inflation ran well above our 2 percent goal, and labor market conditions were extremely tight.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) primary focus has been on bringing down inflation, and appropriately so.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Prior to this episode, most Americans alive today had not experienced the pain of high inflation for a sustained period.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Inflation brought substantial hardship, especially for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: High inflation triggered stress and a sense of unfairness that linger today.1

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Our restrictive monetary policy helped restore balance between aggregate supply and demand, easing inflationary pressures and ensuring that inflation expectations remained well anchored.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Inflation is now much closer to our objective, with prices having risen 2.5 percent over the past 12 months (figure 1).2After a pause earlier this year, progress toward our 2 percent objective has resumed.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: My confidence has grown that inflation is on a sustainable path back to 2 percent.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Turning to employment, in the years just prior to the pandemic, we saw the significant benefits to society that can come from a long period of strong labor market conditions: low unemployment, high participation, historically low racial employment gaps, and, with inflation low and stable, healthy real wage gains that were increasingly concentrated among those with lower incomes.3

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Today, the labor market has cooled considerably from its formerly overheated state.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The unemployment rate began to rise over a year ago and is now at 4.3 percent—still low by historical standards, but almost a full percentage point above its level in early 2023 (figure 2).

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Most of that increase has come over the past six months.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: So far, rising unemployment has not been the result of elevated layoffs, as is typically the case in an economic downturn.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Rather, the increase mainly reflects a substantial increase in the supply of workers and a slowdown from the previously frantic pace of hiring.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Even so, the cooling in labor market conditions is unmistakable.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Job gains remain solid but have slowed this year.4Job vacancies have fallen, and the ratio of vacancies to unemployment has returned to its pre-pandemic range.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The hiring and quits rates are now below the levels that prevailed in 2018 and 2019.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Nominal wage gains have moderated.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: All told, labor market conditions are now less tight than just before the pandemic in 2019—a year when inflation ran below 2 percent.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: It seems unlikely that the labor market will be a source of elevated inflationary pressures anytime soon.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: We do not seek or welcome further cooling in labor market conditions.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Overall, the economy continues to grow at a solid pace.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: But the inflation and labor market data show an evolving situation.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The upside risks to inflation have diminished.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: And the downside risks to employment have increased.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: As we highlighted in our last FOMC statement, we are attentive to the risks to both sides of our dual mandate.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The time has come for policy to adjust.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The direction of travel is clear, and the timing and pace of rate cuts will depend on incoming data, the evolving outlook, and the balance of risks.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: We will do everything we can to support a strong labor market as we make further progress toward price stability.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: With an appropriate dialing back of policy restraint, there is good reason to think that the economy will get back to 2 percent inflation while maintaining a strong labor market.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The current level of our policy rate gives us ample room to respond to any risks we may face, including the risk of unwelcome further weakening in labor market conditions.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The Rise and Fall of InflationLet's now turn to the questions of why inflation rose, and why it has fallen so significantly even as unemployment has remained low.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: There is a growing body of research on these questions, and this is a good time for this discussion.5It is, of course, too soon to make definitive assessments.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: This period will be analyzed and debated long after we are gone.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The arrival of the COVID-19 pandemic led quickly to shutdowns in economies around the world.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: It was a time of radical uncertainty and severe downside risks.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: As so often happens in times of crisis, Americans adapted and innovated.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Governments responded with extraordinary force, especially in the U.S. Congress unanimously passed the CARES Act.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: At the Fed, we used our powers to an unprecedented extent to stabilize the financial system and help stave off an economic depression.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: After a historically deep but brief recession, in mid-2020 the economy began to grow again.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: As the risks of a severe, extended downturn receded, and as the economy reopened, we faced the risk of replaying the painfully slow recovery that followed the Global Financial Crisis.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Congress delivered substantial additional fiscal support in late 2020 and again in early 2021.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Spending recovered strongly in the first half of 2021.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The ongoing pandemic shaped the pattern of the recovery.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Lingering concerns over COVID weighed on spending on in-person services.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: But pent-up demand, stimulative policies, pandemic changes in work and leisure practices, and the additional savings associated with constrained services spending all contributed to a historic surge in consumer spending on goods.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The pandemic also wreaked havoc on supply conditions.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Eight million people left the workforce at its onset, and the size of the labor force was still 4 million below its pre-pandemic level in early 2021.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The labor force would not return to its pre-pandemic trend until mid-2023 (figure 3).6Supply chains were snarled by a combination of lost workers, disrupted international trade linkages, and tectonic shifts in the composition and level of demand (figure 4).

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Clearly, this was nothing like the slow recovery after the Global Financial Crisis.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: After running below target through 2020, inflation spiked in March and April 2021.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The initial burst of inflation was concentrated rather than broad based, with extremely large price increases for goods in short supply, such as motor vehicles.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: My colleagues and I judged at the outset that these pandemic-related factors would not be persistent and, thus, that the sudden rise in inflation was likely to pass through fairly quickly without the need for a monetary policy response—in short, that the inflation would be transitory.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Standard thinking has long been that, as long as inflation expectations remain well anchored, it can be appropriate for central banks to look through a temporary rise in inflation.7

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The good ship Transitory was a crowded one, with most mainstream analysts and advanced-economy central bankers on board.8The common expectation was that supply conditions would improve reasonably quickly, that the rapid recovery in demand would run its course, and that demand would rotate back from goods to services, bringing inflation down.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: For a time, the data were consistent with the transitory hypothesis.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Monthly readings for core inflation declined every month from April to September 2021, although progress came slower than expected (figure 5).

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The case began to weaken around midyear, as was reflected in our communications.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Beginning in October, the data turned hard against the transitory hypothesis.9Inflation rose and broadened out from goods into services.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: It became clear that the high inflation was not transitory, and that it would require a strong policy response if inflation expectations were to remain well anchored.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: We recognized that and pivoted beginning in November.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Financial conditions began to tighten.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: After phasing out our asset purchases, we lifted off in March 2022.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: By early 2022, headline inflation exceeded 6 percent, with core inflation above 5 percent.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Russia's invasion of Ukraine led to a sharp increase in energy and commodity prices.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The improvements in supply conditions and rotation in demand from goods to services were taking much longer than expected, in part due to further COVID waves in the U.S.10And COVID continued to disrupt production globally, including through new and extended lockdowns in China.11

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: High rates of inflation were a global phenomenon, reflecting common experiences: rapid increases in the demand for goods, strained supply chains, tight labor markets, and sharp hikes in commodity prices.12The global nature of inflation was unlike any period since the 1970s.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Back then, high inflation became entrenched—an outcome we were utterly committed to avoiding.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: By mid-2022, the labor market was extremely tight, with employment increasing by over 6-1/2 million from the middle of 2021.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: This increase in labor demand was met, in part, by workers rejoining the labor force as health concerns began to fade.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: But labor supply remained constrained, and, in the summer of 2022, labor force participation remained well below pre-pandemic levels.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: There were nearly twice as many job openings as unemployed persons from March 2022 through the end of the year, signaling a severe labor shortage (figure 6).13Inflation peaked at 7.1 percent in June 2022.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: At this podium two years ago, I discussed the possibility that addressing inflation could bring some pain in the form of higher unemployment and slower growth.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Some argued that getting inflation under control would require a recession and a lengthy period of high unemployment.14I expressed our unconditional commitment to fully restoring price stability and to keeping at it until the job is done.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The FOMC did not flinch from carrying out our responsibilities, and our actions forcefully demonstrated our commitment to restoring price stability.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: We raised our policy rate by 425 basis points in 2022 and another 100 basis points in 2023.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: We have held our policy rate at its current restrictive level since July 2023 (figure 7).

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The summer of 2022 proved to be the peak of inflation.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The 4-1/2 percentage point decline in inflation from its peak two years ago has occurred in a context of low unemployment—a welcome and historically unusual result.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: How did inflation fall without a sharp rise in unemployment above its estimated natural rate?

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Pandemic-related distortions to supply and demand, as well as severe shocks to energy and commodity markets, were important drivers of high inflation, and their reversal has been a key part of the story of its decline.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The unwinding of these factors took much longer than expected but ultimately played a large role in the subsequent disinflation.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Our restrictive monetary policy contributed to a moderation in aggregate demand, which combined with improvements in aggregate supply to reduce inflationary pressures while allowing growth to continue at a healthy pace.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: As labor demand also moderated, the historically high level of vacancies relative to unemployment has normalized primarily through a decline in vacancies, without sizable and disruptive layoffs, bringing the labor market to a state where it is no longer a source of inflationary pressures.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: A word on the critical importance of inflation expectations.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Standard economic models have long reflected the view that inflation will return to its objective when product and labor markets are balanced—without the need for economic slack—so long as inflation expectations are anchored at our objective.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: That's what the models said, but the stability of longer-run inflation expectations since the 2000s had not been tested by a persistent burst of high inflation.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: It was far from assured that the inflation anchor would hold.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Concerns over de-anchoring contributed to the view that disinflation would require slack in the economy and specifically in the labor market.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: An important takeaway from recent experience is that anchored inflation expectations, reinforced by vigorous central bank actions, can facilitate disinflation without the need for slack.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: This narrative attributes much of the increase in inflation to an extraordinary collision between overheated and temporarily distorted demand and constrained supply.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: While researchers differ in their approaches and, to some extent, in their conclusions, a consensus seems to be emerging, which I see as attributing most of the rise in inflation to this collision.15All told, the healing from pandemic distortions, our efforts to moderate aggregate demand, and the anchoring of expectations have worked together to put inflation on what increasingly appears to be a sustainable path to our 2 percent objective.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Disinflation while preserving labor market strength is only possible with anchored inflation expectations, which reflect the public's confidence that the central bank will bring about 2 percent inflation over time.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: That confidence has been built over decades and reinforced by our actions.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: That is my assessment of events.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: ConclusionLet me wrap up by emphasizing that the pandemic economy has proved to be unlike any other, and that there remains much to be learned from this extraordinary period.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: Our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy emphasizes our commitment to reviewing our principles and making appropriate adjustments through a thorough public review every five years.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: As we begin this process later this year, we will be open to criticism and new ideas, while preserving the strengths of our framework.

title: Review and Outlook
sentence_text: The limits of our knowledge—so clearly evident during the pandemic—demand humility and a questioning spirit focused on learning lessons from the past and applying them flexibly to our current challenges.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Thank you, Dean Treanor, for the invitation to speak here today.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I am very sorry that circumstances prevent me from joining you in person.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I will start by acknowledging the parents, spouses, partners, other family members and mentors who are here.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Without your support, sacrifice, and encouragement, we would not have so much to celebrate today.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: And to the class of 2024—congratulations on earning your law degree.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: You are the most selective class in Georgetown history, chosen from 14,000 applicants, and the most well qualified as well.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Among you are Fulbright scholars, military veterans, Peace Corps, AmeriCorps and Teach for America alumni, student athletes, accomplished musicians and even a medical doctor.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: This is also the most diverse class in the 154-year history of the school.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I am especially proud today to say that there is a lot of Georgetown in my family tree.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: My father graduated from the College in 1943 before serving in the U.S. Army in World War II.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: After the war, he received his law degree here and practiced law in Washington, D.C.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I am fortunate to have two wonderful daughters; one graduated from the College in 2012; the other is a member of the Class of 2026 at the Law Center.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: It seems like yesterday that I was in your shoes, receiving my degree, looking forward with optimism and excitement, and wondering what lay ahead.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I cannot help but think fondly of my time here.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: For many years, friends from law school have gathered annually for a weekend to refresh our ties and laugh about times gone by.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: These gatherings are referred to as "Big Chill," a reference to a 1983 movie that revolved around a mid-life reunion of college friends.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I made lifelong friendships here that I keep to this day, and I hope it will be the same for you.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Along with all the hard work, I also remember the fun.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: A favorite tradition was to attend Saturday midnight showings ofThe Rocky Horror Picture Showat the Key Theater on Wisconsin Avenue in Georgetown.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Now, if you have led a culturally deprived life and are tragically unfamiliar with the movie, it is a raucous musical starring a young Tim Curry.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Everyone in the theater would sing along, shout out the lines, and throw popcorn at the screen; many would dress up like the characters.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Now, I didn't dress up—sorry to disappoint you—but no party was complete until all of us danced "The Time Warp" to the movie's famous song.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: As it happens, I still remember the steps, and I had intended to demonstrate the Time Warp for you, but that will not be possible today.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Instead, I will offer a few thoughts that I might have benefited from hearing when I was sitting in your chairs a mere 45 years ago.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Embracing ChangeThe years since my graduation have brought waves of fundamental change to the workplace and to society at large, much of it driven by technology.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Imagine a world with no internet, no email or texting, no personal computers or cell phones, no social media.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Some of you parents are no doubt thinking: I would be fine with that world!

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: The pace of change will likely continue to be very fast.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Be alert to the ways your working life may change.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Think about how you can be prepared for those changes and to turn them to your advantage, and to society's advantage.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: The practice of law has been transformed over the years; if you do choose the path of a practicing lawyer, I would think about what practicing law could look like in 10 or 20 years.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: In a world that will continue to evolve quickly and in unexpected ways, you will need to be agile.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Embracing change and taking risks can be an important part of your development as a professional and as a person.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Your formal education may end today, but you are not done learning.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Many of the important things you will need to know can only be learned through experience.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: And experience can be a hard but irreplaceable teacher.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: As an example, near the end of my second year here, it was time to select the next editor in chief of theGeorgetown Law Journal.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I thought that there were plenty of colleagues who were better qualified, but who simply did not want the job.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: So, with much trepidation, I put my name in.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I was secretly, but utterly, terrified that I might be chosen.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: And amazingly enough, I was.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: It turned out that, as I feared, I was not well prepared for that responsibility.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I had to keep people interested and motivated enough to work on theJournalwhen many things competed for their attention.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I had to have a plan for the organization and not just for myself.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I had to do this while exhibiting confidence that I did not feel.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: My main memory of that time is thinking, "This is harder and far different from what I had expected!"

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: What I now know is that almost no one is ready for their first leadership roles.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: When you step into a leadership role, it is very common to doubt yourself.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: If I could tell my younger self something, it would be to believe in yourself and put yourself in situations in which you will be seriously challenged to do new things.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Assume that you will make mistakes.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Learn from those mistakes; do not dwell excessively upon them in regret.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: The more you do that, the more you will learn and the faster you will develop as a person and as a leader.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Know also that, in my experience, there is no single model of a successful leader.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Each of you has it in you to lead successfully.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: No One PathOne of the great things about your legal education is it sets you up for success on a wide variety of potential paths.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I left the practice of law a few years after I left this school.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: But my legal education has benefited me all along the way.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Studying law teaches you to think clearly, analyze thoroughly, and understand all sides of an argument.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: The possibilities that lie ahead of you are extremely broad.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: You may work for a single law firm for your entire career.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Or you may leave the law fairly soon, as I did, and never look back.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: You will always benefit from what you learned here.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: The fact is, I do keep a copy of the Federal Reserve Act that I consult often.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Like many of you, I imagine, I knew that I wanted to do public service.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: As I left law school, I remember thinking about people like George Shultz and Cyrus Vance, prominent figures of the day who had successful private-sector careers and served periodically in government.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: The head of the investment bank in New York where I worked as a young man was Nicholas F. Brady, who had an extraordinary career in investment banking and had served as a U.S. senator from New Jersey as well.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I was the most junior of employees, but I wanted to introduce myself and tell him about my own aspirations.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: But approaching him was daunting.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Maybe he would decline to meet with me.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Maybe he would think I was not committed to the firm if I told him I was interested in public service.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I finally summoned the courage to present myself at his office.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I told him that I grew up in Washington, had been a federal law clerk and a congressional staffer, and wanted to do public service along the way.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I said that if you need someone to staff you on anything you do in Washington, I'm your guy.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: He said something along the lines of, "Great, thanks."

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I then crept back down the stairs to my broom closet of an office wondering whether that was going to matter.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: A few months later, I got a call from his secretary.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I can still hear her gravelly voice.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: "Can you come up and see Mr.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: When I got there, he said, "I need you to help me out with this thing."

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: This thing was defending an oil company from a hostile takeover attempt by a colorful corporate raider of that era named T. Boone Pickens.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I ended up spending months going back and forth from New York to Washington with Nick.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: A few years later, Nick Brady became the Treasury Secretary.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Nick asked me to join him at Treasury, which opened the door for me to higher levels of public service.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: The point is this: if I had not forced myself to get up from my desk, taken the stairs up to the 15th floor, and presented myself to his office that day, the rest of my life would have been very different, and I would not be standing here today.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Mustering that little bit of initiative changed my life.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: A little initiative can make all the difference in anyone's career.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: ConclusionI will conclude by encouraging you to think beyond yourselves.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Each of you has the capability to achieve success in any field you choose; it is important that you also consider how to give back and use your gifts to make a difference.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Reflect on the motto of this school: "law is but the means; justice is the end."

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Many of you have served at law clinics where you stood up for underrepresented individuals and organizations.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: And many of you will play important roles in the military, at nonprofits, and in governments around the world.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Each generation has an obligation to move us closer to the ideal, as embodied by the famous image of blindfolded Lady Justice holding the scales.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: You should count yourselves among the luckiest in all our society to graduate from this institution, to have the support of loved ones through three grueling years, and the health and other good fortune not to get tripped up along the way.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Several years ago, one of my predecessors, Ben Bernanke, said, "Those who are the luckiest .

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: also have the greatest responsibility to work hard, to contribute to the betterment of the world, and to share their luck with others."

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I cannot improve upon that.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: I thank you for having me.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Georgetown will always hold a special place in my heart.

title: Georgetown University Law Center Commencement Address
sentence_text: Thank you again to Dean Treanor and all the faculty, and the hardiest of congratulations to the Class of 2024.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: It is a pleasure to be here today.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: I will begin with the economy and the road ahead for monetary policy before briefly discussing the Federal Reserve's monetary policy independence.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Over the past year, inflation has come down significantly but is still running above the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) 2 percent goal.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In February, headline inflation was 2.5 percent over the past 12 months based on the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) index.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: A year earlier, it was 5.2 percent.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Core inflation, which excludes the volatile food and energy components, stood at 2.8 percent; a year ago, it was 4.8 percent.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: While this progress is welcome, the job of sustainably restoring 2 percent inflation is not yet done.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Tight monetary policy continues to weigh on demand, particularly in interest-sensitive spending categories.Nonetheless, growth in economic activity and employment was strong in 2023, as real gross domestic product expanded more than 3 percent and 3 million jobs were created, even as inflation fell substantially.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: This combination of outcomes reflects significant improvements in supply that offset to some extent the effects on demand of tighter financial conditions.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The healing of global supply chains helped address pent-up demand for goods, particularly in sectors that had faced considerable shortages, such as autos.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In addition, labor supply increased significantly, thanks to rising participation among 25-to-54-year-olds, as well as a strong pace of immigration.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Recent readings on both job gains and inflation have come in higher than expected.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The economy added an average of 265,000 jobs per month in the three months through February, a faster pace than we have seen since last June.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And the higher inflation data over January and February were above the low readings in the second half of last year.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The recent data do not, however, materially change the overall picture, which continues to be one of solid growth, a strong but rebalancing labor market, and inflation moving down toward 2 percent on a sometimes bumpy path.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Labor market rebalancing is evident in data on quits, job openings, surveys of employers and workers, and the continued gradual decline in wage growth.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: On inflation, it is too soon to say whether the recent readings represent more than just a bump.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We do not expect that it will be appropriate to lower our policy rate until we have greater confidence that inflation is moving sustainably down toward 2 percent.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Given the strength of the economy and progress on inflation so far, we have time to let the incoming data guide our decisions on policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We have held our policy rate at its current level since last July.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As shown in the individual projections the FOMC released two weeks ago, my colleagues and I continue to believe that the policy rate is likely at its peak for this tightening cycle.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: If the economy evolves broadly as we expect, most FOMC participants see it as likely to be appropriate to begin lowering the policy rate at some point this year.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Of course, the outlook is still quite uncertain, and we face risks on both sides.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Reducing rates too soon or too much could result in a reversal of the progress we have seen on inflation and ultimately require even tighter policy to get inflation back to 2 percent.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But easing policy too late or too little could unduly weaken economic activity and employment.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As progress on inflation continues and labor market tightness eases, these risks continue to move into better balance.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: As conditions evolve, monetary policy is well positioned to confront either of these risks.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are making decisions meeting by meeting, and we will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: That brings me to my second topic.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Fed has been assigned two goals for monetary policy—maximum employment and stable prices.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our success in delivering on these goals matters a great deal to all Americans.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: To support our pursuit of those goals, Congress granted the Fed a substantial degree of independence in our conduct of monetary policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Fed policymakers serve long terms that are not synchronized with election cycles.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our decisions are not subject to reversal by other parts of the government, other than through legislation.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: This independence both enables and requires us to make our monetary policy decisions without consideration of short-term political matters.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Such independence for a federal agency is and should be rare.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In the case of the Fed, independence is essential to our ability to serve the public.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The record shows that independent central banks deliver better economic outcomes.1

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We recognize that we need to continually earn this grant of independence, and we do so by carrying out our work with technical competence and objectivity, in a transparent and accountable manner, and by sticking to our knitting.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: By technical competence, I mean that Fed policymakers use the most up-to-date information and research to deepen our understanding of the ever-evolving economy and to reliably deliver on our assigned goals.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are supported by a highly capable staff.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We also draw on the insights and experiences of a wide array of business, academic, community, and labor leaders, as well as others engaged in the economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: And by objective, I mean that our analysis is free from any personal or political bias, in service to the public.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We will not always get it right—no one does.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But our decisions will always reflect our painstaking assessment of what is best for our economy in the medium and longer term—and nothing else.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Transparency and accountability are fundamental for any government agency in a democracy but are especially important for one granted policy independence.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Fed has a special obligation to explain ourselves clearly—to describe what we are doing and why we are doing it.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are always striving to improve on this communication, and it is a job that is never complete.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: But we have come a long way.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Before 1994, the FOMC did not even announce our monetary policy decisions.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Today we announce those decisions and explain the thinking behind them in our post meeting statement and press conference.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We publish detailed minutes of our deliberations and a quarterly summary of the economic and policy projections of each FOMC participant.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We publish a monetary policy report twice a year, and the Chair appears before Congress to present that report and answer any and all questions that are on the minds of our oversight committee members.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In 2020, we completed a yearlong public review of our monetary policy framework, and late this year, we will begin another such review.2My colleagues and I explain our views on the economic outlook and monetary policy in speeches like this one, and in visits to communities across the country, as part of extensive outreach in which we seek input from individuals and groups throughout society.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Transparency is an affirmative and proactive commitment to the public.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: To maintain the public's trust, we also need to avoid "mission creep."

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Our nation faces many challenges, some of which directly or indirectly involve the economy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Fed policymakers are often pressed to take a position on issues that are arguably relevant to the economy but are not within our mandate, such as particular tax and spending policies, immigration policy, and trade policy.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Climate change is another current example.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: Policies to address climate change are the business of elected officials and those agencies that they have charged with this responsibility.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The Fed has received no such charge.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We do, however, have a narrow role that relates to our responsibilities as a bank supervisor.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: The public will expect that the institutions we regulate and supervise will understand and be able to manage the material risks that they face, which, over time, are likely to include climate-related financial risks.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We will remain alert to the risk that there will be pressure to expand that role over time.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: We are not, nor do we seek to be, climate policymakers.

title: Opening Remarks
sentence_text: In short, doing our job well requires that we respect the limits of our mandate.
